full_transcript: hi everyone hi have any tom tan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new pianos become the teeth record keep you these guys are a Baltimore rock aha hi everyone blunt theny ich tanto here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the New Zealand banks record broke with expensive tastes Azealia Banks is a new york-based chinks in her armor for one she's not that versatile of a rapper and she's a kind of subpar singer - still there aren't that many notable hip-hop artists out right now that are fusing rap music with house at least not the way that they used to in the days of Missy Elliott and Rob bass and even Technotronic artists whose influences ring pretty clear in say Leah's music and the song - one - is undeniably one of the best singles hip house has had in years given the distance between this album and - one - I'm kind of in my head left questioning are we just going to have another Kreayshawn here sort of an overnight sensation who just waited too long to capitalize on her one single hit and also completely lacks the potential to come out with another viral single but personally I can't really see it playing out like that I think we're going to hear more from Azalea in the future because as far as the Kreayshawn comparison she is on another talent level she sounds great on a beat she's got flow even though I'm not always in love with her singing I do think the Mel that she tries to sing a lot of the time aren't too bad and I also don't get the sense that her music is is novelty in any way even though some of her singles have been pretty awful and even though that Atlantis video was completely gross and tasteless Azalea is a serious musician zeliha is really trying on this record and the results are here for the most part she brings on a series of very reputable interesting producers on this LP Machinedrum loan MJ Cole a rap music one track here grabs a very brave and interesting enon sample and we also have vodka even Ariel pink among others I actually like a lot of the instrumentals on this record even on some tracks where I don't like azalea's singing at all like on the opener here the Bee is pretty progressive and kind of interesting but when the lyrics and the songwriting coming together with a good instrumental we get a great track like on give me a chance the song that I mentioned has that enon sample really funky bass line and drum break on this thing and then toward the end of the track it makes a surprise turn into Latin music totally changes up the beat we get a great horn section and Zelia is even rapping in Spanish it's ambitious and really turns out great Azealia drifts away from some of the house instrumentals that were used to hearing her on and hops on a few bangers which I'm glad she did for the sake of variety like on heavy metal and reflective I like her lyrics on this track although I think that the song really could have used a hi-hat regardless the track has a completely unexpected Blade Runner reference inside of it then we have desperado fantastic song MJ Cole actually did the production here I love the UK garage flavored instrumental on this thing the haunting melody the desperado vocal sample the song instrumentally is top-notch and as far as Elia goes she works her way into this preconceived beat pretty well we get the song BBD another trap electro flavored banger with some pretty good lyrics as well the song ice princess which is more lyrical brags but as Elia works in a ton of cold and ice and winter references throughout this track and we also get the songs to unto and young Rapunzel she's still trying to get mileage out of these older stale singles though they still don't sound that bad here and and still add to the overall character of the record - one - I hope you've heard and young rapunzel is easily one of her most interesting singles even if you don't think it's one of her best which features some strange screams really loud coughing this beat it's like she's pulling from some Atari teenage riot or even some prodigy the song is dark it's epic it's wild I can't deny it even though I didn't expect it this record has quite a bit going for it but it's also got a lot of downsides and feels like an album put together by somebody who in the music industry is relatively rare and behind the ears it feels very much like a debut album that doesn't know what direction it wants to go in not only that but there are elements of this record that just aren't that polished like the singing constantly azalea just functions off of these sort of corny musical theater inspired vocal inflections where she just throws her voice she's just singing from the back of her throat most of the time well it sounds like she's just putting on a voice or when she's rapping she's just throwing her voice down a few registers trying to give the appearance that her voices is deeper than it really is which is just not the case because what she tries to sing in her lower register that is where she is missing the most notes I feel like Azealia tries to give us these kind of over-the-top maybe somewhat theatrical inflections but she doesn't have the range or the passion or the power to really sell it in the same way someone like Lady gaga someone who is similarly excessive when it comes to vocals and we get weak singing on track after track after track soda Wallis luxury and the closer whereas Elyas vocals are actually mixed really horribly with the beat the song just sounds like a demo and it's maybe the worst way the album could have ended there are moments where I'm impressed with azalea's beat choices when I like her flow when her rapping isn't that bad or her lyric writing but when it comes to her singing it's like the smoke screen just drops and it's revealed that instead of listening to a gray album I'm watching some toddlers and tiaras style talent show which is not cute when the contestants are in their 20s and I can't even begin to talk about how ridiculous and unnecessary the song nude beach go-go was on this record which again is just Azealia singing over an instrumental over a track that is going to be on Ariel Pink's new record I hope Ariel pick out a good paycheck out of this because she took a perfectly good song and turned it into something that sounds like it's from the bye-bye birdie soundtrack on Maui and this song actually makes me rethink the whole Azealia Banks not being novelty thing I said toward the beginning of this review because there are so many beats on this record that have a life outside of Zee Leah's music it just seems like she's not really writing or creating a lot of these songs but just finding beats and then make up your own words I'm feeling a strong v to light six on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I could be eBay's hi everyone Kathy plantino here the internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new wild birds and peace drums record rhythm wild birds and peace drums is a husband-wife musical duo they hail from Sweden this is their third full-length studio album if you're not counting the compilation sister EP record they put out back in 2010 typically wild birds and peace drums records feature the fantastic singing of miriam will lenten and the fantastic drumming of berlin and that's pretty much it the duo is able to embrace influences hailing from jazz and art pop and maybe even a little bit of a folk music and blues too but just with drums and vocals a lot of the time of course on their sophomore record the snake they did bring in some extra instrumentation to I guess kind of progress past they're very minimal beginnings on their debut album and even though it's been about eight years since the release of the snake it's not that Miriam and andreas haven't been busy or doing other things they of course last year together worked on Miriam solo record Miriam the believer not to say that she did the album all by herself but on this record it felt like more of a solo effort because she was really flexing her singer/songwriter muscles and let's also not forget and Riis's and Marian's participation in the fire orchestra who came out with two albums recently both of which they participated on and now that they've done their thing in in fire orchestra they came out with that amazing blood donation Marian the believer record they are getting back to the roots of what made them so popular in the first place and that's wild birds and peace drums now this thing is nine tracks it's 40 minutes and sonically it's not quite as minimal as their early stuff there are tracks that are simply for the most part just vocals and drums like the song ghosts and pains the intro track of this LP which rides heavy on a lot of vocal refrains making it very catchy despite its instrumental simplicity along with the song who I was which is the shortest track on the I record and maybe the most infectious to Merriam's vocals sounding amazing on this track so powerful so much range so much passion few singers could carry a record with just drums and and Miriam is certainly one of those voices and of course with many of these tracks just being vocals and drums lyrics kind of stick out like a sore thumb and a lot of the lyrics on this record at least from what I can observe seem to have a lot to do with relationships love and not just like this initial kind of lust fueled love more of like this long-term interconnectedness and the joy that can come from that be complications that can come from that this message was very perfectly displayed in the cover and single art for this record now there are tracks that feature other instrumental accompaniment but what comes into play is very subtle like with the song the offbeat which features quite a bit of vocal overdubbing maybe if you vocal samples here and there and some very quiet but sporadic jumpy and somewhat glitchy synthesizers that progressively get louder as the song moves on feels like something that could have been lifted out of an LCD Soundsystem track the song keeps some hope seems to be aided by quite a bit of vocal overdubbing as well and then there's a big bassline helping out the usual drum and vocal work on the track gold-digger there's also this growing ethereal atmosphere that i think is coming through with some just reverb soaked background vocals on the back end of this track - and just with all of this sonic color being put into the song this track would have fit pretty comfortably on Miriam solo LP there are some moments where like a really primal drum beat that is fast paced and just intense or some really kooky background vocals might remind me of like a a tune yards record or something like that but not as much of a pop appeal way more raw way more energetic it's more of just a comparison than an influence or anything like that because these songs also sound like wild birds and peace drums previous stuff it's not a comparison I just want to do to death for the most part the additional layers which are very quiet a lot of the time work really well they work in favor of this album's appeal the only moment that I think it works against this record is the song soft wind soft death where we have Miriam singing she's multi-tracked her voice so many times to the point where her vocals are huge they're slow they're sweeping they're gorgeous I love the melody of this track but the drumbeat which fades in to the track we didn't get a hard start on this song we get this kind of weird fade like we're happening upon the middle of this song just feels like it's coming from a completely different world the vocals and the drums may be working at the same tempo but it's almost as if the pacing and the groove of the vocals isn't really complemented by the drums and vice-versa there are also some moments like the closing track on here the feature some really interesting maybe slightly Kate Bush esque spoken-word passages despite being built out of such a simple instrumental foundation this record stays somewhat varied and and entertaining um nearly every track here wild birds and peace drums just come with the same fantastic level of talent they usually do but maybe with just a little bit more accessibility on these new tracks I'm feeling a strong seven to a light eight on this thing transition if you've given this record of listened what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana wild birds and peace drums

of guitars and drums I love the downstroke guitar riffs on this thing really pummeling great groove but there are moments where the sort of low fire recording of this track holds back the intensity of hi everyone each Sinise crashed an O here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new arca a lemn zen hey Dori nori come here Oh duh baby isn't it Oh baby this little baby's so cute ARCA is the pseudonym of a Venezuelan electronic music producer who has been having a pretty great past couple of years back in 2012 mr. Alejandro Garcia here released a couple of EPS on uno NYC records these EPS outside of a few websites and some core fans didn't really drum up a huge buzz for arca but it did end up landing him a taking part in her fantastic new album as well and now that he has this newfound buzz he seems to be pulling back a little bit and concentrating on his solo stuff releasing a full-length commercial debut right here on mute records now Arcas material on these past aps some incredibly strange and unorthodox stuff some really glitchy and warped combinations of hip-hop and electronic music to the point where it was kind of difficult to tell where one genre started and the other ended listening to these EPS though they may be incredibly abstracted points there are arca isms here that also show up on the new fka twigs records so that there is a pretty clear connection this artist made these sounds here then he made them here and I see these similarities however these similarities aren't quite as apparent when I listen to Zen arca seems to be doing something pretty different on this record there aren't as many commonalities here with his past work there are 15 tracks on this thing they number up to 40 minutes and even though they may be very explorative and strange just like the music on the stretch EPS a lot of the hip-hop influences have completely just dissipated many tracks here are actually kind of boundary-less synthetic motifs mitii Diddy's if you will there are moments where I feel like I'm not listening to the guy that produced fka twigs I'm listening to OneNote tracks but I guess I was kind of surprised at just how minimal Arcos approach was on much of this record there are moments when I'm kind of underwhelmed by the synth work even though the Tambor maybe some of the few effects laid onto these sense might be interesting the performances and the playing are actually not that inspiring especially on a track like family violence which is just like a junk pile of fake strings too busy tripping over itself to actually play anything coherent even though I appreciate the experimental nature of some of these songs this is not the genre bending and defying production that was on those stretchy EPS that was on that ampersand mixtape this is kind of predictable despite its lack of accessibility the meteor and more layered tracks in the track listing here are actually much more enjoyable even if many of them are as structureless or as boundary-less as many of the more simple stripped back tracks here like the title track here which kicks off with these strange horrifying horror movie sound effects right at the start mash with these huge hits of sub bass there are some skittering rhythms here and some really eerie sinfully it's moments like this where this record sounds super unique and I wish our code just delivered more instances or the song thievery which is just as cavernous and strange and warp but there's like this reggaeton rhythm underneath these icy synths and just a cacophony of percussion and samples the song tongue is creepy and spine-tingling as well with these high-pitched drones and really weird since stabs and the song sisters is one of the few moments here with a very loose instrumentation though it doesn't really lined up maybe it's not perfectly quantized or anything like that despite the looseness what the music is playing is actually pretty gorgeous especially the tambour of the since on this track it's like listening to light shining through diamonds but tracks like this only make up a portion of the record the best songs here find some really interesting combinations of beauty and darkness but for every moment there is like that there's also a kind of formless underwhelming interlude a musical bridge to nowhere I really like about half the tracks here I enjoy the aesthetic of the album anyway even if I'm not liking the composition of these songs I'm feeling a light too decent six on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana ARCA Zen forever

uh-uh hi everyone strengthening board canto here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new the world is a beautiful place and I'm no longer afraid to die album EP really between bodies these guys are a connecticut-based emo and indie rock act whose full-length debut album that came out not too long ago impressed me enough to talk about it because personally lately I have been mighty underwhelmed by much of what people would be calling the emo revival right now which I think naming it as such is a little disingenuous camera given that emo began in the mid 80s and has continued to exist as a thriving relevant underground rock movement since then not to mention that just ten years ago this genre was at its peak of cultural relevancy and it is no longer at that level of relevancy because every musical trend and movement has a shelf life it has a certain span of time at which it holds the general public's attention and you must either evolve or accept niche relevancy take jazz music into account which evolved heavily through the 50s the 60s and the 70s and punk music from the 70s the 80s and the 90s and emo has undergone similar evolutions as well but I'm finding very little novelty in this latest strain of groups but I get it emo is not really sold on the premise of being progressive or experimental rather cathartic emotionally the genre appeals through its Punk energy with an emphasis on melody and poetic lyrics and sort of twinkly guitars and impassioned vocal performances al be it a little angsty many of these newer groups have stuck very passionately to this blueprint and as has the world is a beautiful place however I did find this group to be a little bit more dynamic experimenting with post-rock huge chorus vocals even a little bit of sort of weird kitschy gimmicky novelty music on some of their EPS uses and they are on another experimental aunt on this new EP of theirs as well between bodies this time the band is providing instrumentals and some backing vocals occasionally some lead vocals as well as atop all of this instrumentation and singing we get spoken word from mr. Chris Suzumiya on nearly every track here Chris can be heard delivering these shouted declarations on life death times space stars the beginning the end pretty much everything and when I say everything I don't mean like bricks and bottles and ballpoint pens everything I mean I'm trying to say something super important and super deep right now everything and as I said earlier these poetic diatribes are supported by the world is a beautiful places typically slow twinkly melodic rock instrumentation these instrumentals are dynamic they progress in a very linear fashion maybe this is something the band is experimenting with a little bit more here because they're not working with a verse chorus verse structure they can just kind of move as they please as long as you can hear Chris's vocals audibly or maybe just sort of intensify as he intensifies some of the instrumentals are really slow burners they're growers some have a really strong backing beat they're a little straightforward and others are much more abstracted and noisy the band does a really great job of complementing Chris I think Chris does a great job of complementing the band performance wise I actually enjoyed this album quite a bit in concept even though this sort of thing has really turned me off in the past especially in the case of bands like listener where you're kind of getting these generic indie rock instrumentals is kind of playing in the background with some spoken word on top that is just cringe-worthy there's even something about the tracks on this EP that reminds me of a recent snap judgment story or performance that you can check on YouTube with someone a 15 year old by the name of Noah st. John telling a story about his mother's getting divorced and they're driving in this CRV and he thinks that they're going to break up in front of him but then fact he learns that they're going to be staying together and their family is forever and so on and so forth it's very moving to me this new EP kind of functions on a very similar premise however it's not quite as effective and in my opinion it could have been more effective because the recording on this thing is great the band plays really well I think the instrumentals they come together with are great the vocals are nice but after a few tracks on this record in my opinion Chris becomes difficult to stand honestly it's like he's trying to force this sense of importance in everything that he's saying he's trying to force this sense of emotional weight in everything that he's saying he's just freaking out over the most obvious and common of statements like oh we're made of the same stuff as the stars like maybe that statement has some kind of impact if you're hearing it for the first time on this record but that has been said again and again and again and there's nothing about Chris's approach to saying this line and many other adages on this record that is really all that stunning or emotionally moving not only that but I don't really feel like he backs up anything that he says because he seems just rattle off one abstract idea after another maybe there are some very real coherent tangible things that inspired some of these songs but you wouldn't really know it from just observing the lyrics in the abstract it's like Chris tries to get to everything and because he doesn't focus on any of it it sort of all adds up to nothing which is kind of a shame because I think in concept this EP was really great I like the instrumentals but the lyrics play just too big a part in the making of this record to just outright ignore them and just enjoy everything else about the record I'm feeling a strong five to a light six on this thing transition if you've given this record a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana have a nice day music forever

and lp's self-titled debut as run the jewels and yeah I think I think this record was an improvement on most fronts on the beats on the guests on the hooks the bars the rapping were roughly the same botanist album VI flora this is an experimental low five very bright and blissful black metal record with drums vocals some bass guitar some harmonium on a track or two but not guitars but hammered dulcimer and it has led to a really interesting sound for this project a sound that no other black metal project has right now while it is very rough and it is very harsh and there are some very visceral tracks on this record for the most part the just the tambour of the dulcimer and just the the production sound of this record is so bright and so pleasant that it's got this really interesting mix of just her and Oh beautiful and those are my favorite full lengths from the past few months thank you for watching you're the best Anthony Fantana music forever

hi everyone I love to me you tan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Deerhoof record la snap bonito 20 years as a band and I believe this is their 13th full-length album if I'm wrong on that I'm sure in the comments you'll correct me over the years that they have been a band they've undergone numerous lineups some sound changes but it wasn't the 2000s that they kind of evolved into this style that they're working with currently which has made them one of the most fun-loving idiosyncratic rock and pop groups in the underground Deerhoof is one of those groups that sounds unique as a whole because there are so many unique individual parts that go into the finished product so Tomi is very light hi childlike vocals as well as her kind of esoteric and absurd lyrics Greg's very aggressive frantic groovy and danceable drumbeats and John and Ed's very sharp angular and sometimes very dissonant guitar leads the band is also well known for using some pretty strange chord progressions on their tracks - or time signatures and even though Deerhoof has settled into a pretty familiar style at this point they do make sure to throw in a few left hooks or surprises into every release they are constantly creative and in my opinion rarely disappoint if you're new to the band I suggest you try anything from the album apple o to friend opportunity but as far as their more recent stuff goes we have the album offend Maggie which was easily one of their most straightforward distorted and rough albums so far maybe even to a slight fault because so many of the songs on this record in my opinion sound very much the same because of the kind of harsh recording then we have versus evil which by contrast was a very dynamic and lush record at times with some of dear hopes most tender and beautiful songs yet while delivering their their usual collection of very uppity poppy catchy very fun tracks as well and on the record breakup song their previous record they experimented quite a on some tracks with some electronics some samples but on their latest here lie they seem to be getting back to basics not really fooling around with speaks to the cover are you're looking at something kind of black and white grayscale but it's kind of distorted and warped too it's like watching epic Saturday morning cartoons on an old old television that is seriously on the fritz as you consume massive amounts of the most sugary cereals known to man the drums on this record they're loud they're booming they're harsh the bass is very resonant the guitars are very sharp and shrill and have kind of a very metallic tone to them they are sunburnt and so Tony's vocals are very loud they're very close in this loudness in this straightforwardness again this record reminds me of a fen Maggie but I think Deerhoof comes off a little more dynamic on this record writing some softer tracks some prettier tracks too and simultaneously deer hoof in my opinion actually delivers some of their heaviest material as well on this record this isn't the first time deer hoof has work with quirky extremes on a record of theirs and they do it again here pretty well too we have the song big house waltz which has this huge massive bass drone on it that's fit up against this killer drum be some awesome guitar melodies so Tomi brings forward these vocals at one point that sound like she's like a ringleader at a circus there's a really strange guitar passage toward the back end with the track deer hoof they might be writing something catchy but they always find a way to throw a wrench in the works and do something weird and the song exit only has one of the most aggressive heavy and hard-hitting drum beats and guitar riffs to ever land on a deer cuff album ever there's the song mirror monster one of the more gentle tracks on the LP that features all these fluttering guitars there's some very tender vocal melodies and harmonies on this thing I love the way the chord progression of this track ascends and resolves and there's the song black pitch which has this very twinkly pretty guitar intro that sounds a lot like something that would have been more marketable in the indie scene in the 2000s when Deerhoof was doing much weirder stuff as much as I like the harsh moments on this record it's nice to hear some pretty songs as well especially since the more beautiful spots were what attracted me so much to versus evil the one major downside to this track is the kind of abrupt ending and the closer Oh bummer is is another track that is a little softer a little more melodic though this track is maybe the dreariest of any song on the record with a vocal melody that's that's absolutely nightmarish and emotionally painful and Deerhoof make sure to balance tracks like this out with songs that are unbearably fun like the song doom which is loaded with melodies that sound like I'm on a psychedelic island filled with squawking polkadot parrots and dancing coconuts there's some pretty male/female vocals on this track as well and this is one of the few tracks on the record that kind of follows in an unpredictable linear structure there are a few tracks on this record that are kind of average for Deerhoof like paradise girls not amazing or totally new song for them but this track would be nice on a mix for a girl who is smart and plays bass guitar because that's what the song is about a girl who is smart and plays bass guitar and I wish the song God to was longer it's a really great instrumental that I wish just had more length to it and I wish that for a few other tracks on here too as creative and as fun as some of these songs are I kind of feel like Deerhoof came in brought some interesting ideas brought a great recording but sort of dipped out early on some of these tracks to me this is another entertaining album from Dieruff I wouldn't say there's anything incredibly ambitious about it in comparison with other Dieruff releases or that there's really anything that fantastic about the flow of this album either for sure there's a nice variety of songs here but it still kind of just feels like a standard mixed bag of tracks whose only continuous thread is the band style and the kind of Bhoomi shrill production what ends up saving this record and makes it great given this album a listen what did you think of it did you look did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it yeah Anthony Fantan oh dear huff forever

I was throwing nap and a Tuesday I think it's cuz I eat too much food hey I was throwing up and a Tuesday hi everyone why am I doing this Tara here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Slipknot album 0.5 the gray chapter Slipknot our Des Moines Iowa metal band known for their numerous members they're kind of creepy masks and for their massive popularity in the new metal movement in the 2000s in my first half of high school I was a pretty big fan of this band I caught them live at one point when I was younger I thought that their self-titled album was like the most hardcore shit on the planet and I bought Iowa when it first came out - and I love the hell out of that record as well but very soon afterwards I kind of fell out of favor with Slipknot not only because it seemed like frontman Corey Taylor was sort of spending a little bit more time with Stone Sour and I didn't really care for that band at the time I just I really hated sort of those dreary sad alternative metal bands like stained and in my opinion that's kind of the direction Stone Sour was going and so it was not vibing with that it was not my style I was young and angry and then on their next record vol 3 I started to hear that sad sappy stuff begin to leak into their sound and their style so I was just I used to really dig their stuff and and there are some groups from my teen years that I have gone back and ivory listened to some of which I've been able to enjoy more and appreciate but some groups like Slipknot have really not aged that well with time in my opinion because now when I listen to some of their older stuff I hear just a lot of cringe-worthy lyrics and lowbrow anger and very safe alt metal production and now that I listen to things more closely and I have a better grasp of instrumentation and production it's just very clear how non-essential some of the Bay members here are 2 Slipknot's core sound which is essentially guitars drums and vocals like many other bands in their genre but there are some things in Slipknot's music that I can look back upon fondly for one I think that their guitar tone is still pretty gnarly these days and Corey Taylor is maybe one of the most ravenous just Mad Men vocalist of nu metal I think he's a good screamer I think he's a good singer and though I may not always enjoy his lyrics there is a seriously real feeling of anguish and frustration that comes through in his performances as a kid I loved Slipknot for their extremity like I said I thought their self-titled record was like the most hardcore shit ever but then once I got in hardcore punk and later into grindcore and some thrash metal and death metal and some black metal more recently in doom metal 2 what made for extreme music was instantly reframed I had heard harder heavier faster and mean our music Slipknot no longer scratches those itches for me which essentially leaves them standing on the pretty flimsy leg of songwriting which I think they used to have a really strong prominent element of on their early stuff tracks like wait and bleed are still pretty decent tracks and I think they did a really good job of melding pop hooks with their extreme aggression on Iowa even better with songs like heretic if you fought fat sack jack socks as well as people equal shit still today I think that sound kicks ass and I think Iowa does the best job of any record in Slipknot's discography when it comes to just putting the Slipknot mission statement out there the fast riffs the pummeling drums the self-loathing lyrics the nihilism the hatred of humanity but since Iowa the band has kind of sweeten their sound and now that they've done that and I guess now that I've heard other things they're not exactly as menacing as they used to be there are some songs on this record like scar tast Rafi great title that get the fifteen-year-old inside of me clenching fess and getting into mosh stance there are some familiar themes on the song of being sort of an outsider being misunderstood not taking the world's crap killing everything that killed you I was really impressed on this track by the passage of very warped tremolo guitars set against some very fast speedy blast beats it sounded really twisted but on this song as well and on a few other moments too we get some turntable scratching set up against these new metal riffs and instantaneously the album just sounds so tasteless and dated there are other equally aggressive tracks but very few of them are actually as catchy as scart Astra fee or approaching original violence which i think is another decent track know when Slipknot go poppy and catchy which I know they can do while staying aggressive the whole time when they go poppy and catchy they incorporate these sweet clean voiced ultra melodic hooks which in their defense wait and bleed is one of those tracks but that track does not quite step over the cleanliness line that a song like the devil and I does which considering that title there's no reason for this hook to sound that wimpy if I wanted this kind of vocal overacting I would go listen to disturbed you know you're in a weird situation where you were thinking of reasons to listen to disturbed but maybe in a weird way I would prefer to do that than listen to a song like kill pop which it seems like Corey Taylor is diving into this like self-harming narrative revolving around this girl in my opinion Slipknot does not do sad well they do not do sorrow well I get them on that aggression level there I feel like they really know that very well but when they go sad it just sounds so melodramatic it sounds so forced it sounds so corny and though they may be addressing some serious topics when they do when they perform a sadder song rarely does the depression actually translate through so that completely rules out many a track on this record for likeability then as I said earlier you have a lot of these aggressive tracks that you know are no hi everyone anime money tornado here the internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new black milk record if there's a hell below black milk detroit MC and producer he's been at it for over a decade now and he is dropping his sixth full-length album right here a record i was kind of surprised was coming out so fast given that his last full-length album was out just a year ago no poison no paradise and of course i was looking forward to this album because I enjoyed that album the production on this record is grimy it's low Phi it's jazzy it's funky there are loads of textured synthesizers peppered throughout these beats if you're into people like J Dilla or mad lib or Kareem brigands you're gonna enjoy the beats on this record I still had my minor reservations with black milks rapping as I had on some of his previous records but uh no poison no paradise black milks lack of enthusiasm and technical skill was made up for by some of his most personal verses yet a lot of songs on this record were coming from a sort of dark introspective and occasionally nostalgic place and maybe there was a chance that this next record of his would be even more hellish and dark given that the title is if there's a Hell below that's what I thought in theory but in actuality this record isn't really all that hellish no more hellish than no poison no paradise there are a few exceptions in the tracklist here but for the most part the beats on this new record come from roughly the same place and milk's delivery is roughly the same as well not that I expect a whole ton of progression within a year's time but there's such a lack of progression on this record that Black Milk openly revisits topics that he talked about on his last album whether that be some of his family or just trying to survive and continue and stay successful in hip-hop I guess all I can say about this record is that Black Milk is at what I suppose is a very reflective point in his career and he just feels affordable rapping about what he knows like on the song what it's worth which is another visit to black milk's mental hustle in the hip-hop industry reminding himself of why he does what he does for his fans for his fans it's not that exciting but the determination is admirable then there's tracks like leave the bones behind with blue and blues guest verse isn't bad but this song is severely under produced it's like just a loop from a song used as a beat which I guess there are fantastic songs that in the past function off of that simplicity that minimalism but it doesn't really keep the track interesting here especially since Black Milk isn't really that electrifying of a rapper to begin with the song every day was is another nostalgic look into black milk's past with him being in school kids banging on desks making beats causing ruckus dropouts failed rap dreams and another similarly muddy vocal hook that feel a little cloudy in the same way that the vocals were kind of cloudy on black notes last record then we get tracks on here like scum with random acts which is the trio that Black Milk has made music with previously featuring Sean price and guilty Simpson and this song has some decent verses from guilty and Sean though I do kind of cringe just a little bit at that you rap dude do but on top of that this song doesn't really feel like one song but rather three different songs because the beat changes up significantly when guilty enters the picture when Sean enters the picture and it's like things shift so much that I don't even feel like I'm listening to the same track anymore and there are other tracks here that feels similarly disjointed or have like a little weird instrumental interlude tacked on right at the end of the track that doesn't really add anything to the equation for me the most fun and interesting track on the entire record which is also maybe the most unorthodox track for Black Milk is Detroit's new dance show which has this awesome beat that sounds like I don't know the the the backing instrumental to what would be a dance music competition on like some public-access television show where people are just popping and locking in breakdancing black milk has some alright lyrics on this track but I have to admit I don't really love the song for its lyrics as much as I do it's instrumental flavor and its groove there's also the song story in her which when it begins it kind of starts like an inconspicuous old love old flame old crush story where Black Milk is meeting up with someone who at one time he had feelings for she never really gave him the time of day she was with other guys and meeting up with her later in life she is interested now they get together and then there is a super crazy twist ending that I did not expect at all so Black Milk does have a few tricks up his sleeve in the tracklisting here but much of what he delivers on this record is relatively average for him at this point in his career I'm getting a lot of the same ideas and expressions and themes that I did on his last LP but for reasons of either production or lyric writing or lack of hook or something like that the material is just a little less compelling Black Milk really is treading some water on this record and he's delivered some less interesting instrumentals and there are some tracks here especially with the last two songs and the track listing that feel more like they are motifs ideas for songs than they are fully realized and fleshed out songs I did come away liking this album for the most part but you know nowhere near loving it or amazed or surprised I'm feeling a light too decent 6 on this thing transition if you've given this album a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana here mm-hmm Black Milk forever also down there in the description box you can find a link to watch a review of the new EP The Canadian art rock and post-punk band Ock has a new EP out and I give my thoughts on that EP via the link in the description box cool cool

hi everyone dandy try potato here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new pharmacon record beast eale burden pharmacon is the musical project of noise maker margaret Chartier she is on her second full-length album here for sacred bones records a label that kind of took a risk signing her because she toys with a genre that the label doesn't necessarily cater to all the time that genre being power electronics one of the most harsh unforgiving and difficult subgenres in modern music the only thing grosser than Margaret's music are her album covers maggots but also making it difficult to get into this music a lot of people who make power electronics are incredibly prolific they will drop limited-run editions of their music onto tape the live performances of this music are often freakish and very loud very ear piercing it's not the kind of scene that tries to cater to the average music listener whether that comes to its sound the way these people structure their albums the way they market themselves and get their music out there so it's interesting to see an artist like Margaret who is in this genre making so much headway though I would argue her music is not 100% power electronics not even close really there's a mix of death industrial and just industrial noise in there as well all genres and labels aside mark Barger it makes tortured hellish music with very shrill demonic screams cavernous reverb heavy primal percussion and some searingly loud electronics it is not pleasant but for someone who enjoys harsh overwhelming dissonant and sometimes disorienting music it is only sometimes that pharmacon reaches that benchmark and then is able to hold on to it take the song intent or instinct for example as noisy as this song is it gets pretty mundane pretty fast it reaches a certain level of density with it's very simple rhythms with it's cycling feedback loop that plays over and over and over and over and the vocals too but then once it reaches that point it just plateaus for the duration of the track we get no significant progression or variation that leads the song to get more intense or more interesting it's sort of like jumping into a scalding hot bathtub only for it to get cold just a minute or two later I feel the same way about the track auto-immune and as far as the title track on this thing goes it's got some pretty simple but also dark backing instrumentation which only serves as a very bland foundation for Margaret's vocal freakout on the song which to me wasn't even really that blood-curdling not as much as other tracks here not as much as tracks off her debut record for sacred bones though I really did like the noisy intense finish of this track there are essentially four meaty songs on this record but then there are two other more inconsequential interlude tracks one of which kicks the record off doesn't sound that bad but one is kind of like a series of chokes coughs it sounds almost as if Margaret is making herself gag or throw up and is just recording the audio and then she kind of set a rhythm to it in my opinion the best track on this entire record is body betrays itself and that's mostly because it has the most significant progression out of any song not only that but the electronics on this thing just had this beautiful metallic ringing quality to them that is just really ear piercing the vocals are frightening and the rhythms are really nice they're pummeling they flow in a really fluid manner there's something about the groove and just the lumbering quality of this tracker reminds me of like some early swans stuff it's moments like this where pharmacon gets particularly twisted and Margaret's moans are like really really anguished the wall of electronics on this track is huge its massive this is the only moment on the record that in my opinion the aesthetic the quality of the aesthetic is met by the quality of the composition and that's a meeting that doesn't happen on the other tracks here in my opinion pharmacon has style but most of these tracks don't contain enough detail to keep the emotional intensity high I'm feeling a decent two strong five on this record transition if you given this album a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana music pharmacon scary scary forever

I am a person hey hey hey hey hi everyone fat Tony that tan though here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new botanist record 6 flora botanist is a one-man black metal project that is had a number of albums released thus far if we are to go by the Roman numerals on this record you can assume that this is the sixth installment of the ongoing botanist musical saga and even though I am reviewing this project just now I have been conscious of it for a while and while I can't say I have been a fan of the bottom use ik I have found it pretty interesting in that the approach taken to black metal in this project is kind of experimental it's lo-fi there is also hammered dulcimer yes hammered dulcimer which is a pretty strange choice for a black metal record and on previous botanist releases I thought it was just a little gimmicky however on this latest release we see the incorporation of some bass guitar and some harmonium and this hammered dulcimer is typically just compressed it's distorted it's just overblown to the point where it sounds kind of like a distorted guitar and now on this latest release we are getting the inclusion of some bass and some keyboards harmonium specifically this record is botanist at its most wonderful beautiful sounding most detailed botanist has one foot in the old harsh lo-fi world of black metal and another foot in the grave new world of black metal where the production and the melodies typically are very bright occasionally epic or uplifting the music on this record sounds kind of like sunrays or just a musical aurora borealis or like beautiful colorful exotic flowers which isn't too out of comparison considering that every single track on this record is named after a plant now this LP is 10 tracks long it's got an interlude at the end and again despite being black metal the the sound the tone of this record is pretty warm and fuzzy you have those wretched yeah vocals all over this record occasionally you know some clean vocals some whispers of course there are some really aggressive drums on this thing blast beats but despite all that this LP is kind of inviting don't go into this thing expecting that big polished soaring sound that you would get on like a deaf heaven record or a wolves and throne room record bond this style is much more raw visceral and direct and the inclusion of hammer dulcimer just like on previous releases continues to give botanists a sound like no other black metal project the sustain on the dulcimer is amazing for the style of music as well as the very metallic tone of these notes the instrumentation a lot of the time sounds gorgeous just as it does on tracks like the opener stargazer or Calais Steen on and even though the melodies on this record can sound beautiful things can take a turn for the dark really quickly just like on the tracks in a moment partha Ngoc salon where the melody here is so devilish that even the bright hammered dulcimer can't distract away from how just evil this lead is I wish the vocals were a little louder sometimes though they do sound quite harsh but they are mixed very low it's kind of like having somebody in a very scary way whisper to you as you press your ear against this wall of gorgeous sound the sound really draws you in but the moment you get you know really comfortable with it and you feel immersed in it you sort of find that there's this really just odd shadowy figure walking through it which for me was the case on the track teri though fight where the melody on this track is is very lullaby ish there are a few songs where the sustain of the hammered dulcimer may be brought together with the harmonium makes for a particularly droney soundscape very relaxing very gorgeous there are a few tracks here and there where you get a little bit of odd time signatures stuff and the song just before the closer is one of the most aggressive propulsive hard-hitting songs on the entire LP this this record really ends off with a bang I think compositionally this record has quite a bit of variety to it even if the very rough and lo-fi production leaves a lot of these songs feeling a little Sammy Sammy but even if all these tracks have a similarly hazy and fuzzy feel to them it's really the compositions underneath that that just attract me there are maybe two or three songs on this thing where I feel like maybe melodically these tracks are a little too basic I wish that the harmonium came in and did a little bit more or the bass or that I just wasn't getting some basic hammered dulcimer chords specifically on tracks like dianthus but still I came away from this album loving it I think this is botanist most complex and interesting album yet and I look forward to seeing this musical project progress into the future I'm feeling a light decent eight on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana botanist music forever

hi everyone Anthony Mel tanto here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new panda bear EP mr. Noah songwriter/producer Noah Lennox aka panda bear one of the main brains behind the neo experimental psychedelic pop outfit animal collective he's also pretty well known for his solo material as well albums such as person pitch and he has a new record on the way here's what it looks like many people thought this album was going to drop this year but no in fact it is going to be released in January of 2015 and mr. Lennox has seen fit to give us this new EP to kind of hold us over in the meantime I guess now let me say before going into this EP I had a relatively positive mindset even though I was not really big on panda bears last full-length album tomboy I felt the record was pretty repetitive it was redundant it felt like so little was going on and yet it was so warped and difficult to decipher and on top of that animal collectives last for length album centipede hurts not really a favorite of mine in their discography not to mention  in my opinion AV tears oh 4 - right now in the solo album department still animal collectives past full-length album successes still hold quite a bit of weight for me so at this point I really have no reason not to at least a little bit look forward to whatever panda bear is going to be doing on his next full-length album in this new EP now the song mr. Noah kicks this EP off and I guess it's also a lead single from the new panda bear album as well so I guess we're going to be hearing it in two different contexts but at least in the context of this EP anyway it's a pretty great start the song features driving beat it's kind of low Phi and it's recording it's layered it's trippy it's colorful if I'm not mistaken throughout the track panda bear incorporates a sample of like dogs whimpering throughout this track it's very apparent that guys like Brian Wilson still inform panda bears vocal style heavily and I love that descending vocal line he keeps using on this track Hey however panda bears vocal performances are just about as off point as my vocal performance just then he just doesn't seem to be as in tune on some parts of this song as he typically does on like an animal collective track I don't know if he's writing himself out of his range or maybe straining a little bit there are some points in his lower register where he just sounds a slightly goofy but instrumentally and melodically I still like this tune I think it has a lot of personality to it unlike centipede Hertz I feel like this track is an onion and I guess I'm sort of enjoying peeling those layers back but sometimes this cacophony can feel a little unnecessary sort of like on the next track the song faces in the crowd which has these swirling cycling synthesizers that a lot of the time I just feel like they're distracting away from what is just an all right song however with the very reverb icy melodies all over this track I do care a lot for the very blissful tone of this track then we get the song untying the knot which I think instrumentally is one of the most interesting tracks on the entire record we kick this song off with like some weird shamisen samples if I'm correct which are incorporated throughout the track and sound very wonderful then we get the layered repetitive vocals throughout this track which read a lot like a chant to me and with the primal beat backing all of it it feels very hypnotic and meditative and a lot like this track I find the closer to be pretty pleasant to the lyrics though sort of come from this place that feels a little esoteric for me you know Noah seems to be talking about the ocean as well as not eating fish it's another instance of panda bear taking something that feels like it was possibly informed by something very real and maybe something very regular or normal but then he just pulls it into this abstract world where we have very little context and have no choice other than to interpret it as strange there are loads of chimes on this track some very textured since swells and the way that he mixes these things it feels very panoramic and enveloping very much unlike in my opinion what was going on with centipede hurts and maybe tomboy to an extent where I felt like I was very much on the outside of the noise and the chaos on here I feel like I'm just sort of surrounded by it and welcomed back into it in the way that I was on some previous animal collective records or in certain surgeons overall to me this EP is decent its likable but I still kind of feel like I'm just getting a taste of what panda bear could potentially offer on this record especially with some of the abrupt endings of these tracks and aside for more fleshed out songs I hope that the vocals are a little bit more on point than they are on some of these songs here though maybe that might not be the case given that mr. Noah is one of the lead tracks from this forthcoming album maybe mr. hi everyone Anthony Fangio here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new run the jewels record run the jewels did run the jewels is a hip hop duo consisting of southern rapper killer Mike and new york-based rapper producer LP these guys have been one of the most unlikely and super hyped rap team ups of the past few years they started turning heads in 2012 with the entirely LP produced killer Mike album rap music which was highly praised by both fans and critics and LP n killer Mike seeing the success off of this record and basically the chemistry they themselves rivers we're seeing in their creative process decided to solidify this duo with the name run the jewels and they dropped a full-length record just about a year after this killer Mike album even though LP and might come from different walks of life they've had different artistic trajectories when it comes to run the jewels they really get on the same page artistically they kind of get together and meet at this middle ground where they can be straightforward blunt super aggressive brutal but also kind of cunning and clever too a little adventurous I think LP skips a little bit on the wordplay on the technical ability I think killer Mike drops a bit of his southern flavor from the equation too and this is all for the sake of coming together and doing something that is uniquely them still even though this first record of theirs really hit it off the question remains that can they continue this and hold people's attention can they keep it fresh can they keep it entertaining can they come up with some new ideas how far can this newly formed oooooo go are we going to get another black star or can we progress past this first album into something just as good Mike and Jamie certainly seem to hope that that's the case because it looks like they're marketing this album as a sequel to the first album Plus on top of it they're dropping this record just a year after they put out their debut record I guess really hitting while the iron's hot but still a lot of hardcore fans are going to have that debut album in their recent memory and they're going to hear this wasn't going to okay which is a completely fine reaction to have if you feel that way but in my personal opinion I think rtj 2 is better there are super brutal violent and aggressive rhymes all over this record cartoon alee aggressive sometimes hilariously aggressive sometimes as well but I think LP and killer Mike have stumbled upon a newfound just like serious darkness on this record - on some of these tracks I think LPS production on this record in comparison with the debut is way more layered detailed it's got more melody - on some of these tracks it's heavier it's busier it's punch here these beats are weighty and together with the lyrics these songs are about is blunt and straightforward and hard-hitting as like a wall of the coolest graffiti - tumbling over on top of you some of these songs feature numerous parts or have wonderful segues toward the end of them that bring you right into the next track without losing any momentum on the record like the track oh my darling into blockbuster night or all due respect into love again like with the last record Jamie and Mike bring just a handful of features but the features they do bring are super impressive Travis Barker of blink-182 hammering it out on drums on one track we also have Zack de la Rocha of raging as the Machine and gangsta boo of three 6 mafia they're not messing around and a few Underground's somewhat unknowns as well Diane Coffey who you might know as a member or a collaborator drummer for Fox again as well as boots a new york-based songwriter who on this record helped lay down one of the most beautiful choruses on any hip-hop album this year as I said earlier I think LP and killer Mike are finding their dark side on this record are finding a way to make slower more toned-down songs entertaining they do it right at the start of this record with the track jeopardy which is a really odd track for run the jewels they're lurking bass lines all over this thing just like eerie horror movies synthesizers and lead guitars some synth swells once the beat kicks in it's really heavy its lumbering and they're like some kooky saxophone leads all over this thing to LP and Mike bring these really slowly paced gritty grimy verses that really build up the the evil of this record like this song isn't the most evil that the album gets but you know that there's a larger evil coming down the pipe there are other tracks on here too that are equally toned down but a little darker just a little more depressing or even sad at times like the song all my life or even crown where killer Mike is delivering this eye widening lease adverse where he's rapping about dealing drugs to a pregnant woman regretfully however throughout the rest of this record run the jewels is the typically head bashing duo that you've come to know this is like some action movie with like LP and killer Mike running in slow motion with like trucks filled with gasoline exploding behind them and like Isis terrorists all around them like shooting at them with their fully automatic assault rifles but like every bullets missing like with the song Omar which has one of the most massive instrumentals on the entire LP really heavy sub bass simple snares coming through some watery swirling keys LP delivers some pimp sea references and some big references there's a hilarious line where he says that someone should run backwards through a field of dicks the instrumental gets noisier and more chaotic as it continues the song isn't exactly delivering any food for thought or anything like that but the lyrics and just the overall tone of the song is hilariously badass same with the song close your eyes and count to LP and killer Mike also deliver some brutal verses here and we have Zack de la Rocha of Rage Against the Machine like I mentioned earlier on this beat he is laced into the instrumental itself and it sounds amazing however his verse isn't totally mind-blowing or anything like that but I do think it's better than his appearance on the recent Deltron 3030 record we've got the song lie cheat steal which one of my favorite images on this entire record comes from this song teabagging a piranha tank or the song love again which has another incredibly hefty catchy beat and gangsta boo delivers a verse that is so raunchy that I blushed a little bit nearly every other track on here that isn't you know sort of sadder or more toned down song is it outright banger and I love that about this record but I also love the LP and killer Mike came together and and put forward a full length that is more balanced as well there are some darker tones on this LP and some of the most melodic hooks that LP and killer Mike have delivered yet especially on this track that features Diane Coffey to me this record is run the jewels sounding more distinct sounding more dynamic despite their incredibly aggressive attitudes I think they took some risks on this LP and the results are positive there are a few tracks here the pale in comparison to others but I don't really think there's anything incredibly negative that I have to say about this LP sometimes the more aggressive lyrics on this record can be a little cringe-worthy but that's the kind of tone and story that this album chooses to put forward it's unreasonably mean I mean look at the cover here it is a stick-up going on it doesn't want to hear your sob stories run the jewels man here and there I wish there were some beats that were just a little bit louder so the vocals were we're more immersed in them as opposed to just feeling like killer Mike and LP were just sort of on top of them with just kind of a lot of space between them and the beat some small technical things here and there pretty much but I'm still feeling a decent too strong eight on this thing transition if you've given this record a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana have a nice day music forever
