hi everyone who vanthu new Fang tanto here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new dope body record lifer these guys are a Baltimore rock band I believe they're on their fourth full-length album they came out with a cassette years ago on watercolor records back in 2011 they came out with their album nothing on Hoss records but in 2012 came their Drag City Records debut album natural history that year that year the album came out it was one of my favorite rock records of that year please give it a listen on this record not only did I love the band's songs but I fell in love with their sound and their style as well which incorporates elements of noise rock post-hardcore a little bit of metal irresistible grooves and bass lines even though dope bodies music is incredibly aggressive it's also incredibly funky - especially on songs such as powder and Road Dogg do what you've bought I do baby what you bought of it that not only is dope body on this record and in their music in general fantastic instrumentally but it is also the vocals that kind of makes the band stand out front man and Ruhlman's wild shouts and shrieks and caveman-like grunts really bring the energy level of dope bodies music up sigh so with dope bodies last record being a total powerhouse and the one prior to it growing on me slowly with each passing time I listened to it what is the band gonna do next well I think we got a little hint of that when they dropped a single last year for the song Saturday there was rougher production on these two songs just Wilder more chaotic performances but aside from that there weren't really any major defining characteristics about these two new songs except for maybe that they were less driven by the really weird and quirky grooves that were all over Natural History which is change in direction that kind of makes sense because I think the band did that sound all the justice they possibly could on Natural History to me Natural History is very much dope body finishing something that they started on nothing whereas lifer feels like the band is beginning something that is slightly newer for them because not only are there elements of noise rock and post-hardcore on this new album but there's also some psychedelic rock in here too some classic rock flavors as well post-punk and grunge which is pretty funny to think because on dope bodies record nothing there is a track titled the shape of grunge to come some tracks do have kind of a Nirvana or like early Soundgarden vibe to them so lifer is not as tightly wound or as funky as natural history but dope body finds different ways to experiment namely with very slow strung out guitars and verses vocals very loose playing and performances very chaotic they so while there are a lot of verses on this record that are kind of subdued it's the choruses that are really heavy and loud and brash abrasive and climactic some of them are loaded with psychedelic guitar solos some of them have really brittle distorted swells of guitar sound don't bodies mo on this record really seems to be that loud soft dynamic they're doing everything and anything they can do to create the greatest amount of contrast between Part A of the song and Part B whether that be a sonic contrast an emotional one a stylistic one the band may be totally just like off their rocker and out of control for one second but then they'll just tighten up and start just like a well-oiled machine punching through those riffs so that's kind of a structural change for dope body another change is their songs on this record that seemed to get more intense as they carry on you know really just escalating in a sort of linear fashion tracks like repo man as well as the 7-minute closing track here which I might add is loaded with sort of noisy glitchy synthesizers something I don't believe the band is done before an atom's vocal delivery has changed quite significantly on some of these songs too he's still a madman and and is willing to show that side on numerous tracks here but during these more toned down verses he is legitimately singing at first it may be kind of hard to swallow and with tracks like new sensation he kind of sounds like he's just sort of dicking around but I found it easier to get into most of the performances here after just a handful of listens to these songs namely on tracks like echo it's on songs like this where Adams very pained moans and whimpers where he's just kind of like wandering around aimlessly it reminds me a lot of Honus Honus from Mann Mann if you've heard that band not only that but this track also features some very slow spacious kind of backwoods guitars that maybe have a bit of a southern rock vibe to them but as soon as the chorus kicks in the song just Rockets off into these spiraling guitar chords that send the song spinning at a thousand rpm so while there are some great tracks on here that create that fantastic contrast between some parts of a song and other parts of the song there are also tracks here that just straight up rock in the way that you would expect a dope body song to rock like the track toy which is maybe as punk as it gets on this record complete with lyrics about wanting to be original and not wanting to be a wannabe also the songs rare air and day by day tracks that have very very very abrasive lively choruses but the verses have these kind of watery milky bass lines that sound like they would be very comfortable inside of like a Joy Division song or like a Bauhaus song even as on the song day by day Adam is delivering vocals that feel like they could be placed onto a Fugazi record the the Ian MacKaye side of a Fugazi record then there's the song hired gun which features one of the most badass heavy noisy guitar riffs of any dope body song yet and for whatever reason the melody that this riff plays is just eerily similar to that of the vocal line on the roll Stonestreet fightin man throughout this record there are loads of subtle references to numerous rock disciplines and they are executed really well without watering down dope bodies trademark personality and just exuberant energy simply put I think this is just another great record from dope body I wish the production on here was just a little bit cleaner because I think the production quality on Natural History was was very very ideal but still despite that very small issue this is a very wild it's a brash rock record with personality with viscera with guts with explosivity with songs that have numerous parts to them lots of changes lots of shifts the band shows that they can write they can perform they could play a loose they could play a tight and they can switch from one to the other at the drop of a hat I'm feeling a decent two strong eight on this record Tran know the best position and if you've given this record to listen what did you think did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantino a'dope Abadi forever

ah hi everyone whoo theny clan tanto here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Vince staples EP hell can wait Vince staples is a West Coast rapper much of who's come up has occurred underneath the odd future Wolf Gang kill them all umbrella he has also collaborated with the likes of Mac Miller he's had some semi successful solo mixtapes some pretty great features out recently as well on the new dilated peoples record on the new earl record when i hear this guy turn up on someone else's track typically i end up liking it but when it comes to Vince solo I'm a little underwhelmed Vince's typically relaxed flow works at two speeds laid-back and lay it back also if you give this guy's rapping a listen you should pick up pretty easily a very old-school Snoop Dogg type inflection now I'm not saying his lyrics or his style are trash but he is not exactly the lyricist of the year either sometimes his instrumental choices have been a little shoddy to me and he's not exactly a song or hook writer in my opinion either sometimes his his courses can really be duds so in my opinion Vince staples can be a little boring for long strings of time but he has a commercial full length on the way he is kind of teasing toward that with this new commercial EP I figure I like his style enough to be curious about this project and it's not a full-length and the EP naturally is going to be shorter plus I did like one of the lead singles off of this EP blue suede we essentially have seven new songs on this project and while not in love with it I do think this is Vince's most consistently quality set of tracks yet but there is a little bit of a range on this thing we have great moments like 6500 which has one of the most killer hooks on the entire record even though it is simple in Vince's courses do tend to be simple it's very very sticky the birds and the bees come with a G Plus this track does have one of the better instrumentals on the entire record - very jazzy horns strings that are very mournful and we be playing underneath the verses some chopped up piano samples as well and over the beat Vince sounds fantastic he's putting a little bit more emotional inflection in his voice at times to me sounding a little bit like andre 3000 and even though we do get a lot of typical gangsta rap themes and Vince's lyrics on this track and other tracks here I think he does a good job of conjuring the hopelessness that comes out of such dire situations as the ones he is rapping about then there's blue suede stellar instrumental the trap high hats the massive bass on this thing the groove of it I as much as I love this beat it's also a little bit of a double-edged sword too because I feel like this song and 65-hundred do sort of highlight the fact that Vince though he is capable rapper he is a little instrumental dependent to continue with this track I do love the surreal imagery in the song the death fixated imagery in the song sort of seeing your friends passing on and hoping that you're going to outlive the red roses that may be at their either their tribute shrine somewhere wherever they had died or on their grave at their funeral I also love the ear you wailing synthesizer leads on this track - it's like a weird dark fusion of southern hip hop and West Coast but even though tracks like screen-door are a little more thematic uh it's it's hard getting into this track just because of how mundane it is as a song the instrumental doesn't show that much variation it's very skeletal very minimalist and vince staples doesn't really change up his flow or his inflection or his energy level that much across the length of the track either and this is a 4-minute song and it feels so much longer because of the the lack of significant change I feel the same way with the song hands up - whoo - I wish this song wasn't as subdued as it is but it is an interesting track lyrically that addresses police violence police corruption cops gunning young kids down and even though Vince doesn't name this location by name a lot of people because of recent events are going to link this track directly with Ferguson but stories like these are happening all over America I think is why it was smart to do sort of a more general thing on this track instrumentally it should also be noted that Vince is kind of doing a nocturnal DJ mustard flavored funk and the instrumentals pretty fitting while I do think the hands up don't shoot and the put your hands in the air as you would typically hear in a hip-hop song parallel is very clever there are some moments on here like the opener which do hit hard instrumentally but lyrically and flow wise is just kind of okay and occasionally Vince shows sort of a softer side of himself like on the song limos not every song needs to be as brutal as the closing track here which does have a line that grips me even now where he says he's going to put the burner in your mouth and free your mind but I still think Vince is on a journey to find his real standout voice while he can rap he sounds fine on a beat I think he still got a little bit of progress to make when it comes to compelling songwriting and finding a narrative and an angle that will separate him from all the other rappers out there that are rapping about similar topics I'm feeling a light at ease on this thing transition if you've given the sepia listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana Vince stop 'less yeah forever

hi everyone Rick theny Grimes tanno here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new Scott Walker and some record soused soused is the completely unexpected collaborative album from experimental music figureheads Scott Walker and son both of whom come from different musical backgrounds both of whom come from different musical worlds though they are very dark in experimental worlds however their respective pasts have very little in common Walker has been the passionate and bellowing voice behind many fantastic baroque pop records decades ago and Greg Anderson and Steven O'Malley of son their background ranges from metal to hardcore punk however both of them are making incredibly strange music now currently and for years son has been a major figurehead in the doom drone metal world sort of taking the heavy vast somewhat ambient archetypes set out by bands like Earth on the record earth - but taking it so much further into the dark ambient realm into the noise realm into the black metal realm and Scott Walker went off of the artistic deep end in the 90s with the record tilt then he went on to put out the drift and most recently bish Bosh a record where Scott's very strange and deep kroons are delivered over some of the strangest instrumentals he's dealt with yet some of the instrumentals here are very minimal and sparse and eerie others are incredibly cacophonous and busy and disorienting dissonant harsh frantic and intense and as far as the lyrics on bish posh co they're absolutely absurd absurdism to the highest degree without a doubt there are plenty of dark and disturbing moments on this record sonically and verbally as well but there are some tongue-in-cheek spots - some people have tried to boil this record down - Scott simply messing about and maybe that is what he's doing to a degree but if you think about what messin about kind of entails No Boundaries No rulz no inhibitions and Scott took advantage of that lack of boundaries in a way that I think no artist ever could or ever will even though bish Bosch is not a welcoming record it's not an incredibly rewarding record it is awe-inspiring Lee twisted and bizarre and even though son makes music in a completely different genre I would say those labels also apply to some of their best records to which personally is enough common ground for me because once I heard this collaboration announced I had no reason not to be excited in my head I sort of visualized like another black one where son bring on Scott Walker and sort of have him mucked into their typically heavy and dissonant and thick instrumentals with just Scott going absolutely insane or maybe even son drifting away from the drones and trying to come up with instrumentation that would complement Scott in a way that the instrumentation on bish Bosh did but with sort of a different tone or style in my head no way could this record be as underwhelming as the recent over collaboration because it's just it's just too unforeseen and it's not like son and Scott Walker had so little common ground that this thing could be as disastrous as like lulu socially speaking anyway because i like some tracks off of Lulu so even though I went into this record with nothing but just positive vibes and a good outlook and just somewhat high expectations I came out just like a sort of underwhelmed maybe that was bound to happen just because of how high of a regard I hold these two artists in first I guess I'll start with something that is very obvious from the sound of the record and was kind of confirmed for me in the way this album has been billed and marketed for one this LP comes out on Scott Walker's label currently for a D and Scott Walker does get first billing if son is playing second fiddle on this record it certainly sounds like it occasionally there are some ear piercing guitar leads here and there who knows if that is coming from Stephen or Greg really where son's presence is felt are in the occasional appear PSA's of thick heavy droney walls of guitar sound sons mo essentially the sad thing is these thick walls of guitar don't actually enhance Scott Walker's schtick which doesn't really change that significantly on this new record in my opinion these walls of droning guitar sound kind of tame when compared to son's best material which leads me to the question that if Scott Walker is running the show here essentially why isn't this weirder I did not love head over heels bish Bosh at the time that I reviewed it at the time it came out it has grown on me a little little since then but the appeal for me in this record is that it is a musical freak show and while freak shows are great their appeal does run a little one-dimensional not to say that there aren't interesting lyrics or emotions or musical compositions on this record there most definitely are but more often than not they work to enhance this record sense of shock value and when so much of what you're doing banks on oddity you've always got to work to advance beyond what you did in the past or else it's just going to feel less shocking it's going to be less gripping and I just can't help but feel as I'm listening to these mere five songs that Scott Walker could have just done these songs on his own outside of Suns guitars instrumentally these tracks just feel like another round of bish Bosch style strangeness but not as strong not as disorienting not as extreme because certainly when the droning guitar sort of introduced themselves the compositional side of these tracks sort of end up stagnating and not really going anywhere that significant though I do think there are exceptions such as the song fetish which most definitely has one of the most interesting progressions of any track on this album not only that but sun's input on this record feel so much less obvious than it does on many other songs here and the track lullaby though repetitive does stay consistently twisted and engaging especially as the horror-movie synthesizers and scott's upper register come together for some pretty interesting climaxes meanwhile the tracks off of bish Bosch thrived on change and unpredictability I can't help but feel like I'm just listening to lesser versions of what I just heard Scott Walker do there are some moments in this record that stand out like the chorus vocals on lullaby when Scott is singing out just very ear lead very creepily the glistening sensor guitars right at the start of the opening track here one moment in particular where Scott is sort of throwing these very primal drums behind Suns droning guitars it actually comes together pretty well and has a bit of an industrial vibe on here and no track on this record is outright awful except maybe for the the second one which does border on just being dreadfully boring at points but outside of that there's not really that much appeal for me on this record it doesn't feel like Scott is pushing himself artistically in the way that he was on his last record and son a lot of the time just kind of feels like background dressing this collaboration is more exciting in name than it is in execution I'm feeling a strong five to a light six on this record unfortunately transition if you've given this album a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it forever also down there in the description box I will drop a link to a review of the new royal blood album you can watch it down there at that link a week before it actually shows up on this channel over here cool cool you're the best you're the best you're the best

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Sir Michael rocks record Bank oh this is the latest full-length project from California via Illinois rapper Sir Michael rocks a guy who was mostly known for his affiliation with the rap duo the cool kids which if you don't remember also features the input of rapper producer Chuck Inglish and when the cool kids hit the internet and blew up they got pretty big they were one of the first hipster hop sensations before - racist before ASAP mob before Death Grips and Danny Brown and Odd Future and all that I was loving tracks like pennies and a v8 and I rock and black mags pretty much most of that bake sale EP if you loved 80s hip hop and really phat beats and simple flows clever rhymes a good sense of humor then the cool kids are worth checking out their lyrics weren't overly complex or deep or anything like that but they knew how to write really instantaneous fun creative hip hop music that had a seriously fresh edge to it and maybe that bake sale EP maybe some of those singles haven't held up too well in recent years but I feel like the reason for that is is that once the cool kids drop that EP they really needed an album to seal the deal and solidify the fandom they had built up so far and when they dropped the full-length LP that really came too late after the bake sale EP it was kind of a fumble and as a duo ever since the release of this album the cool kids have remained relatively silent and the solo material they've been dropping since their slow fade to black has begun has been pretty mediocre - if I'm going to be honest and going into it I thought banco is going to be another instance of the cool kids running on creative fumes ever since the release of the bake sale P and maybe there are some people out there given my reputation who would think I would say the same thing because even here on Twitter we have my Crocs telling me not to review this I'm so picky I just cannot be pleased well I'm happy to say that even though banco is is not a perfect album i did think it was a fun and enjoyable album the mic is roughly at the same level of lyrical ability that he was when the cool kids were at their most popular and he pretty much grabs a bunch of rappers who were around that level as well other than Twista his feature is fantastic and he kills Mikey on the beat but still I have to commend Mike on this recapturing the simple fun silly attitude that made the cool kids so irresistible when they first hit on banco we have some really infectious pop rap with some kind of eccentric playful beats the intro song on here is one of the few that actually takes a serious tone we get a bit of backstory from Mike talking his transition to California sort of suffering the death of a loved one in the process he raps a bit about his current state in music depression there are a lot of brags weaved into these lines but some kind of surreal psychedelic and unsettling imagery to this track is kind of like a bad trip which is a little misleading because the rest of the record is pretty light-hearted because a mood change comes really quickly right on the next song with memo there's a punchy beat on this track a wonky melody some synthesizer chords that kind of sound like a a phaser baby accordion and the hook on this thing I'm ballin did you miss the memo it's enthusiastic it's funny lyrically there's a lot of typical rap here but it sounds like a party we're all invited to then there's the song some issue with some weeping guitars and the beat the groove is very punchy on this thing I'm loving the tremolo synth chords and there's also the twist to feature on here which is great and topically this song is kind of about a meeting of bisexual lover again not a very deep track but a very fun track all the same if you loved some hip-hop that is doused and sexual fantasy then give a listen then there's a song busing maybe one of my favorite tracks off the cell P Casey Veggies I am soo hoping pronouncing that correctly also on this track it was one of the first songs I enjoyed from this thing there's a beautiful icy synth melody on this track kind of a non-sequitur hook what's most enjoyable about this song is that not only is it just kind of an ear worm but it's just filled with in Kading young boy swagger and these sort of underground hits just kind of keep coming with tracks like drug dealer where Mike's kind of just paying homage paying tribute to the drug dealer but kind of like in an older 90 cents as he paints a portrait of this guy that has numerous cell phones and beepers then there's the song kill switch with rob banks and puia another pretty good track and the beat has this awesome bottle rocket sample that makes the song so noisy and ear grabbing the song Lost Boys is well sort of a weird lo-fi country rap hybrid with Trinidad James and Mac Miller both of whose verses are pretty decent they measure up there's all sorts of slide guitar in this beat and for verse after verse after verse the The Lost Boys theme kind of works the main tracks on this record for the first three fourths of the project are all pretty great it's just that they're interrupted by these experimental songs by these skits some of which are good and funny like the song cold sore the Pokemon reference on that skit kills me but then there's the skit Doc's or the Dino feeding skit the song PlayStation 1.5 is kind of underwhelming as is the song SeaWorld though I do think the very close of that song is humorous I think the absurdism and the playful attitude of some of the songs on here that I love also leads to some underwhelming tracks as well and that's all these skits and these weird or tracks still do add character one of the only songs on here I think I strongly stand in opposition to is maybe one time which to me is just a half-assed song through and through one time wintertime summertime at a time then there's the song new with two short and Chuck Inglish the beat on this track just screams DJ mustard it's just kind of a trendy throwaway then the song Francois not a bad track as well but not exactly a winning closer either maybe something that was a little bit more personal or meaningful like the intro track to kind of bookend the whole thing and just kind of make it feel like an experience would have been more fitting but whatever overall it's not a bad P I will say this again but it is fun it's catchy it's not that heady if you're looking for something that's a little lighter on its meaning and is just trying to make you laugh and is trying to get a hook stuck in your head but isn't as dumbed down isn't as overly simplistic as some of the hip-hop you might hear on the radio then give this thing a listen I do think this record is it's smarter than it lets off it may be braggadocious it may be materialistic but it's kind of ridiculous as well and I mean that in a totally good complementary positive way I'm feeling a strong six to eight seven on this thing transition if you given this record of listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana Benko forever

uh hi everyone loud and angry and nihilistic tanno here the it's Anthony Fantana the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new god flesh record world bonfire deadly kill everyone this is the sinisterly titled and latest full-length album from birmingham industrial rock and industrial metal outfit God flesh starring among others experimental music workhorse Justin K Broderick these others being people like GC grain and a rotating cast of collaborators over the years though right now in God fleshes current form it is just Justin and GC now Justin has the bragging rights of getting in on the ground floor of some pretty awesome genres throughout the 80s and the 90s with bands like napalm death ice curse the golden vampire Yaesu who I've had the pleasure of seeing once as well as techno animal but in the late 80s along with bands like pitch shifter and ministry and lard and maybe to a lesser extent Nine Inch Nails if you'll let me through a popular name in there God flesh would go on to set the foundation for industrial style metal music going on to influence groups such as beer factory or strapping young lad and when I say industrial metal I mean metal music that might potentially have electronic drums hanging in the background really heavy thick distorted bone crushing riffs so God flesh they formed in the 80s they broke up in the 2000s and no record in their discography is more celebrated in their full-length debut album street cleaner and it's not hard to figure out why even on first listen because of just how massive this record sounds even today especially the remastered version even at 25 years old this album sounds like an apocalyptic aggressive beatdown that will not let up the band would go on to experiment with more fluid riffs and melody and harmony and an overall smoother sound on the album selfless there actually were some riffs and grooves on this record that would go on to influence the nu-metal movement in the 2000s and that vibe is even stronger on the band's next record in 96 songs of love and hate not only does this LP forego a lot of the boomy electronic drums that we remember from past records but there's more live drumming in the mix instead and with tracks like hunter to me this song is just totally totally 2000 zerrin new metal but without the pop accessibility on records like us and then got flesh indulged in not only incorporating hip hop rhythms into their songs but drum and bass - and what was at one time the band's swan song hymns is a fantastic record where they started bringing some atmospheric sludge metal sounds into the fold actually featured a kind of Spacey and harmonious closing track that sort of led way to the whole yaesu project that justin dove into directly after the demise of God flesh this record is easily one of the best goodbyes in underground extreme rock music so do give it a listen if you get a chance but now God flesh is back after 13 years new record which I guess is a nice change of pace given that all of the reasons stuff yaesu has been putting out I've been pretty underwhelmed by and the band is not really taking off from where they left in the early 2000s on this record this thing is more like our hit of the reset button this thing is like a record that could come out right after street cleaner there's a track on here Imperator I believe it's called that features some clean vocals though this track is a little bit of a bore the vocals are sort of buried thrown into the background the last songs a little long-winded kind of slow and atmospheric there's one beat on here that feels like it might have a little bit of a hip-hop influence but for the most part these songs are completely devoid of all the experimentation got flesh did from like 1990 to 2001 which is funny given that these guys are one of the group's early on that experimented putting industrial music and hip hop together and now that noise infused hip hop music is kind of catching on it's sort of like nowhere to be seen here I guess you should listen to this album if you want to hear God flesh go back and just redo the sound the concept and the idea of their earliest material essentially what the wider community music community celebrates them for street cleaner this MO could not be more apparent right even from the start of this record where the guitars are massively thick compressed heavy Justin's typically deep guttural barked vocals are very crisp they're very clear they're upfront they're in your face I think the only thing this song really misses from the whole God flesh aesthetic are the drums they're so quiet they're so buried where the snares that sound like a shotgun going off in an airplane hangar occasionally they come up on tracks like life-giver life-taker but I was just hoping for them to be a little bit more prevalent still there are some really good grooves coming out of these sort of stiff and electronic drums a lot of the time like the rolling double bass kicks on the song dead end or the drum groove and the guitar riff on the track shut me down which is maybe one of the most nasty head-banging irresistible riffs on the whole record God flesh guitar wise at least and and riff wise too are sounding just as earth as ever there are quite a few tracks on this record that could really go toe to toe with street cleaner in terms of dissonance and aggression and just bleakness and nihilism however there are quite a few songs on this record too that sound kind of inconspicuous for God flesh like with the opening track or life-giver life-taker again these songs to me why loud are not really punishing enough which really is what street cleaner is as an experience a punishment and with so many songs on this record just sounding really heavy and slow as hell for the duration of the track time it kind of keeps these songs from feeling dynamic Justin definitely makes the effort on this record but sometimes the choruses the hook the bridges of these songs don't really contrast one another enough to warrant any excitement or emotional peaks the last third of this record though in my opinion really seems to pull things together delivers one head bashing riff after another and the closing track like I mentioned earlier is a multi-faceted longer song with some interesting sound scapes in there really sort of bringing that atmospheric sludge metal thing into the fold this record is just another example of a group who put out some of their best stuff in the late 80s the 90s sort of coming back out of the blue and just putting out new material again and that's totally cool that's totally fine I mean you know FX is doing it my bloody Valentines doing it way more people that I haven't even mentioned right now are doing it and some of these artists thus far when dropping new material have stuck pretty passionately to what we remember them for some of them have ventured out and experimented in this case with God flesh they're just really kind of sticking at home base and doing what is comfortable for them which is a little disappointing given that the band experimented throughout their career and maybe it would have been interesting to hear a record that was kind of a culmination of the many things that the band tried throughout their career I think it was easier to kind of make a record like this because in retrospect the music community has deemed the band's early stuff cool whereas their drum and bass and hip-hop influenced stuff that would go on to sort of set the tone for new metal throughout the 2000s not quite as cool so I like a lot of the tracks on this record I don't think there's a horrible song here and I think God flesh came through with good production there are some pretty nasty lyrics on this LP as well at least from what I can make out from the lyrics my only big glaring issue with this record is that I guess the whole idea and concept was a little obvious but that's it I'm feeling a strong six to a light seven on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana music music me like forever

ah hi everyone Anton Fantin here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new Weezer album everything will be all right in the end famed alternative rock and power pop band Weezer on their ninth full-length album here Wow their first album came out in 1994 it's on my favorite pop rock albums of all time it's essentially been 20 years since the release of that record amazing singles on this album clever sort of fun humorous nerd friendly Tunes but as great as this album was to me in the grander scheme of things it doesn't really feel like anything more in the career of Weezer than just a moment in time because now with the band being as old as they are there's a lot of history Weezer hit an artistic and a commercial stride with the Blue Album with Pinkerton but then more radio-friendly songs began to come down the pipe with albums like the green album but the grown worthy material didn't really dropping until records like maple leaf or the red album or attitude where we were getting singles like Beverly Hills and we're all on drugs songs that are so far outside the rubric of why you originally loved the band it's kind of hard not to at least feel just a little bit of a sense of betrayal and when fans feel that way it's a little hard to kind of win them back it's like you've almost soured the relationship plus I think a lot of fans were anticipating that Weezer would kind of aged and mature along with them as they grew up but instead Weezer decided to kind of stay in this musical Neverland where they would essentially stay sixteen years old musically and lyrically for the rest of time so despite this lack of progression and maybe even a tiny embrace of regression on a few records I actually did end up enjoying Weezer's last album quite a bit early for me this record was relatively low on BS it just had a lot of good catchy straightforward pop rock songs and the typical Weezer style but another thing this album signaled to me is that Ouiser is going to pander less to the radio rock market because we've got the internet now where everything has a niche and maybe if we're lucky will we not only get some better songs from Weezer but maybe even just a little bit of acknowledgment of the years of disappointment felt by people whose adolescence was defined by songs like El Scorcho and the sweater song as well as Buddy Holly and Weezer actually does that here they make the effort they do it to the best of their abilities I will not go as far as to say Weezer has matured on this record but they have put out their most ambitious album in a while here and in addition to that this is their most self-aware record in well over a decade musically Weezer is putting together songs in typical Weezer fashion with that same guitar tone super heavy super thick the mid-paced riffs rivers Cuomo's vocals still have a somewhat whiny tone to them but still very enjoyable the bass is basically there just to thicken things up the drums are nice with Weezer it's not really the magic of any individual part really it's more about how all the instrumentation comes together to complement the song and there are some songwriting triumphs on this record like eulogy for a rock band a song that embraces a theme on this record that rock and Weezer are both kind of past their prime maybe pass their peak of relevancy and if that is in fact the case then this song is a very punchy fun catchy and kind of a tear-jerking goodbye super melodic chorus way catchy lyrics on the chorus as well and poetically I think it kind of puts the rock band to bed quite nicely and I love the song had it up to here which starts off with this really funky guitar riff it's got a great groove but then when the verse comes in I think the theme of this song really hits home with river singing that I'm trying to give you my best artistically I'm trying to give you my best material but you've essentially plugged up your ears at this point which for a lot of Weezer fans is totally 100% true and you know the the frustration rivers is is very mutual but not on this I love how lyrically he's diving into a lot of the critiques that people have thrown a tweezer over the years and maybe he's acknowledging them a little bit the lack of edge the mediocrity the homogeneous Asian he's saying what a lot of people have been saying and he puts it into a very nicely packaged song but is he only saying what sort of maybe longtime Weezer fans or X Weezer fans have been wanting to hear because it's not like this album isn't without its mediocre moments you have lonely girl like you you were just singing about mediocrity and then you put out this song lonely girl which maybe has some of the most insipid lyrics of any Weezer song not just that but the song is just way too cliche to handle and even further on the cliche scale is the male/female duet on the song go away again you were just singing about mediocrity and you're doing a song here that sounds like a really terrible chien hem tune we have a lead single from this LP back to the shack which instrumentally is a pretty catchy tune but lyrically I'm not really sure I'm that into the concept we have river singing about hey you know let's get out of this crappy singing show stuff and instead get back to what we do best and what we're familiar with them when we know is great and what we know the fans want get back to the shack do the writing do the rocking just be Weezer and in this song lyrically we have river singing about going hardcore like it's 94 when in fact this song does not sound like 94 Weezer it sounds like 2001 Weezer anybody who's a Weezer fan knows that and while in concept I do agree with the the jabot stupid singing shows the alternative that Weezer is bringing to the table here is really only like a lesser of two evils it's not like oh my god this is what I should be doing instead and the opening track on here to over 20 years as a band and Weezer is still singing about that feel when no girlfriend not just that but this song is also an example of how atrocious the production can get on this record the song kicks off with this overly loud bass e and compressed guitar riff that is just so boom and so crushing like what are you trying to prove you don't got to go super heavy just to impress us and besides when the guitars get this loud which they do occasionally you can't even really make out the vocals that well so yeah the the years of musical abuse I have had my heart turned a little cold when it comes to Weezer however there are still moments on this record where they get to me like on the song the British are coming which is a little overly simplified as far as the history behind the song but it's still a little fun left hook patriotism pop rock tune which I didn't see coming then there's the song da Vinci which I think has one of Weezer's best hooks in years on it and I like the lyrical concept of this song saying that this person that maybe a love interest is very hard to describe their abstract they're different they just have no precedent they're hard to put into words saying that not even da Vinci could paint this person not even Stephen Hawking could explain this person we've got Cleopatra which to me sticks out as a unique tune just because of how oddly shaped and grooved the lead melody is on the chorus really weird hook it feels almost as if like the drums and the guitars bust in maybe like a beat early and it's a bit of a surprise like on the British are coming we also have a bit of a nod to history on this song but the concept of this track really lies in aging and just growing older and growing colder emotionally which maybe runs parallel to the whole Weezer rock fan dynamic going on right now that's mentioned on a few tracks here there's the song foolish father where we kind of see rivers very well-documented daddy issues kind of playing out into a sequel song here where maybe he's reflecting a little bit on the fact that he is a father now and has to kind of work through these difficulties at a different angle and once again the song is incredibly catchy straightforward sweet that classic Weezer formula at work once again in this track like many other songs on here work through the themes set out by the title of this album that I guess everything will work out when it's all over and the record itself definitely does that it resolves really well with this trio of songs that are filled with soaring guitar harmonies it's a really grand epic and ambitious finish for this record for Weezer in general maybe some of you might be thinking this trio of tracks was trying a little too hard but I personally like the fact that Weezer seems to be trying at all it really feels like they're putting an effort into these songs and again while this record may not exactly be mature Weezer at least tries to build a bridge to a lot of their older fans saying hey listen we hear you and we know the issue and we know the problem and essentially we're just like a little sorry for it and it's it's nice to hear that but only sometimes does it feel like Weezer is actually working to fix these issues and as a result as much as I like a lot of the tracks here it's sort of hard to be totally gung-ho about this record because of the disappointing moments I'm peeling a strong six to a light seven on this thing transition though I guess I did totally end up digging a lot of this record yeah you know it's it's a likable album it's a good album I just uh you know it's it's it's just uh it's just hard not to at least be just a touch disappointed because of just how high the high-water marks were at least for me anyway earlier on in Weezer's career but that's it you know it feels like a throwback album a little bit but again it's very much a throwback to like the early 2000s Weezer not the 90s Weezer cool cool have you given this album we'll listen if you have what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and um and that's it Anthony Fantana Weezer forever

hi everyone - any dead tail here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Flying Lotus record your dead Flying Lotus is a West Coast music producer known for his incredibly forward-thinking fusion of jazz electronic music hip hop he is also a label head over at brain feeder records many people consider him to have dropped albums that are modern classics like Los Angeles and cosma grandma and on his fifth album here he is following up what I consider to be one of the more underwhelming records in his discography until the quiet comes a record where I think stylistically he was treading a little bit of water some songs on this album sounded like they could have come off of his pattern grid world EP but this album also features some of his most just subtle and toned down material yet it just kind of fell into the background for me whenever I would play it which is kind of an issue I have with many brain feeder records releases so I walked away from this project looking forward to flylo's next project hoping for something a little more lively a little more refreshing and with your dead I got that one of the most notable changes right from the get-go on this album is that there are more vocal features on this LP some honest-to-god rap verses from Kendrick Lamar and Snoop Dogg angel dear Dorian of Dirty Projectors Fame lands on this record Nicki Randa who is a prior collaborator with Flying Lotus and Thundercat as well who is not only on this album vocally but basically as well I'm sure and as if we didn't see this coming Flying Lotus also appears on this record vocally as his low-pitched alter-ego captain Murphy who many of you may remember from his once anonymous solo effort not too long ago something else to note with this record is that it's 38 minutes one of the shorter albums and flylo's discography thus far but I also think you are dead is one of flylo's most upbeat and active albums as well I think this record has the jazzy density of Kozma grandma without all the meandering and the and the atmosphere the music that occurs on this record very tangible it's very bold it's very forceful this record twists and turns and tumbles and flips like a gymnast but an issue that I think some people may have with this album is that some of the tracks some of the musical passages are rather short they're kind of brief they build up to a moment or they create an idea but as soon as that idea is established it's not really fleshed out as much as it is just transformed into something else there are a lot of one-minute tracks on this record and in that regard this album can be compared to something like J Dilla's doughnuts or even a mad lib instrumental album but I think a lot of the pieces of this sonic ear candy though it may be short effectively builds off of one another enhances one another some of the short but amazing musical experiences that these little tracks bring and are incredible right from the start of this record the intro where we're getting these heavy orchestral strings just this dense instrumentation it's so huge it's so massive I just really feel it and even though the song ends in about a minute 24 it glides quite perfectly into the next track which introduces some great bass lines so the killer drums some good keys and this jazz fusion feel gets just turned up the heat gets turned up on the next song cold dead which is just some explosive jazz rock some distorted riffs on this track mixed with these atmospheric musical passages of saxophone and keyboards this album really is flying lotuses bitches brew or even his music is one note coming up not too soon after this track is never catch me with Kendrick Lamar I did a track review for this song I will link it at the end of this video you can watch it there I'm not going to dive too much deeper into my thoughts on this track here but in that track review I thought this track while good not amazing but good would sound better in the context of this album and in fact that happens when this song comes on it's like a fog or a smoke clears or some significant occurrence occurs it's like Cinderella and you're watching this woman in a beautiful gown just come down the stairway ready to have fun at the ball it's not like you're just one tiny unfinished song after another with your dead if you just completely ignore the tracklisting and don't look at the tracklisting while you're listening to this album the entire record sounds like one holistic piece it may jump around a little bit but it features some interesting and nicely crafted segues this is a sensation I also get from until the quiet comes but it feels so much stronger on your dead this album is easily flying lotuses most holistic project yet and even though I love that about this record and I think this is a fantastic record it's not without its underwhelming moments which come here and there it's a handful attracts namely dead man's Tetris with Snoop Dogg his verse his guest verse is kind of underwhelming it's not really anything to write home about Plus for whatever reason this instrumental is far more modulated especially toward the end than any other beat on this record kind of ruins the flavor of the track for me anyway but it's not like this record ever hits a lull anywhere every time I find a track that it's just okay the album picks right back up with a great song it does so right here with Turkey dog coma which features some incredible drumming and there is great drumming all over this record some great rhythms all over this record but here particularly the rhythms are intense moving from there we have the lovely and amazing vocal interlude cornice the Terminator really chilling in heavenly song I love the group vocals on this track they're absolutely stunning Flying Lotus is doing a better and better job with each record just honing and crafting and finding gorgeous sounds Flying Lotus continues to weave this really cohesive musical tapestry tapestry with the song Turtles which features some great hand percussion some blissful female vocals some ascending and descending bass lines ready or not which kind of feels like a little introspective bit of mid-90s IDM with a really quirky drum loop that you know only Flying Lotus would use descent into madness with Thundercat is fantastic melodically and chord wise as well to me this kind of feels like an interlude that would land on like a King Crimson album and Thundercats typically falsetto Vogel are very nice on this track then immediately after we get another vocal appearance from captain Murphy or Flying Lotus himself and he is singing here in falsetto as well it's like a bit of Warped soul music from the 70s or the 80s it's kind of funky but kind of slow and strange as well and he's singing about pills and just generally being unhappy to me the song kind of feels like what Tyler the Creator wishes some of his songs sounded like and this song is a serious risk it's like the weirdest track on the entire LP but my one disappointment with it is not that the experiment fails but Flying Lotus just fades it out which is just oh he was doing so well making one track segue to another why would you just flush this one down the toilet if you're gonna do something this weird stick with it finish it the second last track on this LP is it is incredibly orchestral just like the intro it kind of glides into a an anticlimactic closer but I still ended up loving this LP it was a serious journey it was colorful and varied and dynamic had a lot of personality each song had its own little unique direction and flavor and yet it just came together so well I'm giving this record a strong 8 to a light 9 I'm loving it I'm feeling it transition if you give in this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana Flying Lotus forever

hi everyone 3:30 a.m. taro in the morning shooting this right now here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Ice Age record plowing into the field of love you think it's the same field in here same field maybe ice age is a Danish post-punk and noise rock band that has an incredibly dark and dismal sound they flirt a little bit with goth rock - thus far they have dropped - incredibly abrasive crushing and depressing albums albums that feature very chaotic production and instrumentation very drain and frustrated vocals from frontman Elias bender Ronon felt their sophomore LP is the more dynamic of the two albums and their very short discography I love the aggressive tracks on this record but I came away impressed the most by songs like morals a very sad yet energetic very charged and dreary piano ballad infused with Ice Ages typically noisy guitars and drums in a lot of ways the song was just ice age as usual but with way more finesse plus the promise the idea of there being more instrumental accompaniment into the future was pretty exciting it is something that I in fact hoped for I guess maybe even a little bit predicted on their latest LP right here their third full-length album plowing into the field of love instrumentally Ice Age went all out you've got their usual just very heavy chaotic pummeling punishing drums and guitars and vocals but that is now enhanced by acoustic guitars and pianos and horns and strings there are more melodies woven into these songs as well in general and the chord progressions that Ice Age tends to favor on this record feel a little more harmonious even if that harmony may be a bit of a minor one or a sour one and even though I say just showing more finesse on this record whether it be in the way that they're writing these songs because they are so delivering longer songs on this record that you routinely hit the four five minute mark the entire album is longer than any record they've ever put out thus far reaching almost 50 minutes in length considering their last two records were under 30 minutes each it's a pretty big jump but I say just showing a lot of finesse as well in the way the instrumentation comes together on this record - ice age most definitely showing a gentler side on this record a more subtle side a more detailed side they are writing more complex beautiful songs however they still manage to maintain a very gruff outward appearance they still manage to write and deliver just oppressively cacophonous songs Joy Division and Bauhaus still seem to be primary influences in Ice Ages music but on this new record something I mentioned on my track review for their song forever there is a huge Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds vibe going on with this LP which to me is a musical world that is not untapped in today's modern music market but I think under tapped similar to that of some of the Bad Seeds best stuff in the 80s and 90s Ice Age hit a balance of beauty and ugly but even though this influence may seem pretty apparent at least to me I still think Ice Age has remained its own animal even though they have brought more instrumentation into the fold and the drums and the guitars they may be particularly noisy and chaotic I think ice ages production style has stayed roughly the same as it was on their previous LP and the vocals on Ice Ages record have have mostly stayed the same as well though they have become more dynamic and I think Elias has done a better job of just sort of exploring melody and exploring different I guess inflections and stuff like that all I'm trying to say is that he's not really frightening or commanding in the same way that Nick Cave is rather he maintains a lot of the same emotional characteristics that we know him for on previous records the frustration just the despair his singing is just the epitome of emotional turmoil when he sings it sounds like he is struggle just crawling his way through a desert he hasn't had a drink for days he is on his last breath and their buzzards circling overhead I was impressed with the initial tracks that ice age dropped before the release of this album they really wanted to just send the signal out there to fans that this record is going to be different there's going to be more instrumentation the songs are going to be longer it's going to be different expected to be different and I mean loud and clear the message was I expected a different record and this certainly is a different record in the best way possible in such a way that the band is able to maintain everything you loved about them in their previous stuff but somehow have made it more complex engaging compelling they just built it up I think there's more variety on this record than any Ice Age album so far there are some wonderful slow burners on this thing like the very dreary string kissed against the moon which has some wonderful piano arpeggios in it too or even the song forever incredibly slow song very dismal very depressing and an amazing ending on this track too so so so climactic especially with the horn I love the closer the title track on this thing it just feels like getting your heart ripped out the chords are so heavy they're so downtrodden the ending is just really intense and noisy this track makes the angst of even the saddest 90's records just seem like a walk in the park the song Cimmerian shade is one of the noisiest and and more intense tracks on this record and the melodies coming out of the song are so sinister they're so evil very menacing strung out guitars all over this song and then there are tracks on this record that I think are outright fun like the song the Lord's favor one of the lead singles from this LP fantastic track iceage doing kind of a rockabilly thing taking their post-punk e noise rocky guitars and applying it to the do-do-do-do-do bass lines in a country song Elias vocals are totally strung out more than ever but still through his some compelling melodies for this song and then there's also the track abundant living which has this really gnarly riff playing throughout it that I think is played on a mandolin doo doo doo de song has some serious swagger to it the band is just kicking ass all over this song there are moments where this album just straight-up rocks like on how many and even in the really propulsive rock instrumentation Ice Age finds room for pianos and maybe some very sudden breakneck musical passages and changes like at the 1-minute mark of this song there's the song simony which is another great tune but maybe this is where ice age pull the most from The Joy Division playbook on this record there are a few songs that are maybe more chaotic than they are melodic and I think the tune sort of suffers a little bit as a result maybe with the song let it vanish a little bit but even this song is it really that much weaker than some of the best tracks here even on my least favorite tracks I'm finding the lyrics to be just so ah just the the sadness and the depression behind these songs it's just it's just so rife these track these structures so rife with the nastiness just the dismal Ness these are characteristics again that I've enjoyed about ice ages previous records but it is just so much stronger here and what's awesome is that they've been able to create these dismal feelings by bringing more beautiful melodies and instrumentation into the fold they've they've made me feel like less emotionally by giving me more musically I think this is a fantastic record I think it's a
