symphony concerto here the Internet's busiest music nerd thank you for watching and it's time it's time for a review of the new shellac record dude incredible this is the latest full-length LP from famed underground rock outfit shellac they have been releasing albums pretty steadily since the mid 90s for example their debut LP at action Park a pretty significant record in the noise rock post hardcore math rock canon but a great deal of shellac reputation is built upon that of one of its members Steve Albini of course we cannot downplay the input from other members such as Todd Trainor and Bob Weston Bob you might also remember him from doing tape loops and sound effects for Mission of Burma but Steve is a super producer engineer studio owner he's worked with everyone from Slynt to the Pixies Nirvana Don cab the Jesus Lizard screaming females Cloud Nothings and despite my love of his other projects like big black sometimes Steve's reputation as a producer and an engineer overshadows his influence as an artist regardless that is what we are going to focus on here with this new LP dude incredible is an album of music that is as clearly and as boldly stated as the title that represents it this thing is nine tracks 33 minutes we have guitars drums various members of the band trading off on vocal duties there are loads of very crunchy sharp distorted guitars and bass guitar on this thing sometimes the guitars can get kind of shrill or so distorted that the sound is just like destructive it's on fire it's crumbling shellac continues on this new record to offer pummeling grooves and riffs that often times are in a really weird time signature on this new record shellac continues to offer pummeling riffs some of which ride some some off-kilter grooves a lot of these riffs or guitar leads are repeated to help bring tension up as the song progresses the vocals feature some yelling some screaming some kind of raw spoken word a little bit of amateurish singing and the production as usual is pretty clear it's pretty crisp the drums are really boomy the guitars and the bass are really close and up in your face I think the vocals are a little muffled unfortunately on this record when comparing them to previous shellac efforts especially at action Park and a thousand Hertz but still on this new LP like on previous releases the are usually pretty stark and no BS one of my favorite tracks from 1000 Hertz you'll hear a lyric like this is such a sad  song we'll be lucky if I don't break out crying all of these characteristics I just mentioned you can find running pretty continually through the entire shellac discography shellac sticks to its self applied minimalist tag as well there aren't that many overdubs or layers on this record the distortion isn't usually so heavy that it takes away from the dynamics of the guitars everything here is pretty free of reverb the the recording overall just very dry it's very clear that shellac pulls a lot from bands like Mission of Burma or have a great appreciation for the music of Fugazi or take a great deal of influence from bands like wire and I guess it's cool to see that these influences still have a place on the band's newest records it's also another instance of the incredibly raw and dynamic performances that usually find themselves on a shellac record - there is a lot of interplay on this record record record record Steve Bob and Todd are just together in a way that you don't really hear a lot of bands together in studio recordings these days whether it be in commercial radio music or even in the underground because it's easier to record stuff digitally and just kind of multitrack stuff now and this comes out right from the start of this LP with the opening track that features a guitar riff that feels like it's pulled right out of a stoner rock song but they groove it out in a totally different way once the bass and the drums come in this is a six minute long track there's numerous parts to it a few surprise changes I owe that hook that I can't totally make out the lyrics mostly because the vocals do feel kind of muffled in comparison of vocals on previous records like I mentioned earlier but still the hand and the hand are there the energy the electricity behind this part in the song is just crushing there are a few likeable angular left-field rock songs on this record like the very dreary track Gary or even the incredibly funny at the very end I'm riding bikes but most of the tracks here feel more like abstract experiments in rock art and that's totally fine that's why I enjoy wire albums like 154 or why I enjoy earlier shellac records this results in moments like all the surveyors we're in the middle of the track with these pummeling raw guitarists you're getting these calls of kah kah kah song surveyor is great too this album has quite an obsession with surveyors although I wish that obsession led to a good track on the mayor / the surveyor which is kind of a one minute instrumental where the guitarist is so horrendously half-baked it just kind of leads me to think did you write this did you write anything or did you just figure you were gonna wing it while I do like relaxed performances and their energy and their aesthetic I guess you can't really go into this LP expecting a catchy straightforward or even an entirely visceral rock album because there are some I guess anti songs on here tracks like you came in me or the people's microphone hard-hitting tracks but they're also kind of daunting and challenging to you know you're going to need patience for these songs I suppose although these tracks - a lot like mayor surveyor do feel a tad under in as well overall I would say this is a pretty good LP there are some underwhelming tracks there are some great tracks the entire album itself is kind of short and given that shellac really hasn't made any effort toward reinventing themselves on this LP it does have a lot of similarities with their past catalogue although in a lot of ways they are doing what they have always done as well as they have always done it I'm glad bands like this are still kicking if you're a die-hard experimental rock fan I would say give this record to listen and especially check out their back catalogue if you haven't already I'm feeling a strong six to a light seven on this thing transition if you've given this wrecker to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana shellac dude incredible forever

hi everyone used to be Fant anno here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new Thom Yorke record tomorrow's modern boxes Thom Yorke singer-songwriter multi-instrumentalist producer famed frontman of Radiohead one of the most significant musical acts of the 2000s there's not really anything that can be said about their early and definitive years that hasn't already been written broadcast each tin to stone but Radiohead's latest output has kind of been consumed by the band's attraction to or maybe even just Thom Yorke's attraction to electronics most famously on the latest full-length LP the King of Limbs which drew quite a few comparisons from Tommy works first solo endeavor the eraser the beats the instrumentals on this LP were pretty stiff pretty lifeless in comparison with a lot of Radiohead's other material however Thom Yorke followed this project up pretty quickly with another project Atoms for Peace the record he dropped through that project amok seemed like a much more well-put-together version of what was going on on the King of Limbs in my opinion some of the tracks off these two records I like some of them I don't my views on these albums are a little mixed I think Tom loves the explorative qualities of electronic music the complexities of electronic music as do I which is why I follow a lot of his forays into this stuff but sometimes Tom really fails to make this genre come to life for me because the end result when he produces something is typically very static and kind of lifeless and maybe that's part of the reason he feels so attracted to these sounds the lack of humanity the lack of an organic feel however I can't say in the case of Tom's music it's something I vibe with 100% even if he does manage to drop a real sense of melancholy and introspection in these songs from the King of Limbs I thought amok was a step forward and in my opinion I think tomorrow's modern boxes is kind of like a step back I think it's self-serving synthetic sadness compositionally I think these tracks are a little less flesh out than the material on amok and maybe even the King of Limbs in comparison I would say even a tad unimaginative there are lots of very dry frigid beats and since sequences on this LP and at times the synthesizer leads the bass lines the rhythms they barely feel like they're syncing up or complementing one another kind of like on the track there's no ice for my drink which is a relatively soulless instrumental there's a little very faint vocal accompaniment on this track not really anything lyric wise to be offered but this song is sort of in the minority on this very short album the majority of the tracks on this LP actually has Thom Yorke's vocals being very upfront very clear tom is delivering more of his typically nasal crooning but very few of these songs are actually that well developed you do have songs like the intro here which kicks off with a pretty great beat but it doesn't really progress into anything that significantly interesting or you do have songs that are really stripped back and skeletal and with the chord progressions and the melodies the vocal melodies they may be pretty appealing there's like a serious tune at the core of this song but instrumentally tom doesn't really build things up beyond the very sparse simple tune that he offers it's like these songs are either suffering from debilitating depression or just a little writer's block or just the couldn't be bothered blues I like the aesthetic of this album I like the sense of place this album has but it's sort of like being rocketed into space without any of the fun or excitement or newness of actually being in space again I do like the aesthetic of this album and there are parts musically that do stand out to me again with chord progressions sort of like the closer the vocal melody on this track is really great as well then there is brain in a bottle which it's got a great beat but it doesn't move on anything more interesting beyond the intro the song interference which I think is my favorite song on this record sounds like it could have made for a great intro or for a great song at the core of a track on a record like kid a and the song truth ray is actually stunningly beautiful as well I loved the way that the chords just drone throughout that entire track it's just intoxicating ly sad most of this a song no hype no pressure dropped out of nowhere album isn't that bad it's not that great either some of its good some of its just glaringly boring Thom Yorke here is just kind of indulging in a bit of digital diddling the results are mixed but I wouldn't mind listening to it again I'm feeling a strong five to a light six on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana Thom Yorke tomorrow's modern boxes forever

hey everyone big scary volcano here the intranets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new perfume genius record too bright now with this review right here we're going to be experimenting a little bit it's going to be a co review live right here in the needle drop office and believe it or not we're going to be having kouchuu chesta in on this review giving his point of view talking about what he likes what he dislikes about this new perfume genius record it's kind of a weird thing to try but we're gonna let kow start off right here sort of telling me what his least favorite song on the album was okay thanks Amy well the perfect genie record my least favorite music from it I need real sense settings hold on hold on there's two things that's going to make this review perfect that I totally forgot about two things one I'm going to need you not to talk for the rest of the video don't talk again oh and to transition dramatic lighting transition perfume genius is the musical project of multi-instrumentalist Mike had rias super edgy very genius this is his third full-length album and I have been hotly anticipating this record considering I am a big fan of his songwriting style his two previous full lengths learning and put your back into it each album a heartbreak in every song on these records a teardrop Mike songs typically are kind of short skeletal instrumentally and melodically a lot of these songs sort of revolve around some very simple piano chords and Mike's incredibly powerful and emotionally charged voice and the chords that Mike works into his songs they're often played at a very slow or easygoing pace these progressions at times feel like they're informed a little bit by gospel music or maybe even some vintage pop on his latest songs mike has been finding ways to build up his typically simple piano led tunes with a lot of backing instrumentation and Mike's embrace of that studio sound quality of better sound quality in his music has led to a bit of a night and day difference on his first two records Mike continues down the path he was forging on put your back into it essentially finding new ways to put lush instrumentation behind his very emotionally choked up dirges and Mike also has a few musical experiments up his sleeves on this record - which is funny to think because he's not wearing sleeves however the opening track on this LP just kicks this album off in usual perfume genius fashion the song I decline is a beautiful spacious piano ballad with Mike singing some very sparse lyrics he sings very slowly and it makes it seem almost as if he's saying more than what he actually is but the lines of this track are pretty bare the message is pretty simple no no thanks I decline he seems to decline a tired line he declines what seems like an offer from an angel to save him I don't know if he's saying no to the cliche or if he is saying no to the idea of salvation in general either way it means for another perfume genius album where Mike essentially grabs happiness by the horns and wrestles it down to the ground in tintin tintin but learning from the success of past singles such as hood mike has made sure to put plenty of tracks on this new record that are actually quite visceral Mike delivers his most instrumentally dense tracks yet on this LP and inadvertently I think the end result is kind of poppy maybe perfume geniuses most accessible record yet there's some really prominent percussion on these tracks and the backing instrumentation is no longer as faint as it was as put your back into it take this on Queen for example great lead single from this LP buzzing keyboard notes on this track some really dramatic drum fills some descending epic mystical synthesizer melodies and a really explosive chorus - that is not only loaded with the strange way melodies but also what seems like a kind of backing up the percussion and the lyrics of this track are actually pretty interesting too it kind of seems like mike is painting this picture of a flawed crumbling emotionally inept matriarch moving on from this track to the song fool which has a seriously vintage feel to it like a piece of vintage pop from the finger snaps to the saxophones to the upright bass this song feels old school the song moves pretty quickly through a very brief and beautiful verse and then right in the middle of these two verses on the song all of a sudden things just go ethereal and Mike's voice just climbs up and up and up it's almost as if we've had a dream sequence in the middle of a song I love the song my body which is maybe the most experimental track on the entire record feels almost as if the song was written by timbre Tambor and Xu Shu and then handed over to Mike to perform this song has a 3/4 time signature eerie bassline some of Mike's most twisted vocals and lyrics yet it's like a racer head sick on the song long Pig we see Mike's singing over these really tightly wound bubbling synthesizer sequences that sound like they could have come out of a Vangelis song or a tangerine Dream's song but there's some very primal percussion going on in the background Mike does a fantastic job of mixing these two worlds the futuristic and just the the very primeval and another strange track but maybe one that I don't necessarily connect with is I'm a mother a song where Mike's vocals seemed to be just pitched so far downward they're kind of unintelligible and he sings with his voice just cracking and it's like he could barely hold the note he's just so distraught he just can't hold it together and it's the oddest sounding thing so there are definitely quite a few new ideas there are a lot of firsts on this perfume genius record there are actually a handful of songs on this thing that approach four minutes in length which is kind of a rarity in the perfume genius discography even the songs on this record that stick to Mike's typically simple formula of just heart-wrenching piano ballets kind of get uplifted a little bit at least toward the end where all of a sudden they break into a different musical phrase or introduce really epic instrumentation songs like no good or don't let them in but I do have my reservations about this record I think that with Mike extending more songs and trying to write longer songs there are some tracks that stay engaging throughout and there are some that don't plus even with the introduction of more instrumentation it's not like Michaels songwriting style at its core has changed that much so there is a little bit of melodic deja vu here and there on this record if you're familiar with Mike's back catalogue while I have no doubt that Mike can and will change moving into the future which is exemplified by tracks like grid there are some songs here that kind of show that Mike's approach to writing piano tunes can be a little limited at times and there are some moments here namely on the song no good where I feel like the bit of instrumentation or maybe the instrumental interlude or the instrumental shift toward the end of the track feels a little kind of tacked on but for the most part this is perfume genius sounding emotional and gorgeous as usual while I do personally prefer his last full-length album a little bit more I think this record is great as well and I highly recommend it I'm feeling a strongly to a light 9 on this LP transition if you given this album a listen what do you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana perfume genius to bright forever

ah hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Milo album a toothpaste suburb Milo is a rapper whose roots lay back in Wisconsin and this is his first full-length commercial project which is kind of hard to think because I've been following this guy's music now for a handful of years and it's been kind of a long somewhat windy and rocky road to get to this point back in 2010 in Wisconsin Milo was yet to really go solo and was still making music in the rap project nom de rap but in 2011 that's when I heard of him he dropped his I wish my brother Rob was here mixtape which I totally loved then he put out an EP rapping over a bunch of bats instrumentals that I wasn't that crazy about but the following year is when he really came together not only prolifically but artistically putting out music under the scallops Hotel name-dropping music with Hellfire Club teaming up with open mike eagle and bus driver and no-can-do that was really coming out in a big way and then he was coming out with great solo projects that fans and critics alike seem to be praising like cavalcade and his things that happen to night things that happen at day EPS you may remember those are my favorite EPS of last year Milo's music was very slowly and very organically gaining a passionate audience and impressing the ears of child literacy advocates and export stars alike and the fact that Milo would be able to appeal to such a wide audience is not really surprising considering that in his music he comes off very clever funny humble likable smart and deviously nerdy it's funny to think of how many MCS are out there right now marketing themselves and pimping themselves out as being different breaking the mold and hip-hop I'm not your typical rapper but to me Milo right now really is that quintessential anti rapper and he could be dethroned one day but there are many emcees in my opinion that as hard are working against the self-centeredness and the brags and the materialism the aggression and the attitude and the few people who could compete with him on that level he's already collaborating with him on record and with these collaborators instead of hip-hop stereotypes Milo offers vulnerability abstractions philosophy an endless gauntlet of references to sci-fi RPGs and pop culture and a rap flow that borders on calming spoken word and a lyrical style that seems to emphasize the idea of just stream of consciousness free subject association rather than a clear theme or concept or storyline sonically the aesthetic of this project isn't really that too far off from what milo was doing on his things that happen to eps to produce he brings on a glue ghost tastes nothing gray hat and of course once again riley lake and together they assemble a group of instrumentals that not only are very ethereal and are very lush and colorful but have a bit of a West Coast flavor to them too like these guys are really pulling from Flying Lotus in that whole brain feeder camp maybe a little bit of James Blake too there are lots of punchy off-kilter beats very vibrant synthesizers from rich chords to very bubbly bleeps and bloops there are tons of effects laid into these instrumentals too I think by the end of this record the instrumental tone of this album does get a little old it does get a little stale it's not like there's a ton of variety across these beats even the ones that hit hardest are fairly gentle and aren't really that poppy nearly every beat here has kind of a relaxed vibe to it but some songs are softer more subtle more beautiful more ethereal and others are a little more dry and tangible but in terms of the lyrics it's a little bit more difficult to come together with a summation even though this record does start off with a really clear idea the opening track here starts off with a bit of a story Milo talking about moving into his first apartment his first apartment on the west coast his first apartment in general I'm not totally sure but he's talking about the life he's leading at this point rusty dollar-store pots and pans living broke borrowing a preamp from open mike eagle really tiny insignificant mundane things that in isolation would be totally uninteresting but Milo finds a way to pull them together into a pretty good song there are even some funny lines that turn up one where he says that he couldn't afford cover art from folk artist Clementine hunter there's a little mantra that Milo repeats a few times at the end of the track too but it doesn't really pull the song together but how could this little lyrical repetition pull this entire track together it's not like a package it's not a box it's a bunch of little trinkets just all strewn about toward the middle point of the instrumental things seem to go really ethereal for a moment Milo starts with whipping out these lyrics that seem to deal in violence and abuse toward black people talking about media lies a lot of stuff that seems to be pretty relevant given the recent events in Ferguson Missouri it's a really heartfelt moment in the song and for sure an authentic expression of what Milo feels on this topic however this moment in the track doesn't really have much more weight than any other moment in the track or any other moment on this record because it's mentioned it's approached with the same brevity that nearly everything else on this album is I think the mental state of this record can be boiled down to a single line in Milo's lyrics one where he says he was going to learn the keyboard and write several ballads but instead at a cookout he got lost in the tater salad listening to a toothpaste suburb is a lot like reading a series of diary entries and and bits of poetry from someone who has a severe inability to focus on anything and Milo's inability or refusal to focus is only emphasized by this records lack of hooks and Milo's sort of monotonous flow and voice and when Milo does try to write hooks they can be a little hit or miss some I like we can eat great clumps of sky but others like the song argyle socks which features one of the harder beats on the record they're a bunch of harp samples bus drivers going wild on the hook this instrumental is a freaking mess but to mention bus driver he dropped an album recently I loved that record and a lot like Milo he seems to avoid just delivering a simple straightforward song structure and when he does he really does something weird and progressive in the process he really does it on his own terms Milo also tries to opt out of traditional structures but he offers very little in their place for sure a lot of these beats instrumentals tracks are linear in structure we're sort of getting this one spot and then in the middle there's a significant change goes into something completely different but a lot of these changes a lot of this beauty a lot of what makes these songs intriguing from beginning to end has much more to do with the instrumentals than it does with Milo almost every single line on this project no matter how good it is is just dust floating in Milo's breath because each line builds off of and builds up to nothing it's like I'm listening to a melancholy punchline rapper with way too many inside jokes and whose sense of humor ranges from dry to incredibly immature the beginning of a toothpaste suburb is really great I think this album kicks off well and maybe that's partially because the fact that Milo doesn't offer much lyrical guidance through these songs it's it's yet to set in but it's the back end of this album that I think ends up really lacking especially starting with the song just us I mean you know I can't step in and say how you should or should not tribute a friend but to me this revision of this song doesn't really live up to the original in any way shape or form however this is one of the few songs that actually focuses on a topic and deliver some really personal accounts of a very significant moment in Milo's life and that alone makes this track so much more enjoyable than many of the other songs in the tracklist here the end of this record doesn't feel any more significant than the beginning of this record it's just all really so uneventful in my opinion and it's not that Milo is a one-dimensional rapper or one-dimensional artist it's just I think he goes about addressing all of these dimensions so haphazardly and so quickly and so effortlessly and so in significantly that at the end of the day it all sounds like it's just one dimension there's some great beats on this record a lot of the rhymes are endearing Milo still has a personality that I think is enjoyable in music but a lot of the things that at the start of his career made him kind standout and made him different on this project are now starting to limit him a little bit I think I'm feeling of strong five to a light six on this LP transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should are you next and that's it Anthony Fantana a toothpaste suburb forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Nets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new bus driver record perfect hair hair hair hair this is the latest full-length LP of long time abstract art rapper bus driver as you might know he is a member of the recently formed Hellfire Club collective all of whom have been making an incredible amount of noise this year with a gauntlet of solo projects people like no-can-do open my Eagle Milo has a new album out as well but bus driver he just came out with his for as long as I have known about bus drivers music I have admired his incredibly unorthodox approach however I have not always enjoyed it for example with his last full-length LP bows dollar sign arrows a project that is seriously difficult to put into words however I was very very turned off by the kind of wacky off-the-wall instrumentals and and bus drivers singing especially I was just hoping on this new project of his he would go back to the idiosyncratic rapping rapid-fire rapping that I enjoyed so much on his earlier projects and he does do that on perfect hair he finds balance between his fast tonally schizophrenic nasally flows and his singing now on this record bus driver is writing some of the weirdest instrumentals i've ever heard him on before among the producers on this album are bus driver himself he actually does quite a bit of the production on this record also riley lake you might remember him he's worked with milo mono/poly of brain feeder records also jeremiah jay kenny siegel great dane and mike GAO and the instrumentals are incredibly appropriate for bus driver 4 for these songs as well they're modern they're envelope-pushing they're glitchy they're subtle at times they are quite beautiful and ethereal - some instrumentals have some pretty sweet melodies weaved into them others like the track open mike eagle lands on have the rattling trap influenced high hats that turn up in so many instrumentals today but they are turned up in the most insane on this album here and we've also got tracks that have quite a bit of jazz influence in them it should be no surprise given bus drivers lyrical track record and instrumental track record that this album is the most unorthodox thing that has been Hellfire Club affiliated thus far the absurdism in the lyrics on this record the satire bus driver lyrically and song structurally purposefully avoiding coherence it's like this record is hip hop's long the weighted answer to Captain Beefheart it's only appropriate that on the song Bliss point bus drivers Flo's are met with some really wild angular sax riffing because the way bus drivers flows punctuate beats it is very horn like the pace at which he blurts out words over instrumentals is a lot like that of a solo from a trumpet or a saxophone player playing a piece of hard bop each word is delivered with this incredibly loud and forceful spasmodic brightness but even though drivers rapping may be fast and it may be loud and it may be eccentric and and some of these beats may hit hard I would not say this record is very visceral it's more cerebral than anything it may be kind of catchy and maybe you can Bob your head to it to a degree but it's just so dizzying and confusing and confounding and difficult right from the intro track on this LP we're getting this lumbering groove and instead of getting a catchy chorus to complement these verses instead we're getting these vocal breaks or bus drivers just throwing out these random ridiculous figures as to how much various things on this album cost the studio costs this the backup singers cost that and all of these figures are astronomical after all this the instrumental suddenly goes ethereal completely just melting away the momentum of the song the mood changes instantaneously there's a fantastic finish with just this throbbing pulsating synthesizer sequence and a lot of the lyrics on this track deal in hip hop music the music business relevancy dopest growing older being 30 and having clothes that are still dirty and kind of questioning whether or not you're you're really in the right place in life bus driver reflecting on his continued participation in this music thing it's not a very concise message it's not like it just comes out and says it but for whatever reason at least to me it kind of just feels like it's ringing very loud and very clear and even though I do really love this track I love this start of the record I do kind of end up with some mixed feelings on this song and for the entirety of this album I find these songs to be awe-inspiringly unique I think they're fun and funny I think they're clever I think they're witty but there are times when I think what bus driver is doing lyrically and sometimes instrumentally or with his flow is so difficult it can be a little I don't know unrewarding but with bus drivers really unapologetic sense of humor it's not hard to warm up to what's happening here especially on a track like Bliss point that I mentioned earlier instrumentally but lyrically bus drivers just railing on hip hop as if it were a person giving it these human qualities saying who is hip-hop dating what does hip hop check in the gender box I don't think hip hop has the body to pull off that outfit I think I'm becoming better acclimated to what bus driver wants to do sonically and vocally in this era of his career but I also think he's finding ways to make music that is challenging but not unlistenable case in point the song egodeath the first song I think really hit me hard when I first listened to this record and hit me as being catchy and one of the more easy to listen to on this record not only because of the two great features from Aesop Rock and Danny Brown but the instrumental two is fantastic the ominous heavy bass the distortion on this track the beat on this thing too reminds me a lot of something LP would have pulled off on his last full-length there's a killer hook on here too and lyrically and flowise bus driver Royce this track his lyrics and just how he's spitting on this song is just so dizzying it makes Aesop's verse right after like a walk in the park and I am catching some themes of egoism or even anti egoism especially coming out of Aesop's verse where he's mentioning a bunch of really embarrassing or like humbling things I mean crashing your car Mario pajama bottoms and this is not the only track in this track listing that I think kind of feels catchy there is when the tooth line horizon blinks with open mike eagle and the song features this hook that has the strange 3/4 flow over a 4/4 beat those rattling high hats I mentioned earlier are insane I'm loving the warped synthesizer chords on this thing too and things actually get a little more easy going from here with tracks like motion lines which is maybe one of the most serene and beautiful tracks on this entire record there are some beautiful background vocals on this track and even though bus driver comes through with that really just firing machine gun flow he's all over the place on this B there are a lot of a lot of sad moments in his lyrics specifically having to do with love there's even a moment where he compares his love to a cervix tear ow so there are some love loss themes coming through on some of the tracks here like on King cookie faced as well where it seems like bus drivers may be coming to terms with being a crappy person in a relationship or maybe the relationship sort of broke apart and then afterwards realizing you might have been the cause of that or you were a huge contributor of that and you're sort of seeing all of your shortcomings for what they are and then there is the song with verbs the track can't you tell I'm a sociopath it's one of the moments on this LP where bus driver strikes that balance between being challenging yet instantly gratifying something he doesn't always accomplish fully especially on a song like upsweep where to me his singing and his incredibly nasal flow really hits like a breaking point of Tolerance but sometimes bus drivers excessive anus has an undeniable appeal and beauty to it like on the closer here colonize the moon the song that lyrically is really self-aware and hilarious and instrumentally I think it's a pretty beautiful sonically I think between all the reverb and the very strange harmonized singing vocals it really captures a sensation of the coldness of space and with the mention of street fashion and money and other pieces of pop culture in this song there's even a line here where bus driver says it's important that his life reflects pipsy fan fiction it's almost like he's just taking everything he observes around him and just taking it in and just shoveling it in his mouth and just chewing it and chewing it and chewing it and then just blah and then he takes everything he has just spat out and rearranges it to reflect something he feels and and usually the raw emotion of what he is pontificating or reacting to comes through but yet the way the words are arranged and the way the lines are arranged it becomes kind of difficult to get the total 100% picture however I don't really think it takes away too much from the emotional impact of these songs and I find the the the difficult jumble of a lot of the things he's expressing to be kind of invigorating and exciting and kind of fun and and very playful too um I'm loving this record I am it's a creative it's a unique it's an interesting record not just for bus driver not just for Hellfire Club but for hip hop in general if you're looking for something that's just out there and it's riding the fringes it's got a load of different musical influences and lots of lyrical tongue twisters frenzied flows then I would say give this album a listen you will not be disappointed if you love your music - puzzle you then I most definitely invite you to a listen of this record I'm feeling a decent - strong 8 on this thing try and if you've given this bus driver wrecker to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana bus driver perfect hair forever

could have so many people pissed off at you if you don't give this like the best review the most positive review don't mess it up don't mess it up hi everyone Anthony ant tanto here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new FX twin album Cyro FX twin is one of many but the most popular of musical aliases spearheaded by uk-based electronic music producer Richard E James he is a pioneer in ambient techno Drum & Bass acid techno IBM his styles and his ideas had been copied the world over his influence on electronic music is immeasurable a lot of the sounds and techniques employed on albums such as ambient works have been done to death mostly by other artists to the point where what goes on on these very influential records seem so commonplace and kind of dated now plus it doesn't help that the technology available for making electronic music drum machines sequencers synthesizers digital audio workstations all of that stuff has increased tenfold in terms of capability ease of use availability now even though I think mr. James earlier works do sound a little dated today I don't think that is the case for his entire discography I think the Richard D James album still holds up incredibly well and I actually think the record he left things off with in 2001 is one of my favorites in his discography drugs it may be kind of long-winded and it definitely does drift away from the electronics that many people came to expect from Richard there's a lot of organic impressionist compositions on this record but this is not where Richard is starting his adventures once again on cyro instead he's kind of moving backwards toward an almost completely synthetic sound producing a series of tracks that sound almost retro in tone from the drum patterns to the drum Tambor's to the way the synthesizers sound Cyro calls back to the world of cold calculated cerebral and relaxed IDM I wouldn't say these tracks are as ambient as some of the songs from aphex twin first two full-length records but these songs definitely do explore Richards softer more introspective side so it kind of begs the question do we need Richard to come back to give us another installment of his early years here and how you answer that question depends on how big of a fan you are I guess I mean I just reviewed an effects twin release earlier this year under the name caustic window as music from Richards past sort of resurfaced under this other moniker however that caustic window record didn't make nearly as big a splash as this new effects twin record is and that's for good reason the aphex twin name has quite a cultural pull to it but not really the same kind of pull it used to have when Richard was at his highest peak of relevancy in electronic music when he was still very much active today the underground in the mainstream of electronic music couldn't be more fragmented Cyro most likely isn't landing on the radars of many Zed or Skrillex fans even though the latter of those two is a big fan of Aphex twins music but even though there's a new young market of electronic music fans that Richard's music might not necessarily be touching much of his early discography has recently gained this classic untouchable status combine this with the fact that it's been 13 years since the last effects twin album and you've got kind of a perfect storm for this album it's bound to be a fan pleaser his fans are looking for him to do anything at this point personally I have found this record to be a pretty enjoyable listen despite the slightly stale aesthetic Richard does approach this kind of vintage style of electronic music vintage at this point with a modern clarity and vibrance and a very nice a level of detail some of these songs are packed with subtleties progressions so slight they need to be observed under a microscope but a lot of the very easygoing grooves and light drum Tambor's and very gentle scents on these songs make it kind of easy to listen to these tracks in the background - and for sure I could dive into every one of these tracks and eat up every single musical detail but sometimes there's not really anything about these productions that that invites me in to do that that draws me in to do that because there are tracks on this record that I do think could use some grandeur changes in their progressions otherwise they're just kind of dabbling in mundane minutia there are only a handful of tracks on this LP that I found to be super rewarding when diving into them listening to them more actively namely the song xmas eve t10 which is this groovy 10-minute monster second track on the LP I love the wintery icy chimes synthesizers on this track the bass line which is really funky really nocturnal and I love the bit of percussion that the song ends off with the track is constantly switching out drum patterns and there's some beautiful Lala's at the very end of the song - it's such a journey of a track and then you have circle on six a very aggressive track farty bass lines and these bass lines are riding an increasingly glitchy beat very epic chord progression some really sporadic bleeps some wailing synthesizer leads and I love the mock guitar lead toward the end of the track - and I love the other circle on track coming right after is this a sister song a father song a mother song a cousin a grandfather song I don't know it does share some similar synthesizer tones and drum Tambor's but this track is noticeably darker earier I love the strange vocals that are worked into this track I think this song is also one of the most unpredictable on the entire LP - it definitely has some much bolder changes when compared to any other song especially this really nimble angular bassline that just Ops itself into the song out of nowhere there are some funny doubled high hats rattling away in the song - it's an intricately placed together track and this intricacy was something that also impressed me on the song mini pops but when I first listened to that track I thought it was good but in the context of this album it seems almost dwarfed in detail and attitude by songs like this and then you've got the the lighter and I guess the breezier and the less impressive tracks in this track listening kind of like the song product which is kind of like an exercise in futuristic elevator music the following track underwhelmed me a little bit too then there's the song 180 DB which is my least favorite on the entire record one of the louder and more aggressive tracks but incredibly thin on ideas when it comes to detail really recycling the same obnoxious synth phrase again and again and again why the same intricacies that are on the title track here don't show up there I don't know but I love this song it is a very peppy upbeat fun piece of digital funk reminds me a little bit of a square pusher was doing on his hello everything record but much more cold stiff calculated in pure aphex twin fashion now the final moments of this record are kind of anticlimactic for me here FX twin delves a little bit into drum and bass and and this is where air air air you really doesn't live up to the mastery of past successes on these two tracks the tremolo keyboards may be really cute but they do not reach up to the level of excitement of like come to Daddy it's like listening to drum and bass without all the gratifying punch and viscera and then the closing track which is kind of a very lone solemn piano piece it's very pretty it's very beautiful but again it just kind of adds up to the fact that the finish of this record is kind of anticlimactic and there we have the new effects twin record you can kind of just throw it onto the pile of many other records that we have heard thus far and we'll continue to hear into the future that are coming out from our musical heroes from the 90s sometimes the results are going to be great sometimes are gonna be not so great I think this result personally was a little so so I'm feeling a decent two strong six on this thing transition if you've given this record listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana effects twin sorrow forever

Oh finally poor little baby how do you live oh how are you alive oh hi everyone lumphini cloud shadow here the internet's busiest music nerd doing an actual review of the new yung lean album unknown memory yung lean is the alias of cloud rapper Jonathan lean doer fasted he came to the attention of much of the internet last year after the drop of his unknown death 2002 mixtape along with a few music videos and singles he dropped to back up the release of that tape like ginseng strip 2002 as well as the song hurt and my first reaction to these videos to these songs was that yung lean had a much stronger image and aesthetic than he did a sound which for the most part consisted of a pretty unenthusiastic voice kind of sloppy flow the vocals were also buried in the midst of these very atmospheric beats with rattling high hats and very heavy sub bass however the flipside of the sound is yung leans image which is absolutely incredible the outfits the bucket hats the whole sadboys thing the amazingly shot and edited video for Kyoto which sadly is not on this record the really ridiculous and nonsensical and kind of immature lyrics the constant references to stoner and pop culture the whole thing felt like a big fat forced meme so in my review for unknown death I met a meme with a meme and this pissed a lot of young lean fans off yung lean wasn't that happy either and I guess without knowing it I broke a cardinal rule of the internet you cannot not take the meme seriously which is kind of a funny thing when I see memes matriculating into music traditionally an art form that people take very very seriously and I see nothing wrong with making silly music music music music that's kind of absurd or has an absurd image to it but it's almost as if to admit that you are admitting that your music has some kind of inherent weakness to it it just appeals to a different emotional Sensibility there's nothing inherently wrong with it I love comedy music I love artists that have a serious sense of wit to them I love people like riff raff though I did not love his new album I think he as a figure is hilarious and really entertaining memes and the people who create memes that successfully catch on have quite a bit of cultural value and weight in today's Internet age music that has a very strong meme component to it can have just as much cultural significance and impact as more serious or meme devoid music however in the case of yung lean as far as my first introduction to his music went I kind of felt like I was already listening to someone I was very familiar with little B except without the awe-inspiring absurdity the cultural impact the occasionally very sharp and self-aware social critique in the case of young leans earlier work here I think his music suffers at the hand of the memes and it seemed that as we built closer to young leans first commercial release here there was more and more hype building up for him and the sadboys more and more people were sipping on the Arizona iced tea and now we come to the climax of unknown memory will it be a positive or negative climax I don't know but here is my personal opinion aesthetically and substance wise we are getting pretty much the same release that we got with unknown death 2002 maybe it sounds a little more well recorded a little more well-put-together maybe the budget on this project was a little bit bigger but at the end of the day we are getting another serving of fashionable meme flavored slop starting with the song blinded which instrumentally isn't that bad of a track here we've got a pretty decent ethereal trap style instrumental matched with some very shimmering and glistening synthesizer leads this is essentially the formula of many instrumental on this record from angel to yoshi city to sunrise and the song don't go as well many of the instrumentals on this record are fairly simple and straightforward but they have this incredible sensation of bliss to them I'm not saying the instrumentals are gold on this record but they definitely steal the show because they're good but also because yung lean doesn't do anything over them or within them that is that attention-grabbing the instrumentals here really bring the tone and the musical vibe and the relaxed vibe that this project has and young lean pretty much brings the image some of the catchy hooks he's kind of crushed onto these beats the relationship that young lean has with instrumentals is similar to that of Chief Keef and young chop he's the persona he's the poster boy and not much else as evidenced by his kind of uninspiring versus his unenthusiastic flow his horrific auto-tune moaning on numerous tracks here much of young leans lyrics and his rapping on this project range from bad to pretty much ignoring there isn't that much musical or lyrical variation among the tracks on this record and it pretty much brings me to my overall feeling of this project and that is yung lean right now epitomizes a paradigm shift in hip-hop music currently hip hop is being appreciated much more than it used to be for its sound rather than its lyrics and that's totally fine every decade I think it's entirely necessary for artists who work within a genre to kind of question the traditions of that genre and figure out which of them are still valuable to them and whichever ones aren't try to advance past those and create something new and some of my new favorite artists albums and musical trends have come out of this new evolution in artistic expression in hip-hop music and audience taste but in this shift of artists who are outright rejecting the old-school ways of hip-hop music in order to explore what makes for compelling rap there have been some MCS that have outright underwhelmed me yung lean is very conscious of the fact that the necessities and hip-hop music are not what they used to be ten years ago you don't need incredibly deep or substantive lyrics your lyrics don't even need to be audible or coherent or reflect upon the themes of struggle that a lot of older hip-hop was born out of your delivery doesn't need to be enthusiastic or novel or captivating your flow isn't required to be on tempo all the time and with the rise of auto-tune which is a pretty ear grabbing effect you don't even need to bring on a guest singer in order to have a melodic or a pop appeal yung lean blatantly opt-out of all of these original and traditional requirements but not out of the desire to do something altogether new and break the rules but just to do the bare minimum do as little as possible as evidenced in his mediocre flows his incredibly sluggish and listless versus his complete lack of breath control on lean world and his barely structured songs as well like on ice cold smoke or void which is kind of like a tiny verse in the midst of a really long instrumental or Yoshi city which is just like a fat verse in the middle of an instrumental so no I'm not really into this project I'm not really into young lean I think he makes incredibly weak rap music and I think he makes incredibly weak cloud rap music that doesn't even contribute that significantly to the genre young lean is more interesting as an internet phenomenon than he is a musician I'm not saying the music on this project is garbage it is certainly pleasant on the ears but jerath any fist you know the Internet's busiest music nerd here and it's time for a review of the new earth album primitive and deadly this is the latest full-length album from seattle-based stoner metal and rock outfit earth and over the years the earth has been together they have released and penned some of the heaviest and most influential music in the underground ranging from doom metal to drone metal sludge metal psychedelic rock if this is the first time you're hearing of them try out records like Earth 2 or Pentastar or hex bees made honey in the lion's skull now the band's last few records don't really rank up there as being my favorites of theirs putting these albums out most definitely involved in ambitious risk but I don't think the payout was 100% namely this risk came in the form of incorporating cello into Earth's already very thick and heavy sound and at the end of the day I think it only served to muddy up the aesthetic they've been toying with over their past few records although I have heard them incorporate this cello in the live setting and it sounded great and on this latest record earth is kind of undertaking another risk by incorporating vocals into their music something they've only done on a few other occasions and those few other occasions happened many years ago so they are really dusting off the vocal aspect of this record with three tracks three of five tracks featuring vocals from two different singers Mark Lanegan of Screaming Trees actually appears on two songs and then there is rabia oisin Kazi who appears on a single track as well now instrumentally earth doesn't seem to have undergone a whole lot of change they're still building their tracks out of these slow-mo bright shimmering heavy and thick spaghetti western guitar riffs which they honed to perfection on bees made honey in the lion's skull and they play these riffs over and over and over meditatively progressing and embellishing them with each repetition there's a lot of very slow sparse percussion the progressions are very subtle the overall aesthetic is very relaxing it's a very beautiful vivid serene yet ominous sound this is not a record you just want to play on your laptop speakers as you browse social media this album is definitely something that you should try if you find yourself having a spare moment this year and you are a big fan of heavy or psychedelic music and there's not really any need to go too far back into Earth's discography first because the guitars and the drums are executed just as well here as they have been on their past several releases however still because of the sheer amount of similarities between this album and Earth's past several releases I kind of feel urged to suggest maybe a revisitation of the drawing board to maybe think of ways to kind of advance the band's sound forward into the future because in my opinion the cellos and the vocals are not really doing it and I'm in no means suggesting that Dylan Carlsen should undergo the same kind of personal trauma he did in the time when earth was on hiatus in the late 90s and early 2000s to the point where the band actually got back together and started releasing new music again but over these past few records the few new ideas Earth has managed to stir up for me anyway has hardly been justification for an entire album of new material still despite the lack of surprise despite the lack of a feeling that Earth is on the cusp of delivering another entirely new and refreshing sound this is still a pretty decent record the additional guitars brought by Jody Cox and Brett Nelson really thicken some of these mixes up bring a lot of beautiful guitar tones and despite Dylan delivering a few pretty recycled guitar riffs here and there namely on the track from the zodiacal light there are some wonderful guitar riffs and melodies and in mental builds on the five cuts here I love the opening track on here which features a lot of very slow patient heavy guttural chugging I love the hypnotic groove of this track I love the huge rushes of vivid guitar tones the sustain to on these guitars is amazing just how they play and ring out with such clarity and the song even hell has its heroes is one of the better tracks on here too also instrumental and it starts off a little inconspicuous for an earth track but as it builds it gets heavier heavier thicker thicker incorporates some really epic bells and the resulting drone is just really intoxicating it's the tracks with vocals that I actually end up feeling a little disappointed with certainly none of these songs are awful none of the songs are out rightly ruined by any of these vocals and instrumentally these are very coherent and methodically played and performed and very precise tracks for earth again they're beautiful it's the vocal tracks that I feel a little disappointed with at the end of the day and it's because of the vocals now they're not terrible they don't ruin these tracks outright and instrumentally earth is sounding as good as they have on previous songs and I don't even really disagree with their choices of vocalists on these tracks Mark Lanegan considering his musical background and where he comes from geographically it only kind of makes sense that him and earth might share some fans and would probably make for a pretty successful collaboration I don't really think this collaboration failed because of a lack of talent or anything like that but as hard as Mark and Dylan tried I think mark has been kind of given the impossible task of singing over an earth song with the incredibly slow pacing of the track mark kind of feels like he's left out there in the open unprotected unsupported his vocals feel kind of campy and almost as if he's just wandering around this instrumental at his leisure not really sure of what direction to go how long to sustain notes it's almost as if he's singing with the inflection and with the tempo that he normally would over a backing band that we're playing at a normal speed I think it just all has to do with the pacing that earth plays its music with it doesn't really matter how Marx sings it's all really just gonna come out sounding like miscalculated unkempt spoken word and I think this feeling also comes through on the closing track here where mark also sings but maybe not to whoa hi everyone post the new wave tan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new airplane death from above 1979 record the physical world these guys are at Toronto rock duo featuring Jesse Keeler and Sebastien Grainger and ten years or so ago they dropped in the EP and a full-length album of originals and then they pretty much like dropped off the face of the planet outside of some live shows and touring and and some not nearly as successful solo and side projects and as the hope that these guys would reunite and come out with new music sort of faded away it seemed like people's interest and appreciation of their only full-length album grew DFA 1979's only full-length album your woman I'm a machine had so much going for it even though instrumental he was pretty strict back mostly just vocals drums and bass guitar with the occasional keyboard making its way in to sweeten a particular song up but oddly enough nothing really felt missing from the Bands formula as far as the drumming was concerned Grainger's performances had a lot of intensity a lot of punk ferocity but he also seemed to have a really deep appreciation for dance music beats and just body moving grooves as well I also really enjoyed his vocal delivery on these tracks he had a good vocal range he sounded impassioned as he was singing he had a lot of swagger and charisma and Keeler's thick distorted bass riffs had both the heaviness and the buzz that any modern rock record should and much of his playing on this album seemed to pull a lot from not only metal music and punk music but funk and dance music - it was great production on this LP there were great performances but in my opinion it's really hooks and songwriting where these guys shined the most because to me tracks like romantic rights and Black History Month and little girl as well as the track going steady are not only great from a performance standpoint but they're really catchy songs - now a few years ago came the announcement that death from above 1979 9 were back effectively they started playing some live shows but it didn't feel real until we got the announcement that new music was going to be coming down the pipe to the first single effectively to come off of this LP and I mean not really the fire starter of a song you hope for to me the track had kind of a mundane start to it didn't really kick things off in an exciting way in the way that I would hope a death from above song would there's kind of a cheap throwaway I roll chorus on the track if it weren't for the piano flourishes on the hook here I would say this song is just pretty run-of-the-mill for DFA but maybe just a little bit more pop appeal and I don't know I couldn't help but pick up maybe just a little bit of self awareness of self critique on the release of this song in the title given that it's titled trainwreck 1979 still though on the whole I don't really think this is a bad comeback album and I felt relatively positive going into it given the last song to come out before the release of this LP government trash was maybe one of the most hard-hitting songs I've ever heard the band released period and even though trainwreck 1979 doesn't really start that excitingly this album itself certainly does with the track cheap talk the bass and the drum groove on this track it is just classic it's classic death from above if you will allow me to use such a word with them those high hats that bass drum and kick pattern just the heaviness of that bass guitar not a bad chorus either the song rules and the this track and really this album altogether it seems like it's mostly focused on just trying to rekindle that same magic that was there 10 years ago when their debut LP came out and it definitely happens for the most part and there are some key standout really enjoyable tracks in the track listing here like crystal ball and right on Frankenstein tracks that feature DFA 1979's trademark slick nicely performed vocals in the rock the dance beats being fused together in the heavy groovin bass riffs however there are some underwhelming cuts in the track listing here as well such as always on which to me would be a pretty inconspicuous track for DFA in 1979 if not for the pretty climactic ending and then there's the song virgins which to me sounds like a kind of pathetic piece of blues rock revivalism a la DFA 1979's usual production and aesthetic it's like this track is for people who think the Black Keys invented blues and then there's the song nothing left which to me marks a clear lack of innovation in that Keeler is almost completely recycling a bass riff that the band used on their previous LP there are a few surprises though in the track listing here there's the song white as red which is the closest DFA 1979 has ever come to a slow jam it's got a load of heartbroken lyrics some young love some abandonment issues here I'm not saying the lyrics or gold or anything but it's certainly a clear storyline applied to a sad sounding song which was kind of a nice change of pace in the track listing here and then there's the physical world the title track which ends this entire LP off and is maybe the most epic song in the entire record Keeler playing a lot of melodies with his bass that are kind of romantic in nature very archaic I think it's a bold finish to the record and definitely leaves a glimmer of hope for future DFA 1979 releases to have maybe a bit more refreshing material a few more surprises within in my opinion this is not a bad record there are some tracks I prefer more than others a track or two that I really don't vibrate at all but many I do enjoy of course to longtime fans this album when you give it a listen it's not going to feel iconic there's no possible way that it could in your mind because the band has such a limited amount of pre-existing material and you've had such a long span of time to listen and ingest that material it would be really difficult to come along and expect this record to knock the old material out of the park especially considering that DFA is making music that is roughly in the same vein as their old stuff now even though I'm not head over heels in love with this record I think it's great that the band has come forward and proven that they can come together with another coherent album do this come back and have it not be a total flop and hopefully on their next release they're able to come out with music that gains hype on the merits of its writing and production and performance versus the hype of the band's return I'm feeling a strong six to a light seven on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that said Anthony Fantana death from above 1979 the physical world forever

hello my needle drops to thin EPOC tanto here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new bug album angels and devils this is the 4th full-length LP from london-based songwriter and electronic music producer the bug aka Kevin Martin a guy whose musical experience spans decades and ranges from dubstep to grime to UK bass industrial techno experimental hip hop and it doesn't stop there he is collaborated with numerous artists over the years whether that be on full-length projects guys like Justin Broderick of napalm death and yes ooh and he's collaborated with a number of other artists 'as well just on single songs through Google having them come on to his records and under this bug pseudonym which is just one of his many bands or side projects or solo efforts that he's played with over the years he has dished out quite a few sticky singles especially off of his last full length LP which was his most commercially successful to date and I essentially went into this new record of his kind of wondering how he was going to keep that momentum up would he change his sound would he focus more on just putting out more concise singles but I was surprised to hear that this new record of his I think has a little less single power and maybe a little more star power at least for underground music listeners over here in America because among others featured on this LP are Liz Harris aka grouper there's going to Sufi the psychedelic hip-hop mystic and Death Grips which considering Kevin Martin's work in the experimental hip-hop / industrial group ice many years ago is kind of like things come in full circle there are also numerous features of the uk-based rapper Flo Dan who you may remember from a moment or two on the bugs last full-length LP and with these musical guests Kevin indulges in a series of different musical genres ranging from trap to IDM experimental hip-hop and industrial music as well as some experimental dancehall however this albums variety a and is guestlist to me are significantly more impressive than the contents actually delivered unfortunately at least for the first half of this LP Kevin seems to dish out one underwhelming track after another songs that cycle through many of the same parts don't really build that significantly toward the end of the track offer very little in terms of progression a lot of the songs on the first half of this LP feel more like motifs or ideas that could start off or be the first half of more structured more fleshed out more climactic and more well-developed songs with multiple parts the first half of this LP definitely sounds nice it has a nice tone there are a lot of nice textures to it there's a decent vibe going on here but at about two minutes into each of these songs I kind of end up wondering okay where are we going to go next and the answer often is nowhere else there's the song Pandy which is kind of a slow-moving synthesizer interlude several tracks into the album where we didn't really need it the track just builds and builds and builds and builds very slowly and then at the very end it's just we're done the song void featuring Liz Harris is a pretty interesting track as a great vibe I love the heavy enveloping warm resonant bass on this song the ethereal atmospheres which seemed to have been brought by Liz herself some of it coming from her voice some of it coming from like a really weird spare piece of percussion which could be anything from her clapping her hands to smacking a stick on a piece of wood or something the rattling trap style high hats on this track are interesting too it's a very gentle chill instrumental although I do think that Liz's vocals may work so much better in more of an ambient context because they kind of get lost in the haze of this instrumental for the most part it's a beat that to me feel so urban so concrete and yet the whole thing feels like it's underwater and then there's the song save me which might just be the most aimless track on the entire LP and features go into Sufi and it's not really one of his more hard-hitting tracks here it's kind of like having a personal meditation session with going to Sufi where he's kind of moaning and singing very quietly to himself for about five minutes even though it feels like 55 minutes when I'm listening through it I can take or leave many of the tracks on the first half of this LP honestly the only song that I really feel like I have any strong affections for is maybe me lost with misread which takes a very quiet cute and very endearing piece of dancehall music and gives it some very industrial grimy sort of tattered percussion and since it's a song that is as strange as it is smile inducing and then once the second half of this album rolls in it's like a night and day difference we're getting hard-hitting grimy bangers it's like a tale of the two sided album on this record if you get this album on vinyl you're really going to be dealing with two different EPS almost once you flip this thing over there's the song function featuring grime rapper mango which is maybe my favorite track on the entire LP the hi-hats are so loud they're so sharp on this thing the bass kicks are huge his flow his delivery it's just insane high energy if you're a Danny Brown fan definitely check this on out and let's go to the infamous Death Grips song on this record it's a decent track it's like reading another grime flavored instrumental here but MC ride is is over the song doing his usual vocal mayhem thing and this verse for him is is pretty typical but the collaboration still turned out well and it's encouraging to see that this first big collaboration off of an album of Death Grips --is could mean that maybe Zach or ride or flatlander could collaborate with somebody else in the future and make some decent music to the sonic assault continues on tracks like you featuring vocals from warrior queen the instrumental on this track is insane and and so are her vocal contributions to a degree but I do think there are moments where she kind of gets lost in the mayhem of the song however my favorite flowed an vocal contribution comes on the song dirty to me instrumentally this track feels sort of like part two of the song function except Flo Dan is sort of bringing a slightly more conscious and socially aware lyrics in his verses here to tell you the truth even though this side of the album is way more hard-hitting and inherently more engaging than the first half it is a little one-dimensional this is an all-right LP I came out liking it overall but there are some seriously underwhelming tracks in this tracklist not only that but the entire album itself feels a little bit too much like just a random collection of tracks put together with no real attention paid to the flow that they have together outside of putting the quieter tracks the angels on the first half of the record and putting the harder tracks the Devils on the second half of the record I'm feeling a decent two strong six on this LP Tran sweaty if you've given this bug album a listen what did you think of it did you love it
