then we have the twins Amadeo and simone pace who handle co songwriting as well as guitars drums singing as well and together these guys have penned some of the most gorgeous sensual dreamy syrupy indie pop and rock as well as noise rock of the 90s and 2000's and some a blonde redheads biggest musical successes aren't that far behind them we have their o for album misery as a butterfly 2007's 23 and their last full-length LP penny sparkle in 2010 while not unanimously decided to be one of their greatest albums by critics and fans I enjoyed it though at the time I remember quite a few people critiquing the sort of change in pace that Blonde Redhead took on this album embracing more electronic elements maybe taking on a little too many of the very trendy chillwave sounds that were popular around this year and even though Blonde Redhead did work on a film score that dropped in 2011 most hardcore fans were most likely anticipating more this new full-length of theirs Barragan and this album is a very apparent sound and direction change for Blonde Redhead it is not quite as electronic as their last full-length LP and it is nowhere near as dense or as lush as their previous albums either this time around Blonde Redhead is sounding way more skeletal and stripped back and eerie and sort of intimate - I think Blonde Redhead does a good job of maintaining a lot of their usual characteristics but they deliver them in a much darker and simpler and more mangle way however I will not beat around the bush when it comes to my opinion of this record I feel like it is a bit of a letdown there are some musical highlights on these standard 10 tracks song listing on this record and for sure this sound change sounds really exciting in concept in blueprint but there are some incredibly lacking songs on this record as well it seems like in the midst of this less is more ideal that Blonde Redhead presents there are some songs here that present much too little like with the song cat on a tin roof a very loosely and shyly played piece of vintage pop music and it doesn't even sound like Blonde Redhead wrote this song it's almost as if they're just doing it off the top of their heads because the performance of this song doesn't really have that much purpose to it it's almost as if the band is just kind of playing to kill time like they're waiting for something to happen I was thinking it's almost as if they're in the middle of soundcheck or something which was something that to me felt sort of confirmed because as soon as kazoos first sung verse is over it's almost as if she says like something aside into the microphone to the sound engineer or something almost as if they're just getting levels on this track and this is just a spare instrumental or b-side that they just tossed onto the record even though the performance is borderline horrendous this song is like the epitome have not given a shit it's almost as if they just put it on this record because there's a 10 track song requirement or something and then there's the 9 minute mind to be had which feels like it was just put into the track listening to fulfil a time requirement the song is a very coherent sort of tightly played jam has kind of a krautrock esque steady repetitive groove to it but the very faint and shy progressions of the instrumentation on this song in no way justify the length and convincing things and then there's the three minutes or so of filler directly after the two minutes of decent songwriting on the song defeatist anthem it is a very coherent and pleasant song up until the point where it ends it has a beautiful haunting melody that kind of remind me of a early Portishead or something like that but as soon as this music dies down it goes to silence and the band just presents one disjointed musical interlude after another essentially killing time up until the track reaches the six-minute mark and there's also tracks on here like dripping which to me musically stylistically are absolutely faceless and to me Blonde Redhead is a band that has been very much not faceless very much bold very much chock full of personality but this track to me kind of sounds like your average jangly pretend shoegaze reverb rock underground soundcloud band trying to do a cover of Daft Punk's get lucky then there's seven to the uninspiring lis redundant closing track of this LP which starts off really promising but it's by the end of the song that I realized that it's pretty much nearly the same guitar part over and over and over as well as the same beat Kazu doesn't really build her vocals up that significantly over the course of the track now most of my favorite tracks on this record are disappointingly short but they are still highlights nonetheless there is the title and opening track on this LP which is a little instrumental feature some woodwinds some acoustic guitar it's gorgeous it's enchanting would have worked really well in like a Led Zeppelin album or something and this track gives way directly to one of the best songs on this entire record lady n the track with an incredibly slow smoky sensual sound this is the kind of sensuality that I expect from and love to hear from Blonde Redhead this song to me just feels like 1930s jazz club spotlight just loads of cigarette smoke in the air red dress red curtains it's just beautiful there's a great beat stellar chorus I love the melody on this track the Weeping guitars and strings it's a wonderful song it's just heartbreaking that there are so many tracks following this song that are absolutely underwhelming there are some other saving graces in the middle this tracklisting - in my opinion like the song no more honey the song is a little rough around the edges but it has a beautiful guitar melody some really interesting loud soft dynamics going on with the choruses and the verses and with the really strange effects on the vocals and the weird buzzing guitars layered over the chorus I think this song is the closest that Blonde Redhead comes to it's shoegazing roots on this record and the song the one I love is a really sparse strange and haunting acoustic ballad that features a rush of drums and harpsichord over the chorus again they're kind of playing with that loud soft dynamic over the verses and the choruses I love how kazoos voice on this song is so still and so stone-faced it's just kind of haunting and frightening and the lyrics she presents on this track as well are absolutely depressing there are some standout songs on this record I love the aesthetic that blonde redhead is shooting for on this LP and again I enjoy the usual characteristics that you find in a Blonde Redhead record but this album is incredibly lacking in song writing sometimes presenting songs that are just absolutely drab and boring whether that be because of the the melodies or the performances and then again there are tracks like cat on tin roof which there's really just no explanation for if there's one thing that's strange and interesting about this album is that it really runs the gamut of just really top-notch stellar instrumentally methodical and very well put together in detailed songs and tracks that are like getting a cold lump of mashed potatoes thrown into your lunch tray in a cafeteria housed inside of a compound where you now live because you've given your life over to a cult yeah it's like it's that bad I'm feeling a strong five to a light six on this LP transition if you've given this album a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next let me know and you're the best subscribe have a nice day drink water eat your fruits and vegetables hug your loved ones and try to help others okay okay Anthony Fantana Blonde Redhead forever

Oh to theny hot tan oh here the Internet's most humid music nerd and it's time for review the new Opeth album pale communion famed Swedish progressive metal and death metal band Opeth new full-length album these guys have been active since the early 90s I do prefer their gruffer earlier material in their discography regardless the band's trademark sound and writing has put them on a commercial and artistic winning streak throughout much of their discography from their late 90s output to the incredible success of early two-thousands albums like Blackwater park and the band has been able to maintain some incredible momentum building off of this record for album after album after album after album releases that are mostly incredible fan pleasers now in 2011 Opeth sound underwent a significant and surprising change their last full-length album while not their most celebrated record pretty far from being categorized as a loss in their catalog yet the band saw fit to undergo significant overhaul of their sound heritage was pretty much a straight progressive rock record which is different for Opeth in a few different ways one the death metal element in their music was completely erased out of the equation which at the end of the day I wasn't too surprised by that death metal to me a no pets music has always been a side kick a side dish never a main player so to see them get rid of it really only highlights the fact that they are more of a progressive metal band than they are a death metal band and to rather than being a progressive metal band with rock tendencies they are now simply a progressive rock band with some metal tendencies with this new record of theirs and heritage Oh Pet have essentially gone to the past they've gone nostalgic and they're sort of trying to stand shoulder to shoulder with their most obvious influences from King Crimson to Jethro Tull yes Genesis Pink Floyd movie blues and porcupine tree - and the end result on this latest LP a lot like on Heritage is pretty underwhelming just some second-rate hard rock and progressive rock revivalism to me it was like opeth was indulging in the past just to do it and not really bringing anything that new or refreshing to the table a lot like the record that Steven Wilson put out around this time grace for drowning and the album he followed that up with apparently some of these projects are related a part of a trilogy according to Wilson this heritage record is related to grace for drowning which is related to the storm corrosion project that ocker felt the frontman of Opeth and Steven Wilson had together and with this handful of releases that Opeth and Wilson have put out over the past few years they have essentially sapped the rock out of progressive rock with pastel performances that feel more calculated and studied than they are thrilling plain ultra clean sanitized production vocals that are just a tad melodramatic and writing that makes me feel like I'm listening to somebody's school project on progressive rock versus some legitimately exciting progressive rock and this record definitely gets an a-plus on the emulation front on the very clear ability that Opeth has to dive into progressive rock breathin its intricacies and recreate them to a tee but as a standalone piece of entertainment this record comes up short it's too predictable even for opeth I don't see this album completely winning you over unless you're the kind of person that remembers and curses the day that yes ever put out the record nine zero one two five and hasn't really bought many albums since once again a lot like on heritage the musical references on pale communion tend to kind of overshadow and drown out the sometimes legitimately good writing that Michael and his band bring to the table the vocal melody on the opening track here is a dead ringer for Blue Oyster cult's don't fear the reaper and there are some very nice keyboard and guitar solos on this tracks drum fills the band's performance is pretty tight but overall the end result is just really ordinary for this genre of music the next track on this LP is one of the most concise tracks in the track listing here and it's maybe my favorite track on the entire LP of eternity it's got this gnarly nasty dark menacing little guitar riff and groove that rides throughout much of the song it's a really nice jam I love the UH chorus line on this track it's very demolition as some of the very mystical melodic Middle Eastern flavored guitar leads that play in this track just occasionally these sorts of guitar leads actually appear later in the tracklist as well but the highlights don't really get much higher as the album continues on the acoustic interludes are just blatantly reminiscent of King Crimson as well as Jethro Tull maybe a little bit of Led Zeppelin too I don't really mind the song Goblin it's another hard rocker in the tracklist here there are also some acoustic interludes as well so there is some musical and instrumental variety across this track listing the song the voice of treason has a nice symphonic metal edge to it that definitely makes it stand out in the track listening and the closing track here just directly pulls a piano phrase straight out of Pink Floyd's dogs off of animals and ah I don't know listening to this track it's almost as if I could envision Michael playing this piano and as he's doing it he's looking back at me smiling like you know what this is from right we both know and yeah I know and it's not cute it's not a good look not only because this reference is so plain as day and so plainly incorporated but every time this record goes to tap an amazing classic progressive rock album on the shoulder it only highlights how insignificant of a contribution to progressive rock this album is overall to me this album merely sounds like group of people performing music in a genre that I like a lot and nothing more than that if that's all your standards are for enjoying a new album then give this record to listen this record to me is just standard as standard as heritage but maybe a little less entertaining because those career sort of has a very distinct sound so I was looking forward to this new rusty record however even though it may not seem this way to other listeners rusty fans I think this new rusty album is an incredible disappointment the most surprising change of pace on this new LP is this influx of vocal guests that rusty brings to the table now I understand rusty is not the most diverse producer in the world it's something he may be conscious of and I was hoping he would bring some changes bring some experiments on this new LP of his but I did not really assume or think that vocal guests would be what bring Rusty's new album diversity especially since a lot of these vocal guests in my opinion take away from the record more than they add not only in terms of their performances because there are no prodigies or diamonds in the rough on the tracklist here but many of the vocal guests on this LP have a reputation that is nowhere near as large as Rusty's there's the song up down which features vocals from D double e he sounds like a rapper from Rusty's neck of the woods there's some very sharp eighth we asked snare drums on this track some banging bass and some grading sense that just play very slowly and mundane ly in the background rusty does not really attempt to create some of the bright sunny melodies that made his last length LP so good and the lyrics from D EE the vocal delivery is just really obnoxious and kind of repetitive stylistically I think the song is a little different for rusty too it's kind of like this weird electro trap fusion it sounds more like rusty is trying to get himself on the bill of the next big EDM festival versus crafting a legitimately interesting song there's the song Danny Brown is featured on a tack it's a bangin beat but let's be honest here lyrically and flow wise - this is a pretty average verse for Danny there's the song lost with red din oh I'm sorry but this track just sounds kind of like a talkbox auto-tune Bon Iver Chromeo nightmare not only that but the vocal mixing and the vocal effects are a lot like the sense and some of the scenario on the ears there are some questionable mixing and EQ initial over this record rookie mistakes songs like Tempest have synthesizers that sound like nails on chalk and vocally I don't know who is appearing on the song dream on but this track is just yet another sort of generic vocalist melody and song just rusty is bringing this sort of sunny bright synthesizer window-dressing to the table to sort of bring it into his trademark style as far as the deeper cuts on this project goes there are really any meaty songs the first two tracks feel like intro tracks the song workship is kind of like a very spacey ethereal OneNote Rick's point never style synthesizer scape that just lasts two minutes and with the track a glimpse it's sort of like this bubbling series of synthesizer sequences which are very pretty but doesn't really go anywhere and then at the very end of the song we're getting this pummeling rhythm some downstroke guitars but then the song just ends immediately it's like it was going to go into this on a mono gucci style instrumental but it just stops because of how sadly rusty cuts off and structures some of these shorter more instrumental tracks they just kind of feel like unfinished filler it's like rusty is providing a series of interludes in an album that's barely got momentum like I don't need to take a break from the lack of good songs I just need you to give me a good song the song Raptor another big single from this LP it's not bad it's got some EDM style rhythms very driving very heavy some cycling thick walls of synthesizer it kind of sounds like deadmau5 and buttons rushing through a collaboration they were forced to do at gunpoint then the song velcro one of the few outright decent tracks on the entire LP really funky lead synth melody I love the rhythms of this track it's got a really sunny upbeat feel stylistically sonically I think this song is the closest to what fans would enjoy and expect from rusty but given that the mixing and the effects and the layers on this record are nowhere near as good this song in comparison with tunes on glass sword sounds kind of flat and dry colorless overall I was not into this record I was not into this record at all there were a few songs that I liked but mostly I disliked the tracks on this LP and I don't think I loved not a single song here the sound and the mixing and the eat cueing a lot of the time is sort of out of whack the structures of these tracks are less multifaceted less complex less exciting and challenging there are tons of filler tracks in this song list or songs that really aren't that long or don't make that much of a commitment to a sound or a structure or progression or much of anything and on top of all of it there are some really unentertaining guests in this tracklist too I'm feeling a strong to to a light 3 on this hi everyone Bethany Manzano here the internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Rory album indigo child there's been a lot of talk of in my goes in the underground music slash hip hop scene right now underachievers good guys but overall I think there's been a lot of talk of just higher planes of thinking and alternative ways of thought all that stuff that comes along with having a third eye vision thing Rory seems to be following suit with that he is a 17 year old multi-instrumentalist singer songwriter and see there's been quite a buzz gathering under his name thanks to a few singles and music videos that are on the internet right now for songs such as God's whisper and cigarette song and these two tracks essentially seemed like fusions of hip hop style production with very large grandiose far-reaching indie folk music it's as if he's listening to new and current hip-hop as well as some stuff that might have been high in the 2000s maybe he's a little into the Neptune's Pharrell maybe some future maybe some of the cloud rap that's out there on the internet right now but he seems to enjoy just as much like some boney vert or some flea Fox's maybe some Lumineers or other more low-key but very mainstream friendly singer songwriters and even though I think in a sense these songs are an interesting combination of these two worlds I can't really say I'm a fan of either track the song God's whisper while it does start off really well becomes really incessant and redundant with its constant unchanging acoustic guitar phrase its incessant handclaps the tone of the guitar is very thin the drumbeat gets stale before the song is even over and Rory as a vocalist is really boring such a spacious instrumental could have used a singer that was a little more involved in the track but instead Rory seems to just say or sing rather as little as possible and just merely plays second fiddle to his own beat I was kind of on the fence because it seemed like the song or rather that image that was being put forward for this project was kind of progressive or forward-thinking but then I was knocked over onto the more negative side of the fence as soon as I heard cigarette song which not only has one of the most inconsequential instrumentals on this entire LP but has some really silly lyrics as well about who wants to live forever and I shared my cigarette with her and I fucked her on a Wednesday evening most appealing thing about this song is the music video which is a very cinematically shot teenagers wet dream where he has no real responsibilities and he's got the sexy girl around him and they're just smoking and being bad and living in this magical tree out in the forest so I can't really say I went into this new Rory album with incredibly high hopes because with these songs thus far Rory has sounded like every bland guitar strum er I've ever heard for the past 14 years but with much less pop appeal and an image that seems a little more green for the hip crowd on the deeper cuts of this LP like on the song Superfly Rory continues to bring sickeningly saccharine instrumentals I feel like I'm listening to a combination of Jason Mraz and Bon Iver and the song Armour is almost like a reboot of the imagine dragons track radioactive but instead of a dubstep drop reading this wailing guitar line and on these tracks as well as others Rory always seems to slip in these faint very quiet young boy rap verses that are very fast but instead of being just sort of on point and really coherent and articulate all the words just kind of melt together it just sounds amateurish and nothing of note really occurs instrumentally most of the songs here are pretty coherent though the mixes are fine the beats are pretty well executed for the most part there's just not anything vocally chorus wise or songwriting wise that I really see being carried into next year there's no definitive sonic style to the songs on this record the songs on this record drown in their own influences they sound like they've been put together by somebody who's relative young and musically inexperienced somebody who hasn't really had the time or the opportunity to hone their own musical thumbprint and this inexperienced feeling also comes through on a series of tracks that I'm baffled as to why they made it onto this album it seems to be Rory arguing with his mother these tracks are really badly recorded they're unpleasant to listen to and with how short these tracks are we don't get a whole lot of context as to what the argument is about for the most part he lets her talk more than he showcases himself talking or arguing or posing questions and even though she may sound really aggressive and may sound kind of like a bully with how she's shouting at Rory a lot of the stuff she sang makes sense she seems to be really concerned for her son's future his education especially as she says to him look I'm not trying to get anything from you I'm not trying to grift anything from you but these people who you may be dealing with definitely will they'll want their 20% they'll want their 30% and maybe this is something that Rory is aware about maybe this is something that he accepts and understands but if he does it doesn't really come through in these snippets and it especially does not come through on these songs which for the most part are pretty breezy and forgettable there's the song wildfire which to me kind of feels like what would occur if you had a collaboration between Pharrell and the underachievers with the worst possible outcome the song kinda feels like a kitty pryde song pre removing the pride from her name it's very Spacey it's cloud ravish it's very ethereal their twittering high hats playing throughout the instrumental the delivery of both Rory and his guest singer feel very unaffected underwhelming but there's no cute factor here there's nothing endearing about it it's just boring the song Chariots of Fire tour the back end of this LP turns out to be this really sort of cheesy rock song with more size than stroke they're these huge backup vocals pummeling drums but the song really goes nowhere and ends up sounding as redundant as gods whisper then there's the absolutely mundane closing track on this LP which is eight minutes long and features a bunch of vocals forgettable Ian needlessly a moaning over a very bland beat it's kind of uninspiring although the it seems to be kind of getting down to the idea of youth and being inexperienced and being just stubborn however the song instrumentally vocally doesn't really show off this youthful brashness this idea that hey listen I don't care what anybody thinks I'm gonna go ahead and do what I feel like I gotta do no instead the track just sounds kind of uninspiring like Rory's mother says and one of these arguments it needs direction in the future I could see Rory at this point he is at now producing for other people or songwriting for other people writing hooks or just writing like musical parts for other singers that may have more of a defined sound or delivery to their singing or rapping or what-have-you but until the day comes where worries somehow miraculously pulls a definitive personality out of anywhere I don't see myself enjoying a Rory project I'm feeling a decent too strong for on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantan Oh Rory forever

hi everyone amputee Bam Bigelow here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new pallbearer album foundations of burden these guys are an Arkansas metal band who is fantastically good at picking hilariously depressing album titles here's their last full-length LP their debut full-length LP sorrow and extinction came out in 2012 enjoyed it quite a bit when it dropped initially I reviewed it and today I'm still somewhat fond of it and this LP of theirs is a traditional doom metal album it features five slow heavy dreary metal songs with a strong sense of melody and a very eerie and a cult vibe think st. vitus think Black Sabbath but there's something in pallbearers music that also reminds me of bands like Jethro Tull it just feels like they listen to just a touch of progressive rock enough for it to turn up in their melody writing and their vocals this first full-length LP was far from reinventing the wheel but I thought the production was really good maybe the vocals and the lead guitars were a little buried but the riffs were very heavy and basic just gargantuan and the melodies on this record record record lead guitar melodies I would say are where Paul Bearer gets most of its musical power to me this record had just about everything it needed going for it except variety varying ideas this album to me while very good in parts is kind of like a monotone monolith and from here I was definitely looking forward to whatever the band would do in the future given that it involved maybe a little bit more exploration with their sound maybe experimenting with some different metal styles or even writing some more concise songs even to direct straight into the point songs could really do wonders to break up a five-song tracklist I have no real issue with any one song on this album or really any one song on pallbearers newest album - but how can all of these slow epic melodic tracks feel significant or dramatic or stand out if all the backed up against our slow melodic epic tracks and this album is even longer than its predecessor and the band does not really spend this extra time diversifying their sound not really this album is a sequel to the first one in in like almost every sense from the sluggish pacing of these songs to the melodies to the sort of Barry vocals and again no song is really horrible on its own again we are getting these haunting fiery guitar leads the most sinister of which end up on the very last song here we get these thick and bacey heavy riffs monster drums and despite being 10 minutes in length nearly every song here is pretty engaging from beginning to end these songs are multifaceted they bring a lot of different parts to the table and the melodies that they have they just escalate and escalate and escalate them to the highest point of intensity before the band sort of breaks off into something else are sort of just ends the song entirely but finding any significant contrast or flow to these songs as a group as an album is kind of like trying to read into the finer details of a portrait where the painter decided to only use shades of the color violet to create this image nearly everything here reads as the same color so it all kind of just bleeds together no matter how many times I revisit it you can take the songs on this record and rearrange them into really any order and you're going to get nearly the same vibe there are some instrumental highlights on this LP however these song foundations breaks itself down to the point where it just has this lone eerie guitar playing by itself completely before the band breaks back in with full instrumentation just all guns blazing the song watcher in the dark has one of the most fiery and intense instrumental builds on the entire LP and immediately after brings through one of the few keyboards that appears in the tracklist here there's also the song ashes which I wish was a little bit longer because of how beautiful and tender the keyboards are on this particular track it's just kind of a shame that this song sort of just fizzles out and serves as nothing more than a mere interlude in between what just would have been yet another five track album from pallbearer where all the songs have a pretty uniform vibe there's the closer like I said it has some of the most menacing melodies on the entire record and the ghosts I used to be was sort of a lead track from this album to kind of promote toward its release and while I do find some of the melodies sticky I'm sort of wondering if I'm gravitating toward this track or if I'm remembering it just because it was merely the first I was introduced to off this LP though I will say there is a part where the tempo and the riffs kind of pick up on this track to a point where the song kind of rocks there are variations between these songs but the differences again are so slight that the tracks don't really work that fantastically as a whole record from beginning to end in this time the band is working with nearly an hour's worth of material and on their past album they barely had 45 minutes of fresh very material again not a terrible LP in a lot of ways a likable album but sort of like a hot bath it just gets colder and colder and colder the longer you sit in it I'm feeling a strong five to a light six on this thing transition if you've given this a listen what did you think about it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that is it Anthony Fantana Paul Bearer forever

hi everyone banan thony WAMP tanto here the internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review the new uncommon nasa record New York telephone uncommon NASA is a new york-based rapper producer label head and sound engineer this dude has a deep history was in the rap outfit the presence in the late 90s started uncommon records in the early 2000s was the pretty much go to sound engineer for definitive Jux records from 2000 to 2005 he has a number of collaborative albums under his belt with watu and Willie green as well as short fuse a number of solo records as well whether it be under an uncommon NASA or his other pseudonym Adam warlock however my personal first introduction to this guy's music was shortly after a fight I had with him over Twitter over the I think the last Raekwon album we did not see eye to eye and I had no clue who this guy was and you know we were just having a pretty heated and and lengthy discussion over whether or not this album was good or not that good it's so so as you can imagine coming fresh off this very impassioned argument impassioned on both sides maybe I was not totally in the perfect mindset I could have been in to listen to this man's music especially after seeing in a few different places online that he has categorized himself and his label as dabbling in progressive rap I did give uncommon asses last full-length LP a try it came out last year it's titled the land of the way it is I was impressed by the Prince Poe feature on this LP by a number of conceptual tracks on this project but I thought some of the rapping and some of the production was just a little too rough around the edges to get excited about it however I have come to learn that this is a very intentional characteristic and a characteristic that runs throughout this new uncommon NASA LP to NASA's vocals have a characteristically muddy feeling - either the way they recorded or mixed a feeling that doesn't really ring through on a lot of the guests versus here and the instrumentals on the self here absolutely cacophonous just really clunky bass lines heavy punchy just very muddy drums and samples that include screaming guitars subways sirens their shouts on this LP synthesizers scratching vinyl scratching this album is just pure underground grime plain and simple but is the style where the sound of these songs progressive not really in the sense that NASA is a flashy rapper at least he doesn't come off as one on this record he is no exhibit or Eminem or tec-9 or Busta Rhymes but NASA's material is progressive in the sense that it is different and sort of experimental rhythmically a lot of the beats on this LP are very loose they don't feel quantized they're not very tight just everything is very spaced out and just a little fluid and NASA's flow is pretty much the same way he seems to take away a lot from the rudimentary flows that a lot of rappers used to showcase in the 80s the early 90s sometimes he's on tempo sometimes he's off tempo he kind of borders between rapping and really expressive spoken word a lot of the time and he's rapping on top of these really oddly shaped instrumentals that have grooves in the background I don't think most rappers would even try to touch like the songs curmudgeon or destiny which had these really odd shuffling drum beats or the excitingly noisy instrumental on desperate times which I think there are very few emcees whose voices could really punch through everything that's going on in this beat this instrumental sounds like it was pulled together using the steam coming out of a sewer that was in the middle of the most crime-ridden Street in New York City in the early 90s there's the song 574 s which maybe has the most disorienting synthesizer line on the entire LP like weirder than a lot of stuff Death Grips has even done there are some very tight and steady beats on this LP - they have a very ARC edge to them like this bodega is trying to kill me or the title track on this record that kind of reminds me of old LP or old Def Jux or company flow records I think NASA takes away a lot from MF DOOM special herb series as well but just way weirder and more experimental there are a few sad and very dreary beats as well in the tracklist here there's a lot of variety across these instrumentals and even though they are sort of hard to get into at first because of how muddy they are they are very subtle they are very layered their blood pumping they're eerie they're creative and sometimes they're beautiful what is clearer than the sound quality of these instrumentals are the concepts or the stories behind these songs the song feedback loop is kind of a walk down memory lane with NASA directly referencing 9/11 in the hook of this song kind of marking that time as feeling long ago along with 1999 saying is this my memory or is this just my youth ending the song 574 is is another walk down memory lane but this one sort of orienting itself a little bit more around shoes specifically the 574 line of the New Balance brand and along with this shoe NASA dropped some inspirational lyrics and talks about things like working at a temp job which brought him to working at Wall Street at one point in time where he met mad jerks this bodega is trying to kill me is maybe one of my favorite tracks on this entire LP features a killer verse from a lucid of Armand Hammer and it's essentially a song kind of talking about this bodega filled with either seedy characters or bad omens and really unsanitary food there's paranoia or destruction which hit me as being kind of the one of the worst tracks on the LP at first merely because of how the hook is paranoia is always there just the way that it's sung it just feels very amateurish but the more I listen to this LP the more this hook really fit the aesthetic of the entire album and I do really love the lyrics and the sentiment of the song even though a lot of people paranoia seems to torture them and eat away at them and it seems to do that with uncommon - he sees it also as a plus something that continues to protect him deeper in his life and the song curmudgeon which has the saddest beat on the entire LP in my opinion kind of follows in that same kind of cranky loner vibe where NASA's talking about not wanting to meet a whole lot of new people or formerly strong relationships with really new people because instead he prefers to maintain the relationships he has with a lot of the people who he knows already he doesn't want to flood his life with people or just things that he feels are unnecessary he only wants to carry what are his essentials and then there's the title track to this LP another song I love and not really a track that has a story to it or anything but a lot of phone imagery a lot of phone folklore as well as one of the best hooks on the entire LP and this whole phone thing is an interesting concept that plays throughout this entire album as uncommon NASA presents this instrumental that samples a little bit of Frank Zappa off of the LP hot rats and over these instrumentals it seems like he's putting vocals snippets of people talking most of whom if not all seem to be related to this album in some way and they're all talking about why they love they left or they live in New York I think it's a nice segue from track to track it adds a lot of character to the album I think it pulls all the songs together and the entire record if you exclude the intro is bookended with these two songs which are maybe the most difficult to digest on the entire LP though I do think they do a great job of finishing things off with a really eerie feel or setting the tone with something kind of lofty and ambitious and very abstract you know uncommon NASA makes great hip-hop songs but there's something about tracks like destiny that is really difficult to classify and I really enjoy this track and I think it's a great start to the record even though it was a little off-putting at first but the more that I listen to it and the more that I appreciate it it seems like it's harder to put into words what it is about this track that makes it so great because the off kilter groove the Spacey flow the really esoteric meaning of a lot of what uncommon NASA is saying certainly makes it difficult to address some of the feature verses on this LP for a little bit I do think the songs that have more guest rappers on them tend to be a little less conceptual unfortunately I do think that is a little little bit of a hindrance though the guest verses are still good like with the stakes which features Billy woods you may know him from Armand Hammer and his solo stuff and BMS a rapper that I'm not really familiar with though his flow and his delivery reminds me quite a bit of guilty Simpson and then there is Curley Castro and Prem Rock / the song numb overall I think this is a great record one great track after another with an interesting theme and concept uncommon NASA writes of great hooks there's some very good guest features NASA picks and produces some wonderfully scuzzy beats and even though I don't think NASA is the most technically proficient or technically entertaining rapper he makes up for that a lot with his personality his subject matters his lyrics he's definitely one of those artists that when it comes to lyrics he's very much quality over quantity he is concept over catchiness there's some artists that can't really pull that dynamic off there's some artists who can and I think NASA is one who can I'm feeling a strong eight on this LP transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana uncommon NASA forever

past I mean almost killing innocent people for your own personal cheap thrill I appreciate that he's apologizing but I'm not ready to see her and be like oh he's so brave really addressing this so boldly and so openly though this is kind of an issue that watsky addresses earlier on the record where he talks about well you can separate the artist from the art but what happens when the art is about that artist there are spots like that and other tracks here where Watsky does manage to pull together some clever moments like the one which is another favorite of mine on this LP a song where Watsky kind of talks about how he doesn't believe in such a thing as there being the one person that's perfect for you and if he does believe in that he certainly thinks that that person would be very difficult to find and then of course with some very intentional irony he backs this song up with a track about boomerang where he seems to be going back and back again to this person who he seems to sort of have an on-and-off-again relationship with and there's the track tears to diamonds which to me is maybe the the second legitimate and enjoyable piece of music on this record were watski displays some pretty serious personal turmoil specifically with meds medication he takes to prevent seizures that I guess he's been going through and he kind of gives us what he feels is an even an unbiased view that people may need these medications to improve their lives or just merely live normal lives but there at the end of the day our people who are profiting off of the suffering of these individuals who have to take these medications to survive the song grass is greener is kind of like an acoustic ballad that Watts Keys heard singing throughout very quietly and very boyishly but it does have a nice weird kind of indie folk tone to it that I think is really nice and there's also the track Sarajevo which is about a couple who died during the Bosnian Civil War who were essentially torn apart by the war and came from different racial and religious backgrounds and even though Watsky doesn't really have any kind of from what I understand familial or personal ties to the death of this couple I think it's really admirable what he did with this song these days there are a lot of artists whether it be in rock music or in hip hop music who are storytelling in this way telling a story giving a vivid rendition of a tale that they don't have any personal connection to they just feel it's a story that needs to be told it's the story they feel particularly passionate about and then there's the closing track on this LP the longest track on the record it's quite an ambitious undertaking Stephen Stills of crosby Stills and Nash sings on the hook there's an incredible drum solo toward the back end of the track which is matched with all this really lush instrumentation and strings Watsky delivers a load of spoken word all over this track and kind of like the end of Childish Gambino's camp this is maybe one of the most likable moments he has on the entire record it seems that he gets really personal at this point in the song kind of talking about a love interest and kind of giving me this iral story about this first tattoo that he got again he sounds overly sentimental on this track but again his his passion is really admirable and the way he delivers this poetry is really convincing as well my only real issue with the song and this record overall again is that the instrumentation just sounds a little muddy it sounds a little flat it just never sounds as big or as grand as it implies it is again as I stated earlier I'm not really into this LP I'm feeling like a strong four to a light five on this thing even though watsky is a fast rapper he is on point when it comes to tempo he's just in the pocket he has a lot of skill when it comes to flow however this album doesn't really focus on much other than then whatever sort of drama Watsky seems to drum up in the storylines of these tracks but there's just something really kind of childish and I think a little immature about the tone of watts keys lyrics and the sound of these instrumentals even at his most serious and depressing on this record there's just something about the tone of watts keys lyrics and his instrumentals that make me feel like I'm just chewing on the musical equivalent to a Twinkie or a marshmallow and that's pretty much how I'm feeling about this LP transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think about it did you love it did you hate it why what do it's not going to have the same sort of effect or Maori and why not what happened Elise it's not going to have the same sort of effect or Maori it's not going to have a thing oh hi everyone don't the nishu tan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new anti mask LP its self-titled this is the debut full-length album from two rock musicians who if you are into rock music you should be pretty familiar with by now omar rodrguez-lpez and cedric bixler-zavala both of whom are pretty seasoned vets at this point given the time that they put in over the years with bands like at the drive-in and mars volta and musicians such as drummer Dave LH as well as Red Hot Chili Peppers bassist flea were said to have worked at least on the early tracks of this album from what I understand this LP was also recorded in a studio that flea runs and as happy as I am to see this new project coming out I'm just sort of also wondering what's going on with Cedric's and Omar's previous bands I mean you know they put together at the drive-in and then ended up putting the band on hiatus or really breaking them up and then they came back and played live a little bit and they have been broken up for a second time now and at this point the future of the Mars Volta seems pretty much over Omar and Cedric just had this history of starting bands together and then breaking them up and now they just seem to be starting a band just together and then that's it and of course over the years with the Mars Volta and at the drive-in running parallel to these groups there have been side projects Omar actually very lately has been incredibly prolific with bands like Bosnian rainbows or working with libo Tourette's he has a number of solo albums that have been coming out lately too however there is some kind of impossible to quantify electricity and excitement that I get from an album where Omar and Cedric have worked together on it even in some of their weakest moments of work together over the years there's just this really strong exuberance coming from a lot of the music they collaborate on I loved Cedric's voice which is a little bit of an acquired taste he's kind of like screamo or post-hardcore 'he's answer to Robert Plant and Omar's playing and arranging and songwriting always great though I don't think his guitar playing is as flashy as it usually is and I would say that really rings true for this album overall given the history of bands like The Mars Volta or at the drive-in a fan of Omar and Cedric might go into this record assuming that there might be a really strong element of progressive rock somewhere in the mix here but there's really not because on this record Omar and Cedric write some of their most upfront and hooky material yet just as the lineup of this band is boiled down to its most necessary of elements so are the songs on this record the riffs the lyrics the melodies the drumbeats it's all as instant as microwaved oatmeal essentially in this tracklist you're getting a load of alternative rock songs of power pop songs but they all maintain a really raw aesthetic with the production lots of buzzing guitars dry punchy drum beats the vocals are very loud and bold and in-your-face it's not a very dressed up recording and as a result these songs come off really trim and sharp and just showcase some really good songwriting and playing there's the song for am one of the lead singles off of this LP really twangy guitar leads some crunchy riffs some incredibly dramatic lead vocals from Cedric over the verses I love the hook on this thing - watching way to hanging in the lurch another great lead single from this LP which has one of the most killer choruses and most ferocious grooves at the start of this LP there's 50,000 kilowatts which is kind of this records resident power ballad there are some familiar chord progressions on this thing and melodies some cliche broken heart lyrics but there's something about this track underneath the roughness it kind of sounds like just a Golden Age power pop track that would fit really well on AM radio and there are some other songs here and there that sort of work off maybe a few too many worn-out rock tropes whether that be lyrically or riff wise as well kind of like rad lack the devil Sun or the track drown all your witches which kind of feels like a simplified Led Zeppelin song all the way though I will say there are some moments on this LP where I am picking up a slew of religious themes like on ride like the devil Sun of course with the devil reference but also the the Bible is the truth in the refrain of the hook there's the mention of no godly deed going unpunished on the song drown all your witches there's also the track people forget which makes reference to that old metaphor about atheists and foxholes there are religious and other types of difficult personal situations talked about in the lyrics of this LP but Cedric keeps it more esoteric than he does preachy my only major issue with the cell P kind of comes toward the back end of it and not that any single track gets so terrible that I can't handle it though I don't really like the track people forget the two hooks of this song really do get on my nerves especially the don't kill me that just sounds like a really bad portugal the man hook i guess i kind of feel like omar and saidar together sort of run out of ideas by the back end of this LP or at least limit the scope of their ideas to the point where a lot of these songs feel a little too Sammy samia's seems that they wanted this record to be so straightforward and so to the point that they kind of limit the ways they can venture out and experiment a little bit the entire record overall feels kind of like a mixed bag especially with the last track here feeling just about as urgent and as peppy as some of the songs on the first half of this record not really a magnificent closer or anything like that but I still think overall this is a really solid record tons of enjoyable songs on it it's just not stellar as an album but Cedric and Omar if they continue to work with anti-mask and they certainly seem capable - with all the good songs they've written here if they just sort of take how all these songs sound together as a whole into account on their next record they could have an even more fantastic LP on their hands I'm feeling a decent too strong seven on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana anti-mask forever

pop music with elements of R&B hip hop trip-hop twigs singing on these tracks was very whispered very quiet there were loads of weird samples and effects throughout these songs too of course this production was being brought to the table by ARCA a Venezuelan producer who's been turning a lot of heads lately with his incredibly strange production on his handful of releases he also took part in
