light very cacophonous percussion and strange samples to help make that percussion up among these samples I think is a car alarm but still the instrumentals is very sort of soft and and kind of faint in a way everything is just so thick these productions are dense but they still manage to come off kind of gentle and tender and have a certain amount of finesse to them I actually think there are very few newcomers in pop music right now that have as much finesse are as dynamic as the vocals and the instrumentals showcased on LP one I love the haunting mantra of the chorus on this song saying that when I trust you will do it with the lights on it's such a short statement and it is said over and over in this track but it can be read into so deeply again the instrumental is so strange so colorful it's so interesting and yet the tune underneath it or rather on top of it is beautiful and catchy as well and this is also the case for the biggest single off of this record two weeks for the most part on this album twigs hangs in her upper register when she's singing but there are moments on this track of she digs into her mid range and it sounds gorgeous I also love the descending vocal melody on the bridge of this track around the 3-minute mark it's very reminiscent of like an old-school 90s R&B jam also the rising instrumentation toward the back end of this track as it progresses this song is produced to the nines some of the beats on this record are so off kilter and glitchy and have just the strangest samples it reminds me of like Vespertine Arab York which is my favorite Bjork record which is also a vibe that comes off on the song hours though I do think that is one of my least favourite tracks on this LP just because of how cluttered it feels there's the song numbers which has some very sour melodies coming through on the instrumentals at the very start but ends up very beautiful everything comes together really nicely on the end of the track and even though it is one of the more lyrically redundant songs it does have one of the more interesting and heartbroken sentiments on the entire LP sort of questioning who seems to be an ex-lover asking him was I just a number to you another person to sleep with or could number mean something else because on the song video girl we have a refrain that almost sounds like I don't know as if twigs is questioning someone about some infidelity or something like oh is that the girl from the video don't lie to me but in fact it is a song about twigs being a backup dancer in music videos and sort of being known for that but her trying to advance herself instead as a solo artist the difficulty she's had on this journey also seems to be expressed on the song give up which is in my opinion one of the better tunes on the record - but lyrically the song talks about how she's not ready to just kind of give up on her dreams because there are other people out there who might doubt her so there are some moments on this album that do feel quite autobiographical when it comes to the point at which she is at right now with her music and sonically I think she's in a really good place especially with tracks like pendulum a song that normally I would not dig tracks that are produced in this way and are so slow in tempo yet this is an amazing song it is so sluggish and yet the really tense twittering percussion on this track as well as twig singing just keep me on the edge of my seat with every bar yes there are some good tunes on this record and good performances but what's so fantastic about this thing is just the production the detail detail detail in these beats in these instrumentals my only major issue with this LP is that there are just a couple songs that pale in comparison to others whether they be ours like I said earlier that is a little too cluttered or the song closer which I think is maybe a little underwhelming Lee bare and strip back and the final track to me while it is a good tune it starts off a little disjointed but I do think it ends off very well it's not really the most immense or eventful finish to the album but still even in this album's most ok moments the beats and the productions remain to be very wondrous and pretty and for the most part imaginative I think this is a great record even though there are a lot of aspects to its singing style and its production that feel very in vogue right now I think twigs has come out ahead supremely ahead with an incredibly creative and an artful set of songs not only can twigs and her producers write good songs but they have a fantastic ear as to how these songs should sound I'm feeling a strong 82 a light 9 on this thing transition but if you've given this album a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana fka twigs LP one forever

hi everyone Anthony Fangio here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new mick jenkins mixtape the waters Mick Jenkins Chicago MC he's had a number of musical projects under his belt at this point but he's still so young typically mix songs take a really captivating conscious tone and this newest project of his is maybe his most conceptual yet this album is essentially about water what it does what it represents Mick brings a series of different metaphors for water to the table across this album including truth and knowledge and this water theme runs throughout this album sonically instrumentally as well there is a lot of deep-sea sub bass coming through the kicks on this literally 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea type low-frequency bass there's rattling high hats lots of very murky serene synthesizers a lot of things in the mix here just touched with a splash of reverb the drums the vocals you can essentially turn this mix tape up and feel submerged in it this is definitely not a poppy explosive or aggressive mix tape it can be a little redundant sonically with this very watery aesthetic that Mick Jenkins and his producers are shooting for on this thing admittedly it is a bit of a grower I think a lot of Mick's lyrics take a bit of time to digest in terms of wordplay and the message he's trying to get across and even though this tape addresses a lot of very urgent topics the overall feel of it is pretty relaxed the only major issue I see on this tape is it's kind of hit or miss start the intro track on this LP shipwrecked is actually not that bad it has some beautiful guest vocals an interesting beat change up toward the back end of the song Mick really goes hard with his delivery at this point in the track in a way it kind of sets the tone for this very relaxed and watery album but for anybody who was expecting this record to really come out of the gate with fire this track and sort of be like sonic ambien and I wouldn't really say Mik picks up the pace with the second track either THC which is the shortest track on the tape it feels kind of like a filler song it's really redundant with its hook constantly telling me it's going to get me high but this song really does anything but this track is more sobering than it is intoxicating there's the song healer with gene do I do like the theme the story of this track mix versus about getting together with this girl and kind of describing this romantic encounter that they have where they go out they head up the Starbucks they're having intelligent conversations so on and so forth it's nice it's sweet there's a nice sentiment to this track but I don't really care for the blase singing and sort of rapping or spoken word toward the back end of this track that gene brings to the table it reminds me of something like that kilo Kish would do this type of thing just does not do anything for me and I'm even less interested in the no-name gypsy verse on the following track comfortable it's easily the most boring feature on the entire record mix singing on the hook of this track isn't really that on point but again we do get another series of verses from him that do save the track in a sense and keep it from being completely skippable however once the tracklist gets into songs like vibe it's really smooth sailing right to the very end of the record I love the track vibe it is some sweet intoxicating jazz wrap with an amazing electric piano sample I love the line that Mick delivers on this track for the art and not the hand clap when it's clear you can call it saran wrap I also love the Jill Scott Black Thought reference on this track - and the song jazz is as beautiful as it is philosophical it's a song about the truth choosing the right life path and speaking out and throughout the track - there are references to jazz jazz artists and music but also referencing that jazz traditionally has been used as a term to talk about how people might just spout BS there's also a static selected B on black sheep which has this really quiet droning synth note in the background some sweet soulful chord / Russians and this is definitely attract that to me stands out because of just how urgent and passionate mix flow comes off I mean you don't even need to necessarily read into his lyrics to hear that he's rapping he's writing he's delivering with a lot of heart it's all in his inflection whether he is I guess sort of spinning something he feels very passionate about a bit of truth of the way that he perceives the world or even feeling kind of defeated like on the track drink more water where he's talking about how he can't afford to get his girlfriend into this open mic he performs at but somewhere across the way there is a riff raff concert where people will swarm at there's also an interesting line on this track where it's like he's addressing rappers who seem to make it but then immediately fall off artistically when your stars get chose and your bars get low when you're dull as a butter knife and can't cut I guess the only thing I'm not crazy about what this track is the hook it's a little off just the drink mo water to Cahoon sooo it's just not that catchy or exciting it's not really a I guess an interesting change of pace from the verse it kind of just kills the momentum that the song had going thus far or there's the song Canada dry again not a track that's awful but a song that I feel like mix sort of needs to work on his pacing because the tempo at which his flow and the beat on this track move just feels so mundane but the state does continue with great tracks like hydration the mine does a fantastic job on the hook of this track not only is the singing fantastic but the watery effects laid into his vocals do continue that interesting sonic concept this album brings forward Plus this track also features some of Mick's most dense and aggressive verses yet there's the song martyrs which was another single coming off this tape it's one of the slower and more dreary tracks on the project but stays enthralling because of just how grim a lot of the imagery in Mick's lyrics are and then there's the closer Jerome which is really really really the polar opposite of how the record started very serene very sweet very very quiet and subtle and now we're getting this hard ass rhythm this hard-nosed instrumental with Mick and Joey badass of proair going absolutely insane on the be lately Joey has been dropping a lot of verses where he was just yelling screaming at the top of his lungs and he continues on that hear and Mick does not look like he's going to be shown up on this track either he kind of comes with roughly the same delivery him and Joey are just like neck-and-neck and a lot of these verses in terms of their aggression however it is Joey's verse that ends up wowing me the most though I do love the song overall I love his Goodfellas and then DeNiro wordplay directly after in the next line and how he's saying he wants the dollars he wants the euro just give me this say so I love that rhyme too and that's the project for me overall I think it's really great I have to seriously recommend this mixtape to anybody who is a serious hip-hop fan in 2014 there are some tracks that pale in comparison to others and the worst of all the songs in my opinion is THC it is the shortest does get right out of the way at the beginning of the LP but the rest of the album is just full of nicely written wordy highlights maybe the sonic palette of the instrumentals on this isn't necessarily going to be everybody's style or taste but I think Mick is a very thought-provoking emcee and he's come through with a very interesting conceptual album I'm feeling a strong 7 to a light 8 on this thing transition if you've given this tape a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Mick Jenkins the waters forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new underachievers record seller door terminus ex ordem underachievers is a new york-based hip hop duo this is their full-length commercial debut hopefully you've heard of these guys when they were first making waves a few years ago with their first full-length project a mixtape by the name of indigo ism a mixtape on which the two members of the underachievers is a gold and a que we're dropping a series a gauntlet of rapid-fire raps this was a free tape put out through brain feeder records which is also the label this album is coming out on and cellar-door is a concise album it's 12 tracks 40 minutes and no features outside of a very hefty sample from a portugal the man song in the very last track of this LP which essentially makes up the chorus of that song and I think the move underachievers are making with this record totally makes sense for them their last LP indigo ism was nothing if not a little overly long and I think came off a little redundant because of the overabundance of tracks that we're all touching on a lot of similar subjects like having this third eye vision and dropping acid and smoking and beast coast being Indigo's and spirituality and God and love and positive thinking there are times when it seems like the underachievers are more interested in advancing these themes than they are writing a really catchy or high-quality song or delivering a story or a narrative still there were some incredible highlights and characteristics to the underachievers and this mixtape I loved the hard-hitting attitude of this tape the gritty delivery of the rhymes is a gold fantastic flow and delivery on this tape his inflection is so insane a K's delivery though not quite as out there but very fast very focused very just down to the wire laser type accuracy when it comes to the tempo I loved the relentless flows on this tape the mystical psychedelic production and when a que is a gold really just buckled down they can write some really thought-provoking rhymes rather than just referencing the idea of being thought-provoking so I was excited I was looking forward to seeing how underachievers might grow past this tape how they might advance past it artistically promotionally even though I was a little disappointed by their last release which was a kind of underwhelming EP and the end result here on this record is is not bad I think it's a good record but I am ever so tempted to pull out that term of the euphemism of the sophomore slump yeah this is their first commercial release but it is their second full-length project and even though there are some major highlights on cellar-door this album does kind of also have the makings of a sequel that falls slightly short of expectations and the issues for me on this record they range some of them are technical I actually think in terms of sound quality this is a slightly more lo-fi and grimy your record than indigo ISM and not in an aesthetically superior way either there are a lot of moments on this project where issah and a.k have their vocals purposefully distorted and it gets sort of tiring by the end of the album not only that but this distortion makes it difficult to read some of the bars that they're spinning especially as is and a.k seem to be writing I don't know denser verses this time around it seems like more often than on indigo ISM they are writing themselves down to their very last inch of breath really straining to get those last few words out or sort of jumbling or just mashing words all together as they seem to be spinning a little bit faster than usual - unfortunately issah who is typically my favorite of the two underachievers seems to be especially guilty of this especially as he seems to finish off at the line all your tracks is born on the song sonorous or with his verse in the middle of the track for solace which I might also mention while I'm on it has a beat that sounds exactly like the beat that Mac Miller used with rick ross on his recent phases mixtape there's also Issa's first verse on the track ethereal seems to be a little woozy on the tempo as well which you can contrast directly with a Ches verse right after where he is just on that tempo like he's on a bucking bronco and just never letting go you don't even need the beat behind his voice to hear and feel the tempo you can feel the tempo directly off of his voice but with Issa as soon as the beat drops away the tempo isn't really there quite as much I don't get that sharp sense of tempo from his flow like I do from a Kay's to move on to my next issue with this LP which has more to do with structuring than it does with the recording or the technical side it's just the way it's an akr writing these songs are rather under writing them even though I think they're great rappers and I think the writing better verses on this record than they were on indigo ISM I think their rhymes are more captivating more worthy of sort of diving into and reading into here they're actually doing a better job of delivering that food-for-thought rather than just talking about it I think they're doing an injustice to these songs by delivering them without even seasoning them essentially outside of just good verses and good instrumentals there aren't really any decent intros or outros on a lot of these songs not even a decent chorus or any course at all and I know a course should not be the focus of a song with spitters at this level but still courses were one of the biggest selling points of indigo ISM aka Nessa can certainly write them really well as exemplified by tracks on that tape can on this project I would definitely rather listen to the underachievers with no chorus than some other rappers out there but still I don't think their verses are so quotable or that their songs are so conceptual that they can just completely do without them and have a winning standout captivating track songs like luminescence and nebulous to me just go on and on and on without anything incredibly gripping happening and again not to say these songs are awful there are exceptions like the opener where a K and s are just trading these mini rapid-fire verses from the beginning to the end of the track and there's also the track with kind of hits more of a mid-paced tempo the bars are way more readable the beat is sweet and melodic and jazzy has this really sharp electric piano on it even though I dig these tracks it's the song with courses that to me just have way more replay value like the nakka nakka not gonna hook on caprese which I absolutely love or the song incandescent which has that tough just gritty you a we blowin up southern hip-hop feel to it this instrumental feels like something that could have landed on a an early three 6 mafia project and I think it's one of the best and most catchy tunes uas ever put together there's the song which is one of the few tracks on here that hits a really strong concept where it's kind of about building this utopia of people that sort of buy into the philosophy that a K and s are putting forward where it's like  Fame shallow pursuits anti-hype trends pro spirituality anti ignorant there's the song Felicity which I love toward the back end of this LP an inspirational track that has a beautiful sample running throughout the instrumental and lyrically it's kind of about getting out there and creating that world we're becoming that person becoming that change that you want to see and there's the song amorphous like I said has that portugal demand sample that works is the chorus it's a really great sample it's a great beat and even though it is a little grimy it is a little underground in tone I think it's one of the Papias tracks the underachievers have ever put together and I think it's great overall I really like this project I really enjoyed it I didn't love it more than indigo ISM I actually think I'm just about liking it as much as indigo ism but for slightly different reasons are the hits as big or as infectious I don't think so but it's way more filler free and straightened to the point and I think aka Nyssa have done a better job of driving their message of bringing their message home and translating it in such a way where it comes off as captivating intelligent and kind of makes sense definitely give a listen to this tape if you want to hear some grimy underground New York hip hop it's kind of psychedelic as a positive message as a sort of otherworldly agenda and lots of rapid-fire rapping I'm given this a decent strong seven transition if you've given this record listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it underachievers cellar door forever

hi everyone anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Otis brown the third record the thought of you modern rhythm powerhouse Otis brown the third a drummer who has been been the rhythmic backing for many a jazz artist including the popular and Grammy award-winning Esperanza Spalding and avant-gardist like Oliver Lake this is his full-length debut LP which caught my ear mainly because Otis seems to have the same affinity as me for 50s 60s 70s era quartet quintet Trio style jazz recordings and particularly for me it is the drum sound of these records that I find to be so attractive so clear so crisp so Bumi's so close so intimate it's like I'm actually inside the drum set this is a sound this is a feeling that Brown and his co-producer Derek Hodge we're very careful to recreate it is incredibly fitting that this album is coming out in partnership with Blue Note Records one of the most notorious and important jazz labels during this era of jazz now being that Brown is a drummer and this is his album rhythm does play an incredibly pivotal role in these songs rarely do I come across a drummer that I find there playing to be expressive and and this is definitely one of those instances usually an adjective reserved for people who are playing more tonal instrumentation but there's an incredible amount of feeling in the way that Brown brings this pitter-patter percussion to the surprise cover of Shania Twain's you're still the one Otis is playing on this track is really busy but incredibly gentle there are also a few gospel renditions on this record my favorite being the one on the very end of this LP I am your song and it is amazing how Brown just enhances the rising horns and Nicky Ross's vocals is just the song grows and expands and gets louder of course there are a load of other musicians on this LP out died of braun himself for one Robert Glasper is on piano key on Harold on trumpet Ben Williams on bass John Ellis on sax Shedrick Mitchell on organ and near Felder on guitar the song choices on this LP whether they be original or covers seem to revolve around themes of family and faith and love specifically love for his wife who there is a few tributes to on this album my favorite being the beautiful wonderful instrumentation on the track the two become one weaved into these gorgeous expressive just really tear-jerking horns there is an audio clip of what seems to be somebody officiating a marriage the bass intro to the track is great Robert Glasper piano flourishes throughout the track are wonderful and the horn harmonies are just killer there's just a lot of mature familial love throughout this LP also on the three parts of the title track of this album the thought of you which features vocals from neo-soul singer Bilal which has a very jumpy nimble jagged vocal melody on the track that just sticks with me the thought of you please mine so bad now this track like I said is separated into three different songs which are spread throughout the track listing of the album the first part of these three songs being centered around bob style jam loaded with fiery trumpet solos and even though brown's band is just water tight throughout this song I guess I was a little underwhelmed by this track because it wasn't really an incredibly refreshing sound for this style of jazz and another thing that I don't really gravitate toward with this track is the fact that it is split up in such a way where like on part two it seems like we're entering the song mid jam which in fact we may be because the end of the first part seems sort of finished with the song just coming to a very slow halt as if in the middle of the track somebody just turned off the turntable maybe this second part would have been more enthralling had it been attached to the first in some way and then for the final section of this song I do dig it a little bit because it does bring a pretty significant change to the table I think Robert Glasper soloing on this track is great really melodic and complex but not too hurried or flashy tracks I'm getting a lot of enjoyment out of are like the opener the way truth and life which has this really dizzying strange and angular theme melody that is really difficult to wrap my head around but still is very catchy there's some really intense sax soloing on the song punctuated by piano flourishes from Glasper Brown is playing harder as the band is playing harder almost as if he's egging them on and I love the song stages of thought which has this really ominous looming lumbering lead melody to it that I think is one of the darkest on the entire record it's a really focused fearsome Jam the bass and drum groove on this track is just nasty and then all of a sudden toward the back end of this track Brown breaks into what kind of feels like a hip-hop being Glasper complements it with these weird ascending descending sour piano notes and together this makes for something that sounds like it could come from a wu-tang record then there is the 8 minute gospel medley toward the back end of this track with vocals from Nicki Ross throughout much of these passages and this track is basically like your local Baptist Church's music program on steroids brown and company are are really not writing or delivering concise renditions of these songs in the same way that they did the Shania Twain track they are really just riffing on these tracks but still managing to muster some some really wonderful building intensity especially on tracks like we exalt thee which seems to build higher and higher and higher with every crushing blow of vocals drums and horns overall it's not a bad record in fact it is a very good and varied jazz record there are some tracks I didn't really care for as much as others and I think overall maybe the album is a tad sort of rocky in terms of its flow there are some interludes on this track as well which I don't really care for all that much and there are spots like the broken up in section title track that I don't really see playing that well in between key tracks of this LP but still if you're looking for a modern jazz record with some great composition some great improvisation and a fantastic vintage style recording then I implore to you to give this album a listen I'm feeling a decent too strong seven on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana Otis brown the third thought of you subscribe please forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review the new Porter Robinson record world's this guy is a North Carolina based producer and songwriter who is dropping his full-length debut right here via astral works this year he has been making quite a bit of buzz with some of the singles to drop from this record so far like flicker and sad machine he's been grabbing ears in the wider world of pop music but already he's kind of made a name for himself in the EDM world I know he's done a mix for UKF he's also had the Spitfire EP that's dropped a few years ago which was essentially an EP of electro house tunes brostep I thought Robinson's approach to these styles of electronic music was really epic like on the title track to this thing there's this very refined building set of synth sequences that feel like they could come straight out of a sound track and the song also features one of the most chaotic drops I've ever had the pleasure of laying ears on with EDM at the top of mainstream music culture right now I would figure that Porter Robinson could just continue in this Lane continue in this genre and he would just gain fans as a result of naturally being involved in a style of music that's hot right now but instead he's decided to change up his musical style into something that I think has a bit more crossover appeal because on this LP Robinson is essentially making indie tronic music glitch pop dream pop chillwave maybe a little of that French electro house sound that was popular in the late 2000s thanks to justice this whole 2000s era of music actually seems to be incredibly important to Robinson's music just imagine the biggest names in these Styles like Passion Pit and Crystal Castles m83 justice The Naked and Famous Postal Service and Owl City washed-out Neon Indian early early MGMT imagine all of them but with bombastic EDM style drum Tambor's rocking behind them that's what Porter Robinson does on this LP it's not terrible but it's not really exciting in concept to me and it's not exciting and execution either the idea of this album being mind-blowing is like watching someone lose their over store-brand cereal or soda yes for sure at the end of the day some people might prefer honey Oh's to honey nut cheerios but nobody's coming in saying oh man those honey nut oh man they're changing the game man however I could definitely see this LP making waves in the EDM world because it presents a sound that is yet to cross over into that world but for somebody who is a fan of a lot of the artists or have merely just experienced the artists that Robinson pulls from so obviously this record isn't that thrilling to me because in my opinion he doesn't really craft these influences into anything characteristically different the glitchy swirls of synthesizers good limited that occasionally pop up in these tracks feel like they could have come out of an early Crystal Castles track the song sad machine or divinity had these buzzing loud synthesizer chords and bright peppy melodies that could have come out of any number of Owl City or m83 tracks the song years of war has a bright synthetic lead melody that could have come out of an early MGMT single and on top of that the song lion-hearted in its verses and the vocals on these verses - it actually sounds just like an early MGMT song for me this record is just a gauntlet of songs that sound a lot like other artists with the exception of maybe the back end of the LP where you get songs like sea of voices which is kind of a long spacious interlude track with just a sea of synth layers on them very ethereal and then after this track we get songs that have more of an overt EDM influence on them with those driving house beats these tracks are actually lichen and don't quite mind the final track on this LP is actually pretty gorgeous melodically but leading up to that last leg of this album the rest of this LP compositionally is pretty run-of-the-mill however that's not to say that it's inherently bad I mean Robinson seems to take quite a bit of care into recreating this stuff the production is very crisp it's lush it's clean the melodies pour through very brightly and are sticky and catchy the songs for the most part all have a very nice pace to them a very nice groove very explosive exuberant choruses and overall I do think it's a cohesive album with a pretty nice flow with the more dynamic and and gentle tracks toward the very end of the LP it's not a record that really seems to be focused on its singles or focused on creating a series of singles it has a nice conceptual flow to it Robinson definitely grabs a sound or an idea and kind of runs with it so I definitely give him kudos on trying to craft a holistic ambitious record and there are some whimsical melodies buried in the very loud EDM style production on this thing even if they are a little smothered and mostly delivered with these very cutesy female Vocaloid vocals so you're kind of getting this really cute baby pitch the cheeks of a robot kind of feel and then there are tracks like flicker which have a very nice strong funk electro groove to them and a sort of dirty grimy distorted bass line directly after there's fresh static snow which i think has an even more distorted bass line and I love that Robinson can appropriately balance these distorted harsh heavy elements with some very beautiful melodies the dude is definitely a capable producer but I think his songwriting ideas just run really thin not only were they thin at the beginning of the album where it was very apparent where all of them were coming from but by the middle point of the album it kind of gets old to hear all of these decent melodies and kind of cutesy vocals get buried underneath tons of distorted and overly compressed drums and since not only that but some of the tracks in the middle of the cell P have these faux uplifting choruses that feel like they were just crafted to pander to a group of people who get their music recommendations from like Apple product commercials so while no this is not like a god-awful album or anything like that I can't really say I'm enjoying it honestly I enjoyed his last EP so much more and I would have rather heard him follow through on that EDM style I think he was so much closer to a distinct sound going in that direction with that it feels like on this record you kind of hit the reset button because now it just kind of sounds like any other artist toying with these sounds for sure yeah his drums are louder and he's using these Vocaloid vocals more than I think most artists do playing with this style but that's not really enough for me to celebrate it or bow to it or enjoy it it's fine if you're crazy about these styles of music more than I am at least try it out Robinson has been listening so closely that he has the technical side down and like I said it's not like he's doing these styles of music and injustice it's just not anything incredibly exciting or refreshing to me in terms of the sound the songwriting which is why I'm feeling a strong five to ol eight-six on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana Porter Robinson forever

all my fridge a bright-red spoon man they're too damn bad bad nigga nigga nigga man and man and man down hi everyone Anthony fan tanto here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new spoon record they want my soul this is the latest full-length LP from Austin texas-based band spoon an indie slash alternative rock group who penned some of the most commercially and artistically solvent records in these genres in the 2000s albums that might not have been the most cutting-edge in rock music ever or for that time period but they were certainly loaded with catchy songs strong grooves and a really impassioned vocal delivery from frontman Burt Daniel that would have certainly resonated with people no matter what decade you placed it in records like girls can tell and kill the moonlight and gimme fiction and gah gah gah gah gah and one thing that I've always admired about spoon as they have progressed and gotten more popular and and made hit singles that did their reputation wonders they continued to deliver albums with very organic natural sounding recordings the typically warm bass the really loud clear crispy drums the thin crunchy guitars occasionally the band weaving in strings piano tambourine and even in their Poppaea SMO Minh spoon finds ways to experiment add a little bit of noise and grit to some of their recordings either that or delivering songs that are incredibly stripped back surprisingly skeletal now at this point it's been four years since the release of spoons last full-length LP transference not a high point a high watermark in their discography but not really a catastrophic disappointment either and that's the thing about spoon they've put out so many records at this point that have consistently delivered roughly the same sound with some very minor alterations here and there they're a band that I don't think is ever going to really disappoint their fanbase at least not in a boy of unpredictable glory anyway once again with this new record spoon delivers a roughly straightforward pop and rock album that has some hits and has some misses the tracklist on this thing is loaded with good singles or discography but when they are it's great then there's the song do you a really punchy little pop rock single that has a nice little refrain to it do you it's got a nice beat to it a sweet rhythm acoustic guitars just a lean mean pop rock machine and there's some other tracks on here that sort of fit that same bill as well what is the most appealing thing about them is that they're really straightforward and accessible and sticky like the title track off of this LP the track rainy taxi resonates with me as well it's got these really water moody melodies rippling across one of the nastiest beats I've heard in an indie rock song in a while Britt delivers some really urgent lyricism on this track there's some noisy pianos scattered throughout the song too this is the kind of weird noisy instrumental studio experimentation that appeals to me on so many Beatles records and as modern as spoon sounds you can really pick up on a lot of musical quirks from that era of the 60s and 70s that that ring true in their music today like the song let me be mine which starts off with the kind of rock groover ii that led to iconic songs like Gary Glitter's rock and roll now there are some songs on this LP that don't really appeal to me that much for one reason or another for one the opening track rent I pay another song where spoon picks a groove and sticks with it nearly song just crumbles into dust it feels like almost half a song then there's the song inside out one of the notoriously strict back in minimal tracks in the spoon album track listing this time around however this side of spoons persona has never really Blee Blee been an incredible selling point for me there's another track on here that seems to be sort of about unrequited love and brings a lot of iral lyrics like you said you needed me like an ocean needs sand does an ocean needs sand the ocean has a lot of sand to begin with or maybe she didn't mean it like that it's moments like this where I kind of find myself nodding my head in agreement with the resounding criticism that spoon is kind of generic and that their music isn't that adventurous but for every spot on this LP that's that's sounds like a very spare and in lonely xylophone melody playing itself throughout the song - it's an interesting closer and I think kind of a brave finished this LP again spoon is just kind of a trusty band this record is nothing that really blows me away but I certainly found myself enjoying much of the LP I guess I can kind of liken this band in this record in general to like a car a really hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new common album nobody's smiling camon more like come and get a better name I hate couch' chesta and I wish he was dead I wish God if there was a god that he or she would come down with a lightning bolt of justice and just strike him in the face and long after I'm dead he's still gonna be around in in a disgusting display of evil always triumphing over good common is a famed Chicago MC and actor and a poet in the truest sense of the word and in my opinion one of hip-hop's true hippies in a good way if you're ever in the mood for some classic thought-provoking Midwest hip hop do give albums like resurrection and one day it'll all make sense a listen this guy's career started in the 90s during this decade he dropped some really good features with De La Soul as well as the roots as he progressed into the 2000s he would work with black star as well as Kanye West who has produced for his albums on numerous occasions and into the 2000s his artistic momentum seemed to carry on as well with really great albums like water for chocolate and B which was his inaugural album for Kanye West's GOOD Music label a label that he has been on ever since with the exception of his last full-length LP the dreamer the believer which in my opinion was one of Commons least memorable albums in years even though it sort of did mark a new era of his career plus it was not really marketed or promoted that well I think this album was dropped like five days before Christmas which is maybe one of the worst times you can put out a commercial record and the singles off of this LP weren't even really that sticky or controversial or hot more people were talking about common subliminal beef with Drake at the time then they were the music on this record with this new record of his however I am sensing a little bit more of a commotion around this new stuff though I do still think common might be in the midst of an artistic dry spell that I think he's been in ever since the album universal mind control with tracks like make my day and sex for sugar I think this album has some of his worst songs ever on it a lot of Commons fans might not be head over heels for an album like finding forever but I find this record to be way more interesting and eclectic than the more commercial stuff he's been putting out lately yeah I do like albums like water for chocolate as well as B but I also admire some of Commons more left-field releases like Electric Circus where you get hints of not only hip hop but rock and soul and pop music plus there are a ton of interesting features on this record common being one of the first big-name rappers to sort of bridge that hip-hop indie gap allowing somebody like laticious Adair onto his record now like I said 2011 and the dreamer the believer sort of marked a new era for Commons career with this last release of his I feel like we're kind of getting the story and the mindset of an aging old schooler who's kind of embracing his home and celebrating his untouchable spot in hip hop history though there are moments on this record where I do feel like Kamen might be coming off in a way where it just feels like he's trying a little too hard to be aggressive or badass sort of like on the song sweet which i think is absolutely crazy truthfully I'm enjoying Commons flow and his lyrical content a lot more on this latest LP of his nobody's smiling but I can't say I'm really enjoying it more than the dreamer the believer because it brings a host of entirely different issues to the table now for sure there are some serious highlights on the cell peace songs that I think are great but they just happen to occur at the very beginning and the very end of the album there's the track the neighborhood where Kamen delivers a bunch of grimy sobering Street centric lines that seem really dismal there's a lot of violence referenced in the way a lot of lost hope people just getting caught in the violence of this concrete jungle and this is the type of song that I would expect from an album titled nobody's smiling given that common is from Chicago and has given an album cover that looks like this the instrumental is fantastic on this thing I love the strings weaved into this beat and there is a fantastic feature from little herb on this track to check out his faisal lanin mixtape that dropped earlier this year that I've given a review and did like these same lyrical themes Landover a much more ominous and and quiet subtle beat on the song no fear right after and then we have the song kingdom with vince staples another good feature on this record and it's a conceptual track it's a theme track about somebody who is young growing up in a violent city and trying to find solace in God in religion but having a difficult time relating paying attention finding value in this because it's so hard to survive in this violent urban setting in my opinion these are great tracks so good that there's there's really no reason to lose faith in common as he is aging in his rap career he could still write really coherent interesting captivating songs but he doesn't keep this consistency up throughout the middle of the record there's the song diamonds which could have been a quality track but Big Shot is featured on this song and delivers one of the worst features I've heard this year he basically moseys on in into the song of a hip hop legend and moans and ad-libs ridiculously in between Commons verses common should not have allowed this Big Sean should not have done it everyone should have known better then there's the song black magic which I enjoy lyrically but it has one of the most obnoxious instrumentals on the entire LP black magic black magic black magic and the song speak my piece maybe one of my least favorite tracks lyrically it's just sort of a bunch of forgettable braggadocio from common not that I don't want him to brag when he does see success but it's not like it's that much of a thrill to hear him rap about his spot in the hip-hop industry right now especially when you have people like jay-z who are a little more riveting with it Plus Commons bars kind of stop halfway into the track and the rest of the song from the halfway point is just the instrumental they've been playing through the first half but it just kind of carries the song out until the next song decides to play this same week structuring hurts the title track on this album as well I do like the lines the verse that common brings on the first half of the song he delivers more lines that give a vivid portrayal of the social darkness that Chicago is moving through right now but after that we get a really long-winded and sort of uninteresting spoken word piece from Malik Yusef that really cools the heat down that the song had been bringing thus far it seems like common gets things going and either doesn't really finish off a song or just kind of hands it off to a feature that isn't as good as common I feel like this is one of his most padded out albums in a while as far as features aside from Vince staples and little herb I think the only other feature that I liked was drusy on the song hustle harder which does have kind of a ridiculous hook that makes me cringe a little bit but the song is about a woman who hustles hard she's independent she's badass I like Commons verse I like jay-z's verse even if her delivery seems a little too nicki minaj inspired at least on this particular song i've heard other songs of hers and on other tracks she sounds much more in line with a lot of the other Chicago rappers the young Chicago rappers that are coming up right now sort of like Chief Keef and little Reese King Louie little herb overall this this album is okay they're just so many either underwhelming or utterly disappointing tracks through out the middle of the tracklist and what's even more alarming or worrying is that there are two tracks in the bonus edition of this album that are loads better than the songs that actually landed on the standard edition of this record for one the song seven deadly sins it could have fit right after the song kingdom and would have played beautifully into this religious theme that that song displays it's got a great beat I love how common play is on these different seven deadly sins in his lyrics and it's a common solo track you don't have anybody else coming in and interrupting the song and stealing the spotlight and then there's the song out on bond with Vince staples maybe it's a little redundant given that Vince staples is already on the standard edition of the record but it's still a better track than say diamonds or real this is an alright album from common I like a lot of the tracks off of it and even though they didn't make it onto the standard edition I do have just really strong feelings for some of these bonus tracks I think Commons started well with this record I think he ended well with this record especially with her wine that which is a beautiful song that sort of reflects upon his time in the hip hop industry creating music with different people one verse specifically centering around J Dilla the time when he was making music with him when he received beats from him sort of seeing him pass away before his eyes it's really moving part of this record even if this song was not about J Dilla this would be an amazing track simply because Kamen gives such a personal recollection of the life of a very close friend who is not around anymore if this kind of consistency if this kind of heart-wrenching storytelling continued throughout this record I could see it being a total winner and a standout in his discography but instead we get filler we get moments like Big Sean on diamonds that couldn't be worse for the album's flow I'm feeling hail I six on this LP transition if you given this thing a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantan Oh common nobody's smiling forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new fallujah album the flesh prevails before I get into this review I want to say thank you to these cute little babies for the shout out in a recent video that they were in I will link to that video down in the description box and fallujah is a california metal band this is their second album their sophomore album a lot of metal fans passing this record my way telling me to check it out really urgent in their recommendation of this album and these guys are a death metal band a technical death metal band to be specific genre I don't really mind or even enjoy at its roots or with some of its bigger names like Niall death cynic gore guts atheist I also enjoy a little bit of ulcerate bands like this technical and melodic death metal bands find ways to make death metal a little more dynamic and incorporate some really complex compositions and guitar work and melodies into the tremolo Pickett ARS and the beats and the guttural growling that we typically hear in death metal and Fallujah is not only pretty flashy and they are incredibly melodic but they try to work in a bit of atmosphere into their songs as well there are loads of epic soaring guitar solos on top of these chugging riffs and intense drums and these guitar solos are soaked in this really larger-than-life reverb that feels kind of interstellar there's just relentless drumming throughout this record - the rhythms the grooves they're all pretty dizzying and for the most part I think the band does a good job of balancing simplicity and complexity on this album - even though the performances may seem really difficult it's not that hard to grasp what the band is doing on a first listen they might have a slow moving chord progression but then they'll throw some insane drumming behind it or they'll have a really difficult groove the riff is bringing forward but they'll pair that with one of those sweet huge melodic guitar solos Felucia has a lot of good things going for them but I still don't like this album it's it's just a shame and it really for the most part comes down to production I don't like how this record is mixed recorded compressed to death the way this record sounds to me is absolutely excruciating after long periods of time and not in a way where it's like whoa this band's really brutal I feel like sonically there that they're really pushing the envelope it's not because the band feels incredibly loud but again feels incredibly compressed all the sound all the instrumentation just brick walled and smushed down until you're just getting this bodyless chaotic wall of guitars and drums that are just continually smothering one another in this really ugly display frequency clashing not only does the reverb on this LP sound just grossly synthetic but the drums have the tambour of smacking the driver side door of a car with a piece of PVC pipe the vocal delivery and the guitar tone as well are kind of dime-a-dozen as far as this current state of melodic and technical death metal goes even though it seems like Fallujah puts a lot of effort into the composition of this record really making sure that every note every drum beat every vocal is in its place and perform to perfection as far as the mixing on this record it's frustratingly tangled there are some more ethereal tracks on this record that do serve as kind of a counterpoint and a bit of a break a bit of a breather from the more intense and dense tracks on this LP but all the other songs just kind of blend together for me in a really unappealing way I can most definitely appreciate flawless punchy clean metal production records like carcasses heart work will forever be a metal favorite of mine and metal classic and sort of a pioneer in the current trend of ultra clean digital metal production that we see today but bands like Fallujah push this trend so far I don't even feel like I'm listening to humans perform on a record anymore to me this record is like the equivalent adding sex with a robot the most expressive thing to me on this record are the melodies and melodically it's not like this band brings anything forward that a group such as Animals As Leaders doesn't already and to me melody alone does not make a good song if all of your foundational instrumentation on a track sounds like soulless droids are performing it then the melody doesn't really make a difference I know in modern metal this kind of record qualifies as a very brutal sound but to me brutality is very human characteristic it's an animalistic characteristic if you strip your music of its animality of its and you just make it as robotic and as sequenced and as perfect as possible the brutality doesn't really seep through instead for me this record reads as cold emotionless ruckus with some nice melody splashed on top I'm feeling a strong for tool like five on this thing transition if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana Felucia forever
